show.title: Myths: The Greatest Mysteries of Humanity
show.description: Each episode examines legendary myths with the assistance of scientists, archaeologists and experts. From biblical stories such as the Holy Grail, to historical mysteries like Attila's tomb, to modern legends — the series explores inexplicable events and ancient legends.

episodes.title: King Arthur

entries.text: Freud thought dreams were wish fulfillment fantasies, Jung saw them as healing to imbalanced psyches, and Joseph Campbell saw myths as spiritual training. My sense is that the Arthurian romances are so successful because on one level they’re wish fulfillment, on another level they are healing to an imbalanced collective psyche that devalued the feminine, and on another level, they offer tremendous spiritual training

Common myths support common identities, and part of why the Arthurian material spread across Europe is because it resonated with so many Europeans. Its ability to do so came from its ability to reflect so much myth and history—we see Classical, Christian, Celtic and Caucasian myths, memories, magic and crusades. With a French Lancelot and a German Parzival, the story created sharable narratives and identities.
Stories that are true are successful. We’re drawn to stories that resonate. We don’t always know what they’re resonating with and the truth they represent might not be literal or moral.
In the case of Arthur, it resonates with its audience on countless levels. True romantic fantasies and true romantic nightmares, resonant visions of both moral righteousness and moral failure.

Jung saw dreams as snapshots or x-rays of the psyche that represent both its imbalance and its internal efforts to heal.  What we see in the Arthurian stories is a representation of a hyper masculine hyper Christian reality that trying to heal its rift with femininity. On one hand this looks like Guinevere’s feminine disruption of a hyper masculine order, and on another, we see the Grail quest as a quest for the feminine.

King Arthur is the most successful state myth of the most recent and expansive global empire — one that established English as the international common-tongue and one that hardly lost to the writers of our history.

On one level, this is also why we all know Hercules and the Avengers. On another level, this is a bit unfair to myths that provide a tremendous amount of what Joseph Campbell would call “spiritual training.”

These stories don’t just model ideals of the state and it’s status quo, they also point to a path of individual development from and beyond the state. While Arthur redefines the standard of governance as motivated by fairness and equality, the quest for the grail is spiritual, mystical, philosophical and profound. There’s a reason why Wagner’s Parsifal was an adaptation of his earlier interpretation of Siddhartha’s quest for enlightenment.

Freud thinks myth and dream re about wish fulfillment while Jung thinks they help us heal, but what a good storyteller knows is that the fantasy is exactly what seduces us into a plot that brings change

It is exactly the fantasy and wish fulfillments that are, on the surface, the most seductive. Then, of course, once we are pulled in to the Fantasy, pulled into the dream then we can be worked. Then we can be transformed and changed by the efforts of a storyteller.

The bigger question is where did this tire where did the style come from? It certainly isn’t Roman toga‘s. No, this attire comes from the Caucasus region, from which the Romans brought mercenaries into Europe. This is a place where we find the actual towers we see in European legend and women associating with them, this is where we get the trousers we wear,

On one level we see a state in myth encouraging love for a Christian king and good social orderly moral behavior. On another level we see a story about a spiritual quest and reformation the reformation of the status quo of a wasteland of a society that is decayed that’s eating itself with greed, whose supply chains and  trade routes have been overtaken by wolves and pirates. Like the Templars who brought order to the trade routes of Europe, Arthur brought order to a kingdom in chaos.

There’s no doubt that there are real historical figures that influenced the myth of King Arthur, and it’s also the case that clearer universal qualities are working their way into this historic narrative, making it increasingly mythic.

Arthur looks a lot like Hercules. In the folklore, his shield can become a boat, which reminds us of the cupboat Hercules takes to the Hesperides, an island of golden apples. Arthur also goes to an island of golden apples. And though both narratives associate the cup and a woman with life everlasting, the most obvious similarity of these culture defining heroes is their origin story. Both were conceived by a father who pretended to be their mother’s husband.
From Nennius to the World Wars, Arthur’s defense of England tends to be renewed every time it needs defenders.
This is the story of a king establishing order and righteousness establishing itself in the face of greed and evil. This is the story of Horus creating order,

entries.question: Which role does magic play in King Arthur?
entries.text: You might say that magic was opposed by Christianity and opposed by this European Christian mythology, however Merlin is on no uncertain terms a very positive figure in the myths. And he is on no one certain terms a magician. No one associates him with the priesthood. And so while we do see the conflict of Christianity and morality with magic, as represented by the conflict with morgana, Merlin’s Christian mother and demon father present an image of integration that presents magic in a positive light within the Christian imagination.

entries.question: Are Camelot and the knights of the round table the utopia that explain the success of the myth?
entries.text:
The story of Camelot is the story of Eden recast as a narrative with which Europeans can identify. On another level, it’s the story of anyone whose household was been destroyed by infidelity. So though our fantasies resonate with Camelot’s utopia, resonance can also be found with its downfall.

Tolkien recombined them in Gondor, whose tree, like the tree of sedentary from folklore, died when the patriarch left, and flowered on his return.

entries.question: What does the round table stand for? ◊ In medieval times, guests were seated in respect to their hierarchic status. Who was sitting closest to the host was the most honored guest. The roundtable is a symbol of the ideal of equality.
entries.text: Long before and long after the reign of Arthur, the world was seen as a disk — as a Round Table. Ok one level, to be king of the Round Table is to be king of the world.

entries.question: On another level, the great disk can be seen in the Zodiac — why always 12? 12 signs, 12 gods, 12 knights. The round table is the great disk—the disk of the planet and the disk of the sky. To be king of the roundtable is to be king of heaven and earth.
entries.text: Where the Round Table represents equality, the table of the Narts featured a vessel in the center that reacted to truth and dishonesty. It was from this table that the proto-arthurian knights, the Narts, set out on their quests. In the Nart Sagas, it’s not just the cup that reacts to untruth, it’s the iron of their armor and weapons thst becomes as weak as their hearts are untrue. And so we see the connection between the true heart of the knight and worthiness decided by a vessel grail.

entries.question: Is King Arthur the best known Brit in the world?
entries.text: If King Arthur is the best known Brit in the world, it’s because he’s the most mixed Brit there’s ever been—a Classical, Christian, Celtic, Caucasian, Crusader who brings all of their myths and identities into concert.

entries.question: Why is King Arthur so popular among satirists? Where does this potential of humor come from?
entries.text:
Arthur represents the bringing of Order and Morder represents rebellion. And on the other side of the rebel is the trickster. Where the rebel attacks the tyrant’s order, the trickster speaks truth to power and pokes at pride. To the trickster, order and power are always a joke. So as a representative of order and power, even if he’s the best representative, Arthur draws satire.

Arthur may be the best personification of order bringing but he is still a representative of order, which will always be the target of jokesters, prankster‘s and trickster figures. There will always be a dichotomy between tyrants and rebels serious people and tricksters, this is timeless. This is the tension between disruption and stability. This is a crucial tension that must always exist. We must always be pursuing stability and we always be challenging its order.

entries.question: In King Arthur we have a lot of strong women as the Lady of the Lake, Morgane. How feminist is the story originally / today? How can these strong women be explained historically?
entries.text:
The entire grail quest can be seen as a hypermasculine quest for the feminine

The Arthurian material is like the dream material of a psyche that is repressing the feminine on one level but on a deeper level knows it’s a problem. And this is why we see the patriarchal power structure associated with a wasteland at a loss for vitality and a quest for a grail that repdresents femininity. It’s also why it presents an order fragile to the feminine disruption of Guinevere, their Eve figure.

The Arthurian consciousness is expressed as both repressing the feminine and in quest for it. Morgana represents the repressed feminine vitality. The wasteland of Arthurian legend represents the wasteland we get when we represss feminine vitality. The sun of Guinevere represents the shadow disruption of the feminine when it’s repressed. And the Grail quest represents our recognition that the splitting off and repression of feminine consciousness has created Ed a wateland that can only be redeemed by the integration of what we’ve split off and repressed, which is the feminine LF and so the quest for the Grail, which represents, at least on one level, the womb, is the quest for the integration of femininity and all that it represents. This also becomes a story aboutnloveniver war, which we see recurr in the convergence of pacific at and feminist movements from Athens to modern day.

entries.question: Is it probable that King Arthur was a Roman military leader?
entries.text:
The fall of Camelot echoes the fall of both Eden and Rome, which built and abandoned Britania. This created a power vacuum and triggered invasion. But though the military was withdrawn, mercenaries, who had been paid in land, didn’t want to leave. And so, as the story goes, a Roman commander, Artorius, stayed behind. And with the help of these soldiers, he defended Londinium—a contender for Camelot.

Part of why this story is so compelling is because the soldiers he led were a strange group of foreigners who jousted on horseback in heavy armor and told the story of a king, who, like Arthur, when he died, demanded his sword be cast into water; and as with Arthur, his attendant faked it, and like Arthur, the figure  insisted until, finally, the meteor sword, a sword from stone, was thrown in the sea.

The myth of King Arthur has assembled itself from pieces of history and myth, for which reason the disqualification of any sources based on their lack of certain elements is kind of a joke, to put it kindly. Tolkien was less kind. His point about Arthur is that storytellers draw from what he called a Cauldron of Stories. This was a poetic expression of the imagination. Do our dreams not mix life with legend? Myths are no different. The quest for a linear or reductive comparison is a symptom of our own hypermasculine Western consciousness. What we should really be asking is what was in the water. All of it was. Celtic, Christian, Caucasian and Classical myths, legends and historical figures—all of it. It is exactly the repetitions of history and legend that result in a myth like Arthur’s.

entries.question: Why is Monmouth’s Historia a founding myth of Great Britain?
entries.text:
Fact or fiction,Monmouth didn’t just articulate a lineage of kings in doing so,, he created a story of Britain,

Monmouth’s Historia mimes the founding myth of Rome. Where the Aeneid tells the story of how the first Roman king came from Troy, Monmouth tells the same story. Brutus, brother of Aeneas, appears as the first king. Did Monmouth make it up, or does this take us back to a memory of a mythic concept that had been introduced by Romans at a time they were still trying to bring citizens of Londinium to identify with Rome? Either way, the narrative presented by Monmouth creates continuity between the Classical world and Britain before presenting an ideal king in which we see major historical memories and essential mythological textures.

More than a state myth for England, the Arthurian material represents an integration of material thst the imagination and cultural spirit had been trying to integrate everywhere — Christian, Classical, Celtic, Caucasian.and the integration was happening at a time when the populations had been integrating for the common cause of the Crusades, which also informed the stories. It even seems likely that much of the material came from cathars, templar  and other sects that were themselves transnational.

entries.question: What’s King Arthur’s secret of rulership? Why is he often used as a role model for political leaders?
entries.text: Arthur’s defining power in reality was probably his ability to get armies and leaders on his side. The Round Table may have been the Roman amputheatres in which he called the English to fight.

entries.question: Evolution of the myth: How did the myth become the version as which we know him today?
entries.text:
The Myth of Arthur has assembled itself from countless sources—historical and mythic. And as it has, though it’s grown further from any kind of historical truth, it’s only become more resonant. Our hearts are the target towards which it has repreatedly adjusted its aim.

Most Arthurian scholars are focused on the tension between Celtic or Norse pagan mythology‘s meeting Christian mythology‘s in the Arthurian Saugus, but this leaves out to essential streams one is pagan pagan classical Roman mythology and the other is Caucasian mythology that was imported by Roman mercenary as he turned on Rome retain power after the fall of Rome and then ended up defining the aesthetic that we know is the medieval era, this is heavy armor on horseback jousting towers ladies with handkerchiefs and pants as opposed to Togus.

Where we see the clear evidence of the classical mythology isn’t just in the Hercules figures that are pulled out of the ground and displayed in museums all throughout England, but also in Geoffrey of Monmouth story that introduces Arthur on such a major level, first British king is presented as Brutus, who comes from Troy, and Baron AnnaGrace the story of Rome in the classical world into the mythology of England. And of course where the grail is associated with immortal life in the Arthurian saga, the cup of heavy is the symbol of the mortality for the classical mythology’s, and it’s Hercules he marries he be upon his death in this represents is achievement of the mortality.

FALL OR ROME AND RISE OF ARTHUR CONTINUED – When Rome began collapsing and pulled out of Britain after having been there for centuries,  while the legions left, many soldiers and mercenaries had been paid in lands thst were now in a power vacuum. What seems to have happened is the rise of a Roman commander who led those who were left behind. His key skill was rallying support, and his historical connection to the round table may have been in relation to the round amphitheaters in which support was rallied around the message of a common cause. The heart of Roman London, Londinium, persists to this day. And among those who rallied in defense of the formerly Roman occupied England were former mercenaries from the Caucasus and North of the Black Sea, and it seems thst this is where the Arthurian material got its aesthetic

ENGLAND’S CAULDRON OF STORIES – Imagine you’re an English family before Caesar jnvades, then he conquers England and loses supposedly his sword after seekng Whiskey heal Scottish wounds and calling it the elixir of life. Then, in come Clasical myths, like thst of Hercules, whose statues fill British museums and who, like Arthur, was born of a father pretending to be someone else, and, who like Arthur, goes to the island of golden apples, where the sun sets, and where Arthur is associated with the Grail, Hercules immortality is symbolized by his marriage to Hebe, the divine cup bearer, who gives him Nectar. Then, everyone in the Roman Empire, including England, converts to Christianity, which offers  eternal life as an elixir  in a chalice. The Roman empire then loses the ability to defend England and withdraws, by which time they’ve brought in mercenaries who tell stories about truth telling vessels, swords made of meteor stone thrown in lakes when kings die and heavily armored men on horseback thst have been seen jousting in front of ladies in towers since 1200 BC. So imagine this cauldron of consciousness that’s taken all this in. The Arthur myth is a mix of everything—the whiskey Caesar called  aqua vitae and the nectar of hebe and tbe  blood of Christ and the truth telling vessel AND the Celtic cauldron of Dagda — they’re all there in the Arthurian material. And then that material is there in Aragorn and the silver cup Bilbo retrieves. The material just keeps alchemizing and evolving. And what it’s always evolving towards is the moving reflection of our own psyches.

FRENCH: With Lancelot and his family we see the French more clearly represented in the story. Here we see an association of the French man with a lover — even a scandalous one — that persists to this day.

The Mayan throne was a mat on which the culture’s myth was woven, and into this myth was woven the entirety of their culture.

This is a perfect metaphor for the Arthurian throne. His myth is one that weaves together the threads of Europe—Classical, Celtic, Caucasian, Christian, Anglo, German, French, Welsh. We can work to pick apart it’s sources, but it’s successful resonance with so many people depends on the successful blending of so many identities.

HERCULES: The birth of England’s greatest hero is a near exact match for the birth of Rome’s—Hercules. In both cases they are fathered by the ultimate patriarch—Zeus and Uther--who take the form of the mother’s husband.

ARTHUR & THE ARK: Like Arthur, the Ark is destined to return again, and like Arthur, the Ark’s coming and going can be associated with the sun, which it emulates as a golden vessel in which the god travels. This can be seen in the golden cup boat of the sun in which Hercules travels and in the gold plated boats that led the Egyptian sunrise ritual for what must have seemed like aeons. The golden rod can be associated with the golden line or the golden path of the sun, which we also see in the yellow brick road or the yellow arrows on the Camino de Santiago. In the golden chalice we recognize the golden cup boat of the sun that Hercules rode from sunrise to sunset, from which he retrieved a golden apple that also shined like the shn. The ark itself, the golden vesse in which the sun journeyed, would also have been well known. From the chariot of the sun to the cupboat of Hercules and the solar prow of Osiris — time and again we  see the sun associated with a golden vessel in which the sun travels.  In Tennysons take, Arthur arrives as a baby in a basket, like Moses.

entries.question: What makes the Bermuda Triangle myth so special?
entries.text:
It’s alive today – it’s an active part of our collective imagination. And based on the role it plays, it has become a repository for virtually every unproven but not disproven possibility – from Aliens to mystical energy and sea monsters, rare natural phenomena, you name it.

The Bermuda Triangle isn’t just a repository for all kinds of myths and phenomena, it’s also one of the key places they all converge. Atlantis, Underwater Archeology, Psychic Powers, UFO’s, Military Mysteries—all of these threads become fabric in the mythic triangle. Are these stories cautionary tales designed to keep us from paradise? These stories are traditionally used to keep kids from going into the woods or exploring sex too early. Are these serving to keep us from going into the unknown?

Underwater kingdoms are ancient mythological ideas that can be found all over the world. Achilles‘ Mother, Nart Matriarchs and in some cases even Guinevere, for example, are from kingdoms below the sea.

entries.question: How did the Bermuda Triangle myth come about?
entries.text: The oldest kings were of fishing ports, and wild stories about the sea are as old as boats. You might say there’s always been a Bermuda Triangle – a place over there beyond the known and observed, where all the craziest stuff you ever heard of happens. From Greek mythological sea monsters to mysterious phenomenon in the Bermuda Triangle – this is just an updated incarnation of the same old story.

entries.question: There are innumerable theories: UFOs, the crystal energy of Atlantis, wormholes ... Why do different myths mix (here)?
entries.text: One of the theories of what goes on in the Bermuda Triangle involves rogue waves, which, while literally compelling, make even better metaphors.  The Bermuda Triangle is where all the little disturbances in our imagination add up to something huge.  Some of these disturbances may be statistical, some psychological projections, some weird but natural, and under this cover, who knows, maybe there’s some stuff we won’t understand without expanding our worldviews.

entries.question: Why is the case of the USS Cyclops so puzzling?
entries.text: The story of the USS Cyclops plays into the archetypal narrative of a lost crew and ship that was carrying metal ore. In this case, 300 men died. It was one of the worst maritime accidents in US Navy history. So what’s with these ore stories? They were coming out at a time when we were just beginning to assimilate electromagnetic and radio waves ideas into our imaginations. So where are we going to project our wildest ideas about the newly discovered fields? In the wildest most unknown territories, including the Bermuda Triangle.

entries.question: One might ask – do these stories emerge from initial incidents? From writers? Or do they sprout up because they’ve found fertile soil in our imaginations
entries.text: In some ways it’s like a sister story to the Derbyshire, the worst Navy accident in British history – which, again, involved a cargo of metal ore. The same can be said of the Nostromo in Alien, where we can see the motif repeated in an imaginal story.

entries.question: Why did Flight 19 become a myth?
entries.text:
Flight 19 plays into the patterns of major myths that serve major functions. For example, the Chumash tell a story of seven boys who turned to geese and were never seen again—the winter migration of these birds represents the flight of souls to an afterlife. This is one of the key mythic patterns that underlies flight 19 – it’s the story of our boys whose death and flight are the same. Don’t we all want to believe they passed into another world?

The loss of a rescue team while searching for a lost boy has appeared in Naval myths before. Hercules, for example, is lost to the Argonauts when searching for a lost boy and fellow shipmate.

You might say it became a myth as it permeated countless cultural mediums—from pulp magazines like Argosy to Close Encounters of the Third Kind. But it’s not the existence in multiple mediums that make a story a myth, it’s the presence of the story in conversation that supports its multimedia incarnations…which reinforce its presence in the conversation.

entries.question: Dark Powers & Sea Monsters - Sailor's Yarn or Reality?
entries.text:
Skylla and Charybdis seem to be personified versions of true perils – a tight strait, dangerous rocks and even maelstroms. The Skylla and Kharybdis of the Bermuda Triangle are the Blue Hole Vortexes and limestone “Breakers,” dangerous rocks that can be invisible on calm days. As with Charybdis, locals in the Bahama personify the ship-destroying vortices as monsters. The most famous is called Lusca, whose breath creates the maelstrom.

blue holes  are Geological rock formations that create under water cavities extending 100s of feet below sea level. The largest is Dean’s Blue Hole, which has taken many lives. Inside these holes are vast cave networks that have hardly been explored.

Breakers: Bermuda is an ancient volcano surrounded by destructive reefs and hard limestone called “breakers,” which can be invisible on calm days, and cause major shipwrecks.

entries.question: Myth of giant waves - what's in it?
entries.text:
Big Fish and Big Waves stories have been circulating harbor pubs and fishing ports since time immemorial. And though job of science is to dismiss what isn’t empirically and theoretically validated; in recent years, Rogue Waves have been recorded on camera and recreated in labs.

The term, however, is a misnomer – they aren’t the most rogue of waves, they’re the most convergent. Their harmonic or constructive interference is what makes them huge.

A myth is like a rogue wave born of countless small ideas that converge in the fluid medium of our imaginations.

The funny thing about Bermuda Triangle Explanations is that even the most scientific explanations can feel like radical ideas that involve extremely rare phenomena

entries.question: What can be said about the magnetic anomalies in the Bermuda Triangle?
entries.text:
One of the recurring themes – from the Bermuda Triangle to the Devil’s Sea – is that many of the ships are carrying ore. Another theme is that electric or magnetic instruments have failed or been affected. This pattern extends from Christopher Columbus to flight 19. Another theme is the failure of radio waves. The fact that human relationship with electro-magnetism and radio waves is relatively new means that we are still integrating it into both our understanding and our imaginations. These stories play with both – sometimes there are phenomena we hardly understand, and in some cases the Bermuda Triangle is serving as a place for our imagination to model possibilities.

Anomalies in the earth’s magnetic field have been associated with a variety of strange phenomenon – from the perception of alien abductions to compass failures in the Bermuda Triangle.

entries.question: Could methane gas have caused the ships to disappear?
entries.text: Dead fish and plankton decays into Methane Hydrate, which gets trapped in pockets. When these pockets get loose, it’s like bubbles going through the water. If this happens beneath a boat, it’s like the ground giving way.

entries.question: What makes the Dragons Triangle myth so special in Japan?
entries.text: The Japanese Dragon Triangle is like the Pacific doppelganger for the Bermuda Triangle not only do they share similar stories, they also share a latitude and have near opposite longitudes. Where the biggest US Navy Accident occurred in the Bermuda Triangle, the biggest blunder of the British Navy, the Derbyshire, was in the Dragon Triangle – both missions, of course, were carrying metallic ore.

entries.question: How did Charles Berlitz's book really fuel the Bermuda Triangle myth?
entries.text: Myth emerges where pattern converges, his Berlitz’ wrote at the convergence of three great myths – Atlantis, the Bermuda Triangle and Aliens. Fact or fiction, this weaving of threads has created the fabric of what we now think of as the Bermuda Triangle.

entries.question: Why do people want to believe in myths like the Bermuda Triangle?
entries.text:
We don’t want to believe in a world without miracles, which for most of us, conscious or not, means living in a world without soul, free will, divine presence or potentially even meaning. It’s not just about the things that can happen there, it’s that those are the places they seem most likely to happen, and if they can’t happen there, and they can’t happen anywhere.

There is a lot of unknown territory in our psyche– we need a place in the world to project our inner unknown. The Bermuda Triangle has become one of these places.

Why does the Bermuda Triangle myth live on?The Bermuda Triangle doesn’t stand out statistically as much as it stands out in our imaginations. There is a lot of trade traffic and a lot of natural perils. If you want to believe everything is explainable, that’s the myth you’ll project onto the lost ships. If you want to believe in aliens or Atlantis, then that’s the myth you’ll project. So long as traumatic events continue to happen and ships keep disappearing—at a statistical rate or not—we’re going to keep seeing all of our myths

entries.question: Holy Grail - Dr. Will LinnWhat "general" knowledge is there about the Grail? What are the different interpretations of what the Grail could be?
entries.text:
The Grail myths aren’t consistent with one another. One version is that Joseph of Arimathea hosted the last supper, caught Jesus’ blood in its cup, then carried it to Glastonbury (in England). Another version is that Peter carried it from Israel to Rome and sent it to Spain for safety. Another version is that the Templars found or were given the Grail upon their arrival in Jerusalem. Meanwhile, the conflation of the Grail from Arthurian legend with the Holy Cup was a later development; and some of the stories are that the Grail was Cathar Treasure or a vessel used during Pagan rites transformed for Christianity. And the pagan theories deepen, as several scholars associate the grail with earlier images like the Classical cup of Hebe or Celtic Cauldron of Dagda. Then there are the arguments that it isn’t a grail, it’s a stone—the philosopher’s stone—which turns the grail into a sort of symbol for enlightenment. Grail, stone, maybe it’s just a metaphor? Maybe it’s a womb—the womb of Jesus wife and/or any womb. Maybe it’s a meteorite? Maybe it’s all about the mythopoeic imagery of any and all cups? Maybe we should look at holy vessels in older traditions? I’d like to connect it with the crescent moon and thumbnail associated with the resurrection of Inanna. The theories are endless.

Why did the Nazis look for the Holy Grail?Heinrich Himmler very much believed in the Occult, which didn’t just mean that he believed objects like the grail could help him win the war, it also meant that he wanted to create a mythic reality. He didn’t just want the grail, he wanted an order of Nazi Knights. At the same time, the grail is like Excalibur in that it carries a sort of implicit right to rule, which, as seen in Nazi mythology, was an obsession of Himmler’s.

When you think about the Nazi pursuit of the grail, you have to think about it in the context of the intended extermination of the Jews. This would have been the extermination of the “chosen” race, which would have made way for their notion of the master race.

entries.question: Why did the crusaders search for the holy grail?
entries.text:
Crusades are pilgrimages, which are journeys to god. When the crusaders got to Jerusalem, the place where God was supposed to be, and when the Templars took over the temple, where God was supposed to be, I think they didn’t find him, and I think they kept looking—under the temple and across the world. Everyone wants the grail for different reasons, but I think one of them was a sincere existential need to find god – to find divine union. This is the same pursuit that drove alchemists towards the philosopher’s stone. The outer journey is but a projection of the inner quest. I think this is also why we read these stories.

Relics are endowed with meaning such that the possessor of that relic becomes the possessor of that meaning. The possessor of the grail would be arbiter of its meaning, which, in the case of the Grail, could be contorted into a right to Christian rule if not Holy Land possesion.

entries.question: What “powers” are attributed to the Grail (assuming it is a mythological object)?
entries.text:
The grail is like a condensed conduit for the powers of creation. This energy comes with love and wisdom, it heals individuals and whole lands, brings life, restores sanity, delivers food, is endlessly full of wine and can the bearer with god. And in that it represents divine power, it’s not subject to natural law. This means it can float, disappear, and endlessly refill.

As a cornucopia, the grail represents the endless refilling of both Earth and Mother with offspring and new life. The way wine endlessly refills the grail or cup of shared by Baucis & Philemon can be seen in the monthly refilling of the maternal vessel with the life-giving blood of menstruation.

As a portal to the divine, when Gallahad finds the grail, he transcends immediately—leaving th eworld behind.

MENTAL HEALTH – Geoffrey of Monmouth, who wrote the first great work about Arthur, didn’t write about the grail. In the Vita Merlini, however, he wrote about apples that made knights go mad and an elixir that restored their clarity. This is reminiscent of berzerker warriors whose battle-related madness must be quenched by waters. Perhaps the greatest power of the Grail Myths was the way they helped to heal Crusade induced PTSD. These are stories that follow the arc of a closed heart that opens and a wasteland that’s redeemed – of warriors who stop fighting and lovers who start loving.

Why is it not so absurd to look for references to the Holy Grail in Eschenbach's Parzival?Wolfram would have had every opportunity to pick up stories and encounter interesting figures. There’s no reason to believe that some of the stories that filtered to him weren’t based in truth. And for those who believe the Templars retrieved the grail as opposed to Joseph of Arimathea or Saint Peter; Wolfram’s story, in which the grail is protected by Templars, could offer clues. At the same time, many believe that Wolfram is more likely to have encoded a recipe for the philosopher’s stone than the grail, which he described as a stone. This would mean that the grail isn’t found, it’s made, and Wolfram’s story could be the recipe.

as is so often the case with conspiracy theories, there is often a glimmer of truth in it. –

Tolkien’s notion that the imagination of a storyteller is like a Cauldron of Stories is meant as a response to academics who want to flatten stories into limited if not singular inspirations. As he sees it, stories are ladeled from an indivisible soup of myth, history, rumor and life—dreams, thoughts, you name it. So truth? Tale? There’s always some kinda both.

entries.question: Is it still possible to find the grail today - is it an object over 2000 years old?
entries.text:
We have older cups that were less significant to less people, so if Jesus was a historical figure, which is the consensus among academics, then it is entirely plausible. The story that the catholic church could have taken responsibility is plausible, the story that it was retrieved from Jerusalem by the Templars is plausible, and I don’t think it’s impossible that a wealthy man who buried Jesus could have fled to England with the prized possession. So though I’m more compelled by symbolic interests, I wouldn’t dismiss the literal possibility. Core to the Christian tradition is the notion that something perfectly symbolic—like Christ—could also be very real.

GRAIL AS MYSTICAL UNION – I thought I had it yesterday, the sun was rising and my mind was empty, but alas, just out of reach. Some day though, someday, I’ll feel one again—one with myself again, one with my world, maybe even one with the divine. And then, no matter where I’ve journeyed, I’ll have the grail—I’ll be the grail.

LOVE: I’ve got to say, the deeper and wider you go, the more you come to recognize that the core common denominator is love—love heals mind, body and soul as well as crops and even belligerence. Love is the elixir we drink—it’s the gate we walk through to find union with self, with cosmos, and even with the divine. Love is what makes the womb the womb. If there’s an incarnation of Jesus in the form of a child, the point is that it’s an incarnation of the wisdom of love on earth. In many ways, the grail stories are in opposition to the testosterone-colored violence and persecution of their day. In some ways you might say that these stories represent the real Christianity of the time – not the kill to save model. These stories deconstruct the violence and prioritize the inner journey. Parzival, for example, climaxes when Fierfitz and Parzival stop fighting! So when you go to Roslyn, and when you stand under the stone they say you have to stand under to be able to see the grail, you’ve got to realize the grail is you, and your capacity to heal, create, unify and find wisdom—through love, the true heart of Christianity.

entries.question: Where in art history do we find the Holy Grail and can it give us clues to its location?
entries.text:
In the medieval period is was the standard practice of Alchemists to encode their recipes in mythic imagery to avoid watchful eyes. Many of the artists who worked with alchemists to represent this imagery also worked on the imagery of the Tarot. That artists of the time were capable of encoding hidden meaning in their art is beyond question. And we know the primary secrets they were encoding concerned the process of creating the philosopher’s stone and elixir of life, which share qualities and are conflated with the Holy Grail – especially in the context of Wolfram’s Grail Stone and his alchemical penname. So definitely artists and storytellers were encoding the recipe for the philosopher’s stone in quest-like myths; as can be seen in the story of Nicholas Flammel; and I’m sure that if these artists thought they knew where the grail was, they could write encoded stories and paint encoded pictures that pointed, in a hidden language, to the grail. That they encoded a path to the philosopher’s stone, I’m definitely sure that kind of thing was going on, and that it was really about a recipe process. That they encoded a literal path to a literal grail? I couldn’t make a definitive claim about that.

Especially when you know that in old Spanish the word "grial" meant a mortar-shaped drinking vessel. So it makes sense that the path to the Holy Grail leads to Spain. ”

One of the interesting things about the Mortar and Pestle in the context of the Holy Grail is that it unifies the image of wine and bread insofar as flour is ground in the pestle, which becomes a vessel for the wine. Christians already associate the flagellation of Christ with the threshing of grain, and so for those who see the grail as a mortar, they can see the grinding of the grain as symbolic of a direction towards death followed by wine, which is symbolic of life.

Can the Essenes (where Jesus is supposed to have celebrated the last supper) really existed?Just beyond the reach of what we can really be sure about are these reasons to believe John, the Baptist of Jesus, and Joseph of Arimathea, in whose tomb Jesus was buried—were Essenes. This has led to the belief that Jesus had a particularly close relationship with the Essenes, who many believe hosted the Last Supper. The reason this is disputed by academics is because the Essenes did not pursue wealth and were not known as urban; which makes the idea of an Urban Last Supper with the Essenes seem unlikely. The response of believers comes in the form of Josephus’ 1st Century description of an Essene area and gateway in Jerusalem, which may have been found in recent years.

What could the Grail mean in Parzival?The Grail in Wolfram is a stone brought down from the heavens by Neutral angels—like a meteorite, from which the first iron objects were made—including swords. If the Grail Stone relates to a meteorite, then meteorites are the common denominator between the Grail and Exaclibur, an iron sword that bestows a heavenly right to rule. This can also be seen in the vajra or lightning stone of Indra, which parallels Zues’ symbol of authority.

Wolfram is a word for Tungsten, which is harder than steel, more resistant to fracture than diamond, and has the highest melting point for a pure metal. Such mythopoeic mortality is certainly resonant with the philosopher’s stone if not the Holy Grail. It’s also true that Tungsten was often the crucial impurity in Damascus Steel – which made it lighter, harder, stronger and sharper.

Mythopoeically, if you think about a hero that’s stronger and sharper in a way that relates to their corruption, you get to anti-heroes, the earliest of which, I believe, were personifications of steel. For ages, metallurgy and religion was focused on purification. The discovery of steel, however, was the discovery of the strongest most immortal of metals that came with a bit of corruption. This is what we see in the earliest Personifications or Men of Steel like Sosruquo and Achilles. Not only are they stronger and more invincible than anyone else, they also corrupt the laws of god.

How realistic is it that a mug survives 2,000 years and then ends up in Spain?We certainly have older and less important cups, so there’s no reason to consider it out of the question. And though authenticity is almost impossible to confirm, to what extent are Christians hoping to drink from the real grail, and to what extent would a surrogate cup support the ritual participation of practitioners?

As the story goes, Saint Peter took the cup from Jerusalem to Rome, where he founded the Catholic Church and used it to perform Mass. Nearly 300 years later, it was carried from Rome to Spain when Emperor Valerian demanded all Christian relics when he persecuted the religion. This is when it was given to Saint Lawrence, who gave it to Proselius, who is believed to have delivered it to Spain. It then pinged around several churches and hermit caves before, in 1135, it was exchanged, with documentation. A paper record then follows the grail until the Spanish civil war, when it was hidden from Communists.

Verifications of the Spanish grail include its stone composition, which is believed to have concerned Kosher laws, and its consistency with the Catholic narrative of Peter retaining the grail. It also fits the description of Saint Jerome. That having been said, the Catholic Church has long been suspicious of its Authenticity, though that did not stop both of the last two popes from using it for a Mass.

entries.question: Can a ritual measure really provide information about the authenticity of the grail?
entries.text:
Ritual: That early Arthurian references aren’t to Christ’s cup has almost become irrelevant in that the tradition that carries in our world and imaginations is one of the Christian ritual.

Christian Mass: The most important ritual in Christianity is the Mass, which centers around the cup of wine, which provides a path to spiritual immortality—like the Holy Grail; so whether or not there’s a literal link, to our imagination, these holy vessels are resonant, mimetic and easily conflatable.

Pagan Grail – One of the popular theories of the grail is that the tradition emerges from the relationship of Christianity with more ancient mystery religions throughout the mediterranean. These traditions typically revolve around some kind of death/resurrection and immortality deity, like Dionysus, Mithras, Attis, Adonis, Persephone, Osiris, Inanna—and sometimes many are seen as one. In the oldest real megamyth we have, Inanna is brought back from death on a cross from bread and elixir of life—contained within the lunar thumbnail. Dionysos is the god of wine, with which we toast the living. Blood, elixirs and vessels are central to many of these cults, and we even have some wild ritual vessels from Eleusis, where wine came from much more than grapes. So as Christianity displaced the Pagan religion, it is believed that many of these mystery traditions and their ritualistic cults came to assimilate the myth in their own ways. Some of these sound pretty wild to us – Orgies in the name of Christ, the drinking of menstrual blood and semen as the elixir and bread of life, and even the consumption of aborted embryos. Could these cults have contributed to grail legends? Could grails pertain to ritual vessels that predate the conversion of Pagan cults? Most of these were traditions were wiped out by crusades and inquisitions, and myths tend to get written down when things are ending – like Genesis, which is believed to have been written around the time of Israel’s fall to Babylon. Could some of these cults have avoided complete annihilation? This is one of the places where the bottom drops out into mystery.

entries.question: Why does the relic cult play such a big role in Christianity?
entries.text:
The very essence of the Christian religion depends on its literal truth – that Jesus was real and the son of God. Yet, it was the Muslims who had Mohammad’s sword and other real relics. This is why some believe that the European interest in relics was in response to their collision with Islam. At the same time, the Christian emphasis on literal truth has sent them down multiple hyper-literal paths. Lutheran literalism in response to Enlightenment science was a later incarnation. Earlier was the fixation on relics.

A relic, first of all, is a connection to a source—to the Buddha, to Mohammad, to Christ—and that connection is valuable because of their connection with the divine. The relic is then seen as a sort of connection with the divine. And this is how we feel about the objects of lost loved ones – they connect us with them. The grail is, in this way, the ultimate relic – not only is it an object that connects with someone connected with the divine, this is seen as the actual object that makes the connection. The grail is the source of wine-blood that delivers salvation and immortality. It is the ultimate relic that offers an ultimate connection with the divine.

What other goblets are there that are thought to be the Holy Grail?Not only are there multiple “Holy Grails,” (The Nanteos Cup, Antioch Chalice, Sacro Catino, the cup of Lake Chiemsee and others) There are also countless divine vessels from other religions. Some of these are even likely to have influenced the Grail – from the cup of Hebe to the Cauldron of Dagda.

entries.question: What is the holy grail for you? Do you really think it exists?
entries.text: The grail, to me, is about love and union, which can be seen when we drink something dark from any cup. To begin, we kiss our own reflection, which we then imbibe—incredible visuals for healing love and union. The same can be said of the elixir, which carries waves, that, unlike particles, can reconcile the paradox of one and many. Single coned speakers, for example, produce a single wave in which we hear countless individual instruments . In the pursuit of oneness, elixir is the ultimate mythopoeic image. But then what of the empty cup? A perfect dish unifies the light of a space into a holograph or disembodied image, which, in this case, is the head of the drinker and the surrounding environment.

entries.question: The Grail - a vessel made of wood or stone? Why is it more likely that the grail was made of stone after all?
entries.text:
If it was a cup used for a Jewish ritual ceremony it would have had to have been kosher, which means it would not have been porous, as in clay, and it wouldn’t have been made of metal, which could have been forged from pagan coins. In theory, it would have been stone. This is consistent with Wolfram’s description of the grail as a stone. It’s also consistent with the description of the grail as a mortar, which also would have been stone. The same can be said of the meteor.

Why is the Holy Grail a constant theme in films and novels (Dan Brown, Indiana Jones)?On one level the grail quest is just an incredible narrative structure – an ultimate mcguffin, you might say. It also represents that thing that saves the day  -- that thing that renews the world. This can be the life and light that returns after winter or the antidote delivered at the end of ____ Name your movie. What story matters more than the story of retrieving and delivering the essence of life?

The common denominator between Robert Langdon and Indiana Jones is Joseph Campbell, the famed mythologist who led real grail tours and had a major influence on Dan Brown, George Lucas and Stephen Spielberg. You even see Grail motifs identified by Campbell in the most recent Star Wars films—a projectile through the eye of the red armored knight and entering into the forest where there’s no path. The grail quest can also be seen in the journey of Bilbo, who steals a silver cup from the dragon before discovering a stone that carries a right to rule.

If Dan Brown's theory is correct and the Holy Grail stands for Maria Magdalena, who was married to Jesus, what would this knowledge mean for the Catholic Church?It’s not just that the Catholic Church wouldn’t want to be in conflict with the authority of Jesus’ own family, which they already face with the Eastern Church and its Patriarch, James, brother of Jesus. More importantly, the Catholic church should be afraid of a path towards the divine that they don’t control. The path to the heart through the journey of romantic love is in competition with the path to god they promote. (Though it seems that could be changing.)

entries.question: Why are myths like the Holy Grail so fascinating?
entries.text:
In Inception, Nolan points out that if you put a safe in a dream, the dreamer will put what’s precious in that safe. The grail works in the same way – whatever is most precious to us, that’s what we see in the grail. It could be anything from union with god or a happy home to riches and power. We’re obsessed with the grail, because we see our obsessions in that vessel; AND, we find real wisdom on the quest.

episodes.title: The Search for El Dorado

entries.text: The Search for El Dorado – Storyline

As one of the 10 myths of Season III THE GREATEST MYTHS OF HUMANITY, THE SEARCH FOR EL DORADO is one of the least explored and perhaps the most adventurous of all myth. El Dorado leads to one of the most dangerous and bloodiest times of mankind, the European colonization of the Americas. It is the story of an illusion of the conquistadors, describing a city of pure gold somewhere in the deep jungles of South America. In this documentary, we will uncover the latest finds and follow clues that reveal the myth's origins. Our two protagonists embark on a great journey of discovery to find out what leads to El Dorado and, if the city really exists, where it might be hidden today.

The El Dorado myth attracted European explorers for two centuries. Among the earliest stories was that told on his deathbed by Juan Martinez, a munitions captain for the Spanish adventurer Diego de Ordaz. With his last words he reveals the secret: the story of a lost place deep in South America, Manoa. He tells of a massive city with a grand palace on the edge of a lake. A kingdom wrapped in gold. The shore of the lake itself is said to be covered with gold dust. The natives were kind to him, he reported, and the chief treated him like a royal guest with food and lodging in his grand palace where everything was made of gold. The city was said to be so far from civilization that it was safe from greedy people seeking nothing but wealth. Juan Martínez calls the city Manoa.

The path to the gold of Manoa leads through unexplored and almost inaccessible areas of this world. The myth not only creates a fantastic gold dream in the mind, but also the driving force behind the “discovery” of the New World, America. But the greet moves the myth into one of the darkest chapters of humanity, the colonization of the Americans. Manoa gets called by the famous name El Dorado and so El Dorado becomes a murder weapon. To unravel the origins of the legend of El Dorado, the documentary follows the steps of the Spanish explorers who recorded in historical documents their obsession to find these gold deposits. The research shows generations of conquistadors who cruelly plundered, burned and tortured the highlanders to find the hidden gold.

Our journey starts at the cradle of the magnificent Incan Empire, what is now the Peruvian city of Cusco. Together with the French explorer Thierry Jamin we enter in the most important Inca foundation before the colonization. Under the church of Santo Domingo, we find the ruins of Coricancha, the Temple of the Sun of the Inca civilization. A Temple dedicated to the most important god, Inti. Entire rooms, even courtyards, that were covered here with gold by the Incas. The greed for wealth led the conquistadores to bloody plundering of such places. Tons of Gold was melted down by the Conquistadors within a month of the sacking of Cusco, most of which was sent back to Spain, some forever lost at the bottom of the Atlantic due to Spain’s Naval battles with their rivals. But it could be that the most important and spectacular of these treasures were in fact hidden by the Incas, carried away through Cusco’s underground labyrinth of secret tunnels to the city of Paititi. Paititi is the native name of the "Lost City of the Incas", the mysterious refuge of the Incas in eastern Peru. An inaccessible place somewhere along the rainforest with the rich possessions of the Inca ruling caste. All the clues of the Paititi legend reveal clear parallels to the European myth of El Dorado. Together with other experts, Thierry Jamin wants to bring light into the darkness and follows the traces of the ritual signs of the natives.

Thierry Jamin visits one of the few preserved Inca fortresses in Peru, the ruins of Sacsayhuamán. These are now one of the most important sights from the Inca era and are located on the outskirts of Cusco. In fact, researchers have discovered a gigantic tunnel system under the city. Various chroniclers leave data about secret labyrinths, the so-called “Chinkanas” of the Incas. There is a theory that there is one of them that would be connected to the Coricancha, the ancient Golden Temple of Cusco. Thierry Jamin explores one of the tunnels that are still accessible. Here he finds evidence that people must have performed ceremonies, but El Dorado must be much further away.

Using several satellite images of the Peruvian jungle, Thierry notices a strange square formation - an eight-hundred-meter-high mountain - the explorer and his team have a lead. Some recent satellite images show that part of the mountain has been deforested. There is also an unusual structure on the deforestation. Is it El Dorado? Thierry Jamin and his team set out from Cusco on an expedition into the depths of the jungle. After more than twenty expeditions, this one will be the most important expedition of his life. Thierry travels with his team over five days by jeep, on foot, on the boat and on helicopter to reach the square mountain. His search is reminiscent of one of the many expeditions of the conquistadors. Thierry recognizes structures of an unknown site from the helicopter, but they cannot land on the heavily overgrown mountain. Thierry must wait patiently until this possible city is archaeologically researched and confirmed as what Thierry is looking since 1997.

But what if El Dorado is much more than a city? What if Thierry Jamin and all the Europeans before him only followed the quantity of gold instead of the cultural value of the concept of El Dorado? All the traces so far show that the indigenous people of South America had a very special and, above all, different relationship to gold than the people of the wealth-oriented and capitalistically influenced Old World.

The most valuable gold finds are in the Gold Museum of the Colombian capital Bogotá. The Colombian archaeologist Juan Pablo Quintero studies the historical gold pieces and their original meaning. His theory of El Dorado leads to a whole new area on the map: from Perú to Colombia. Of all the gold finds in Bogotá's Gold Museum, one in particular stands out to Juan Pablo Quintero, the gold raft of El Dorado. A gold artefact depicting a ceremony and considered proof of the authenticity of the first European listened legend of El Dorado, a gold man. Juan Pablo believes that the mysterious El Dorado legend was inspired here by the ancient practices of the Muisca, a tribe that lived in the highlands of Colombia and one of the four great tribes that lived deep in the Andes.

It is clear to historians why the Spaniards were impressed when they arrived in this area: Their gift for handling gold. Juan Pablo finds out that all metal analyses of the Muisca gold finds have one thing in common: they are not made of pure gold, but an alloy of gold and copper. Some with copper contents of up to 70 percent. For European goldsmiths, this would mean true gold pollution. But the historical traces teach us to distance ourselves from the way Europeans handled gold. The gold raft becomes the focus of a new treasure hunt for the myth of El Dorado.

Juan Pablo analyzes a map of Sedimentary rock from the entire Muisca region and he comes to a surprising conclusion: The sedimentary rock that makes up the soil has never contained gold. Did the Muisca know about a huge secret gold vein? How else could they get their hands on so much gold? Juan Pablo Quintero recognizes an above-average variety of another natural resource – salt.

The documentary accompanies Juan Pablo to the Muisca territory to meet a current Muisca tribe member Clara Lucía Chauta. Together they get deep, not only into history, also into the most famous salt spring of Colombia, the salt mine of Nemocon. The Muisca are true salt collectors. In salt water springs they create a huge production, dumping liters of water into pots. In the end, they are left with blocks of salt as a valuable and easily transportable commodity. They use these to trade. They load up the salt and make the arduous journey over hundreds of meters to the valleys below. On the banks of the river, the exchange takes place with the neighbouring people. The Muisca trade to turn salt into gold.

The Muisca tribe wants to lead Juan Pablo to where the Muisca ancestors performed their most important ritual. The path leads them to a large lagoon, the Sacred Lagoon of cacique of Guatavita. Here the Muisca keep a special tradition that must be followed when a new king comes to power. According to the legend, the Muisca covered the new king with gold dust, crowns, bracelets and precious stones in a kind of coronation ceremony. This treasure was then taken on a raft to the middle of Lake Guatavita. At this point, the gold was thrown into the murky depths of the lake as an offering to the gods. The belief that the lagoon was full of gold because of the offerings led many colonisers, starting with the Spanish, to try to empty the water from the lagoon. Despite numerous attempts to fish the gold and jewels from the bottom of the water, few clues to the treasure were found.

Here is where El Dorado becomes a myth. The Laguna de Guatavita is under the strict protection of the Colombian government - any excavation is strictly forbidden. If the Muisca gold is indeed hidden at the bottom of this lake, it will remain inaccessible for the time being. But when such a wondrous story is passed on from mouth to mouth, fantasies and illusions lead to much more. The theory that El Dorado in the imagination of the Spanish explorers was a wonderful city in the jungle full of riches and gold is consistent with the tales of the Inca city of Paititi. But it was much more a city built to protect the Inca culture from the conquerors than an empire made of pure gold. Nevertheless, the Europeans managed to eradicate the indigenous people and their culture through their violence.
El Dorado is therefore mostly just a powerful idea that, once you fall for it, you can't get rid of. El Dorado does not exist outside us, but inside us.
WILL LINN - Mythologist

entries.question: Why is El Dorado one of the most famous myths of mankind, what makes it a myth? Free answer.
entries.text:
And encoded in this mythic predecessor of the capitalist ideal, we get an early glimpse of its shadow. In the story of El Dorado, we see the disregard of others and sacredness for the purpose of wealth.

The pursuit of personal fortune, especially in the West, is a living myth. It’s a capitalist myth. Before El Dorado, great quests were for Truth and holy objects. The story of el Dorado, however reduced treasure to wealth.

entries.question: "Where would you hide the greatest treasure of all time?"
entries.text: Where can you find El Dorado? All across Europe, golden arrows lead to its western-most limit—Santiago. Follow these arrows. And when you reach what you thought was the end of your pilgrimage, follow the sun across the sea, to America, where the streets are paved in gold. Then follow these yellow brick roads until you reach the end of the rainbow. And there, where sun sets on the shoulders of Atlas, you’ll find the promised land, El Dorado.

entries.question: Is the myth true, or perhaps more importantly, what’s true about the myth? With the help of emerging technologies and new approaches to myth, we find more and more answers.
entries.text: A myth is never just a myth — there is always a presence of historical and philosophical truth that’s becoming increasingly accessible with the help of technology and new approaches to myth.

entries.question: The question isn’t just if the myth is true, it’s what’s true about the myth? While new technologies can help us uncover secrets about the potential history of a real El Dorado, new approaches to mythology can help us understand what it’s telling us about ourselves.
entries.text:
As with any myth, it’s likely to be grounded in a significant amount of truth.

As our technology advances, we have more and more tools for finding El Dorado.

The oversimplification and literalization of myth is very dangerous. When you can’t recognize metaphor, you’re in trouble. Journeys to treasure are abundant, but can’t a journey for treasure be a metaphor? Can’t a golden city be a metaphor? With myth, it’s always about the metaphor, and in the case of treasure, what it’s really meant to represent is vitality, which is often unlocked with a new understanding of truth. 1

entries.question: What makes the Search for El Dorado so special?
entries.text:
For the Conquistadors and Europeans, no world was more other than the Americas, and it’s one most chamber and source of value we imagined as El Dorado.

The search for El Dorado and its treasure was a Hero Journey par excellence. Liked those who sought the grail, you don’t look for El Dorado because you think it’s a myth.

"It is the enigma of one of mankind's most dangerous and least explored myths: the unimaginably rich city of gold-paved streets with golden temples. The location of this promised land is mysterious and its coordinates vary, as do the men who set out on expeditions with the dream of getting rich, the outcome of which for many is more like a nightmare than an illusion."

entries.question: Describe the possible gold land of El Dorado from the conquers perspective. What was this place? Free answer.
entries.text: In the imagination of the Conquistador, El Dorado was the mysterious source of Gold at the heart of the Amazon, a shining city on shores of gold dust

entries.question: What does gold do to us humans?
entries.text:
As Tolkien pointed out Gold gives us what he called dragon sickness, which is a kind of greed and belligerence that comes to disregard the wellbeing of others. Conquistadors had this sickness.

Who isn’t questing for wealth ina capitalist works?      The quest for the Holy Grail was understood as a quest for knowledge and experience of the divine, but El Dorado, which comes later, is most definitively a quest for wealth—for gold. If we go beyond the conqueistadors to ask what the story encouraged in Spaniards and Europeans? The answer is still a quest for gold. A quest for wealth… This is core to the emerging capitalism of the continent.

The confusion of El Dorado for a person, city, and civilization is itself telling of the core myth at hand. In great stories you often see an individual that personifies the health and well-being of a land or of a city

entries.question: What does this myth teach us as human beings? Free answer.
entries.text:
How preCrossing the Western Ocean for a land of gold was a journey of Hercules and Arthur long before the conquistadors set out. This recurring narrative has to do with the projection of human journeys on the journey of the sun — from the journey of life, death and crops to this quest for wealth.

If there is something holy to us, there’s a motivation to pilgrimage to the source of that holiness, whether it’s in Mecca, Jerusalem or Santiago. If what’s holy to money, your pilgrimage is to a wellspring of wealth. And this isn’t just to degrade the quest to something secular, it’s to say that from within their mindset, the pursuit of gold was existentially meaningful.

entries.question: How does every treasure hunt begin?
entries.text: Like so many treasure hunts, the quest for El Dorado begins with a treasure map.

entries.question: How did Manoa become El Dorado?
entries.text:
Manoa lives on as El Dorado, “the gilded one.”

It’s not uncommon for a leader to speak for a whole city or organization, and it’s not uncommon for myths and legends to start mixing them together. For the people of El Dorado, Manoa, the gilded one represented them. For the Conquistadors, the golden king became more like a personification of gold and the sun they followed to where it sets.

entries.question: What does the discovery of America awaken in Europe? Inflation.
entries.text:
The road to el dorado is reminiscent of the myth that American roads are paved in gold, which, like the Gold Rush, motivated mass populations to move WEST for their fortunes.

And as they poured the gold they found back into the economy, ironically, its value plummeted as inflation soared.

What did the myth DO? On one level, like the later gold rush and myth that american roads are paved in gold, the story of el dorado served to motivate Europeans to seek fortunes in the west. On another level, this is a myth about the pursuit of wealth that aligns with capitalist ideals that would continue to grow until it was first realized by those same Europeans, who came west for their fortunes.

entries.question: What is the real origin of El Dorado? And what did the conquers misunderstand? Ceremony of the Muisca.
entries.text:
El Dorado was a man who covered himself from head to toe in gold—an unforgettable sight that spread through the South American imagination like a viral tweet, but by the time it got to the Spanish, el dorado was a city of gold. .

This is often in the mythic structure of a ruler. And so we talk about Washington, or Paris, like a character in the news. Washington did this Berlin did that. El Dorado did this, El Dorado did that. This is the personification of a culture in the form of its ruler. And rulers often and as was the case in the city associated with El Dorado, rulers often personify the sun as well. In the sun itself is only a incarnation of something greater, of light. Of the source of creation in existence. So the king is the master of all of the gold and all of that power and light and vitality from which existence comes. And the health of the king and then be associated with the health of the land, as a scene in the story of Oedipus Rex in Athens. The sun going down into the water is symbolized by the man or the golden objects going down into the water. These are common rituals for kings, the reason what was Arthur his sword must go back into the water upon his death, a motif ancient for Indo Europeans. As found in the Caucasus mountains with the figure of Patras. This is a symbol of the kings death or the kings entry into the other world. Osiris on the solar boat, every night, went into the underworld, the Dewert. This was the journey of the sun, but also the journey of the role he played as king. All over the world, leaders can be priest or spiritual leaders. Whether it’s the Dalai Lama or the caliphate. These spiritual divine leaders like a Cyrus sore Horace in Egypt are associated with knowledge of the other world, like shamans. They adventure from the known world to the other world of death, knights, chaos, and the source of creation. They journey into the land of dreams and healing, for the we not all heal from our dreams. And so the king, El Dorado, with spiritual leader ship as well as political, convenes across the boundaries of above and below like the golden sun, entering the sea, descending beneath the waves.

entries.question: How strong is the myth of El Dorado?
entries.text:
With people looking for El Dorado, it wasn’t long before El Dorado’s started spring up all over the map!

Journey to Source

El dorado as the great city not just of gold but a sort of ultimate source within the Americas, something holy, maybe terrifying to a Christian,

As far as we know the oldest city with great Piramidal ruins in the Americas is in Peru which is also where we find Cusco the city associated with El Dorado. The search for El Dorado is a search for the source of all the gold they see in South America, the search for chorus is a search for the truth or original source of culture from which everything they see comes

The fountain is a movie that demonstrates the spiritual she’d metaphorical nature of the road to el dorado. In the film, we see high Jackmans characters find el dorado as he finds a cure for death and spiritual answers at the center of reality, symbolized by a World tree or world navel from which he drinks the elixir of life. While the search for el dorado may have been for gold, it was motivated on a deeper level by something Existential and even spiritual, a sort of search for the meaning of life.

The search for El Dorado is a search for some ultimate origin of all the goals. This is a search for the origin of all the vitality, all the light, with which the goal is associated. This is a search for the golden city of Apollo. Which the sunset was associated. This is a search for origins. And it’s only through a mind thinking in economic terms that we fixate on the economic value of the goals in this equation. And I think the conquistadors were themselves fixated on the economic value of gold. This is a myth of individuals pursuing great wealth coming into the European consciousness in a major way.

Like the grail quest in its journey to center

Journey to Destination: Golden Road & Treasure

Heroic conquistadors journeyed across the western ocean to western lands for golden treasure, like Hercules, who crossed the western ocean for golden apples and Coyote, who swam from from north of Los Angeles to the Channel Islands for a golden flower. This is a recurring motif — the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, only the rainbow would be better understood as the yellow brick road or the yellow arrows that point the way from anywhere in Europe to its western most point in Santiago. If we want to really get down to it, in the depths of the imagination, the golden road is the road of the sun, which sets in the west, where, culture after culture, imagines treasure.

Before the road to el dorado was the Camino de Santiago, which is directed by golden arrows. These arrows point to the western most tip of Europe, Santiago, where the sun sets on the continent. The golden road is the road off the sun. And it continues in the Americas. And like the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, the imagination imagines a golden city at the end of the golden road.

Or the emerald city for Dorothy on her yellow brick Road? Is it an extension of the Camino DeSantiago with its yellow arrows pointing the way of the sun? Is it the journey Hercules takes across the western ocean to the western islands to find the golden apples? Are the journey of lizard and coyote from Southern California across the western ocean to get to the western islands retrieve the golden flower? When we look into the myths that have already outlined this quest to El Dorado we see the journey of the sun, we see journeys into death, we see searches for the origin of creation, and we see searches for self. The road to El Dorado is all of these. It is the journey to the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.

An ego myth with a shadow of deveststion

Unfortunately, the hero’s journey or what jung would call individuation is a journey highlighted by disillusionment and ego death. In the case of the conqueistadors, those who went in search for el dorado all failed, and they all suffered that loss. Along the way, great damage was done.

For every conquistador it would’ve been different. And, like Jungian individuation or the hero’s journey, It’s a journey of ego death and Disillusionment. No conquistador found what they were looking for. These are journeys of defeated pride.

Think about the inflation of Christian’s when encountering less powerful people who  worshipped them upon arrival—the entitlement.

Hero’s Journey and El Dorado

Great adventure myth — from home on a holy quest ti bring civilization and to come back with glory and riches.

Overview: The road Del Dorado is a classic hero journey in that you leave from home as a representative of your cultures status quo as enforcer of it even. And then you depart for some great adventure crossing some great ocean to get to some foreign land where everything is completely different and nothing is like what you expected. And at first you would be completely overwhelmed, but then you would learn how things work there a little bit how to move in that jungle. But then you would Fail to find what you thought you would find which shatters the ego and one’s expectations and one’s sense of control over their reality. And then this moment the hero complex should die. Disillusionment should set in. And having not gotten what you thought you wanted you should find what you really need. Or if you are the bad guy in the story, you keep wanting it anyway, you can’t let go, you keep driving for it, at the expense of lives, love, care, and any consideration for others. And in the story of El Dorado you can be sure that there were heroes and villains and everything in between. Certainly victims, many many victims. Whatever roll the conquistador played, the completion of the journey will be there return home, to deliver whatever they found it cold or wisdom, as the new person they become. And you can be sure that no conquistador return from the Americas the same person who left.

Like any heroic figure on a journey, they set out from a familiar world to find themselves in a landscape beyond their wildest dreams.

The world from which the Conquistadors set out was one of tyrannical oppression that was becoming more and more about monetary wealth as European capitalism began to bud.

In the imagination of a conquistador, finding the treasure of El Dorado was like an Arthurian knight finding the grail. It was an ultimate quest.

episodes.title: Secrets of the Lost Ark
