entries.text: Secrets of the lost Ark - Storyline

As one of the 10 Myths of Season II THE GREATEST MYTHS OF MANKIND is the ARK OF THE COVENANT perhaps the oldest. It is the story of a biblical Repique, which contained the word of God and was said to be THE all-powerful artefact of Jewish and Christian belief. In this documentary, we will uncover the latest findings and follow new leads of where it might be hidden today.

With Archeologist Danny Herman, our search for the secrets concealed by age, faith and political cult begins. He takes us to places where the ark of the covenant was located and where it was last seen: Jerusalem.

According to the bible, Moses received the ten commandments from God at Mount Sinai. Further, he was told to build the Ark of the covenant. The book of Exodus gives a detailed description of its looks: A golden chest that keeps the ten commandments and functions as God’s throne on Earth. He appears in between the two angels in the form of a gray cloud. The most vivid reference to it gives Hollywood in Steven Spielberg’s “Indiana Jones”.

On an ancient cemetery near Jerusalem might lie the bones of one of the last people who saw the Ark in person: One of the most worthy, a High Priest. No other was allowed to see the Ark. It is said to have unimaginable power, it could change the course of a war and defeat the enemy only with its mere presence.

But divine power not only affects the enemy. The bible tells stories about the taboo to touch it. What is the real story of the Ark? One look at the oldest bible text might open up a whole new perspective. The oldest transcript of the bible was found in 1942 in Qumran, the Dead Sea Scrolls. It contains historical evidence of the alterations of bible texts in antiquity. Prof. Pnina Shor shows similarities and differences to the well- known Hebrew bible texts.

Archeologists find references to proof this biblical narration in Shiloh and Beth Shemesh. But at another location, Kirjat Yearim, Israel Finkelstein finds evidence that indicate a historical truth, that differs from the Ark narration in the bible. Near Jerusalem, Josef Garfinkel finds mysterious objects from the time of the Ark. They could be the answer to the question of what the Ark truly was. A portable altar. One of them even looks like a small replica of the temple of Salomon. The true and last resting place of the Ark of the covenant.

This golden temple was destroyed in 586BC, when Jerusalem was taken by Babylon’s King Nebuchadnezzar II. The bible describes precisely the siege and fight. It states what happened to Salomon’s temple, but not in one word what happened to the Ark of the covenant. A Babylonian clay chronic lists all the looted treasures of the Babylonian campaign through the Judaic lands. But the Ark is not listed. Also, at the brutal siege of the Roman empire in 70AD, nothing of the second temple was left. Another list shows off the treasures General Titus took from Jerusalem. Again, no sign of the Ark of the covenant.

Archeologists dig since the end of 19th century, but believe to have uncovered merely 20 percent of the old city of Jerusalem. In one tunnel, an ancient aqueduct system, they found evidence, that the Ark might have been moved outside before the Babylonians entered the city.

Danny Herman beliefs, that one book in the bible gives indications to where the Ark of the covenant was hidden. The second book of Maccabees states that Jeremiah, the bible prophet of a time before the Babylonian attack, took the Ark of the covenant and hid it at Mount Nebo. The Mountain to be believed to contain the bones of Moses himself.

Two treasure hunters in the 1980s believed to have found the Ark in a cave there. This unauthorized dig had enraged the Jordan government so much, that to this day, no further archeological excavations are to be allowed. Just as at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem itself. No digging under a sacred space. As for the whereabouts of the Ark of the covenant, not all tunnels and caves have yet been fully discovered. Yet every other week, archeologists find new evidence pointing to the ancient times in the holy promised land. Whether there was an Ark of the covenant or not and where it might be to this day.

entries.question: How does the bible describe the Arks almighty power with Uzzah?
entries.text:
Uzzah was immediately struck dead when he touched the Ark, as though smited by lightning for his disobedience.

The Ark is like the forbidden fruit in Pandora’s box. Those who disobey god – those who look in the box or pursue its knowledge – are punished.

entries.question: How does the bible describe the Arks almighty power, at Beth Shemesh?
entries.text:
The scene at Beth Shemesh is reminiscent of another in which the priests of Hephaestus, Pandora’s maker, take a box to the front of a battlefield. Struck by terror, their enemies forfeit. As Pandora and her box are described as a forbidden plague, the forbidden Ark caused tumors, which leads us to wonder, are these memories of biological warfare?

Another ancient weapon of mass destruction was the head of Medusa, which killed an army of men who looked when they shouldn’t have.

Like Pandora, Eve and the Beauty in Blue Beard. Those who can’t resist their curiosity and look into the Ark are punished mortally.

entries.question: Why was the Ark able to be stolen, why did it kill so many of its own people? It was supposed to help the Israelites against their enemies, right?
entries.text:
The Ark killed all who did not submit to its power, from enemies to Jewish priests.

Islam means submission, submission to a god who punished Adam and Eve for their disobedience. Like the untouched fruit of Eden, the untouched ark represents the power of God and submission to the power.

entries.question: What is the relevance of the Ark for the people of Israel, on their 40 Year journey to the promised land? How do they see the Ark at the time?
entries.text:
The Ark was a guiding light for the Jews. As the star led to Jesus, the ark led to Israel. These guiding lights, as is often the case with guiding lights, presented hope—hope for change, hope for a new day. And whether it comes from Christ, Prometheus or Moses, hope is the light, brought from heaven to earth. And in the cases of both Christ and the Ark, they represent proof.

When Semites ruled Egypt they identified with Seth, who used his great staff or scepter to cut through Apep—the world encircling snake. This enabled the solar prow, the seat of god, to pass into the divine realm. This world encircling snake represented the world encircling sea, or river, which is to say, Seth the semite used his staff to part the sea so that the seat of god could enter a Holy place. This sound a lot like Moses when he parts the red sea and the ark passes through.

This ark, by the way, also looks and sounds a lot like Aker, the seat of Osiris in the innermost chamber of the underworld. Aker is the secret scene at the absolute bottom of the underworld known only to pharaohs and priests, like the brother of Moses. This is the scene where the first divine spark comes into its vessel. This seat, by the way, is flanked, in the pyramid texts, by two chimera, and in the myth, two birds. Together, they look like Cherubim.

Like the sun rising from night, the Ark rose from Egypt and the desert to  bring hope and promising a new day.

entries.question: What is basically the meaning of the Ark in the book of Exodus?
entries.text:
Like the seat of Apollo at Delphi, the ark is god’s throne on earth—this is the seat of god, like the sunboat of Osiris or the cupboat of Helios. And like these solar seats, the golden Ark is a guiding light that leads souls to life beyond their world.

As the Ark leads jews to the Holyland, the sunboat of Osiris leads souls to a life after death.

As the Ark was a guiding light for Jews who would cross the red sea to enter the Holyland, the sunboat of Osiris was a guiding light for Egyptian souls who would cross the world encircling sea to enter their afterlife.

entries.question: The Ark of the covenant was placed in a similarly mysterious temple. Salomon’s temple. How sure are we about the existence of this temple?
entries.text:
The only excavations beneath the temple were executed by the templars and shrouded in mystery. If there is an older temple made of Lebanese cedars beneath the Temple Mount, we wouldn’t know. All we have are the myths.

The temple of Solomon is said in the Bible to have been built by the Phoenicians and is claimed by the masons, who claim the pyramids as well.

entries.question: When does the Ark of the covenant becomes a Myth? Why? And what can be a clue to its whereabouts in the bible?
entries.text:
The Ark is at the exact precipice between myth and memory when scholars think priests started writing down stories – this was in response to the Babylonian invasion and exile, which compromised a living, oral tradition. One might actually wonder, could the writing of god’s word onto tablets on a journey from Egypt be a poetic expression of the torah’s writing on the way to Babylon? To this day, the Torah is kept in a miniature Ark.

The Ark is said to have been in the possession of the Jews right up until the time they started emphasizing the written tradition.

The Ark becomes myth, when, According to Maccabbees, it was taken to a cave in Jordan to be hidden from the invading Babylonians.

Like the Grail, the Ark enters and leaves history, like a metaphor for a god who spoke to us and stopped.

entries.question: How did the Ark narrative and the Ark of the covenant become a Myth? Is the bible itself maybe even a Myth?
entries.text:
History becomes infused with myth over time, from the story of Arthur to WWII.

When we look at the story of the bible, we find phrases and clues everywhere. But any story, adjusted by different authors in different centuries, will end up as a story with flaws. The books of the bible were written down from memories and folktales heard and retold over centuries. But this is how Myths are born.

entries.question: What is it mainly with the Ark of the covenant, that keeps the Myth alive?
entries.text:
We still want what the Ark can give—knowledge of god and a connection with the divine.

Vessels and thrones are symbolic of the feminine. Whether the patriarchy is run by Knights, Priests or politicians, the oppression of femininity sets up a quest for its retrieval. We still have some retrieving to do, and so the stories persist.

At the same time, quests for the ark or grail are also quests for the divine source, for the source of creation, which more than a woman’s womb. The Human condition established by Adam and Prometheus is one of estrangement and separation—from god, from humans, from everything. And if you see everything as atoms, if you can’t see anything but as separate, it’s even worse! Like Adam, we experience separation as lonliness. Our isolation is an source of existential dread. And this dread sets up a desire—a desire for union, a desire for oneness or wholeness or whatever you want to call it, and this motivation is behind our love for stories about union, which tend to be journeys to some divine source—from the grail quest to a search for the Ark, this is a search for divinity that’s motivated by a feeling of estrangement.

entries.question: How powerful was/ Is the Ark?
entries.text:
The Big Bang is only the most recent myth about some point from which creation came. And for the Jews, this point was in the dead center of their temple, before the Ark—the seat of the creator at the seat of creation. Lightning, meteors, plagues and the sun are but derivations of its true power, which is all power—a power not meant for human wants.

In the Jewish imagination, creation was from the center, for which reason the tree of eden, cross, and temple were described as in this center. Over the exact center was the foundation stone of our reality, on which was written the name of God. This stone was associated with the Ark, which was also associated with the creation point of reality.

The Ark represents the power of creation and destruction itself.

entries.question: How could simple lightnings evoked by friction be called mighty and magical?
entries.text:
Until the scientific discovery of electricity, until Ben Franklin brought lightning down to earth on the string of a kite, lightning was heavenly, and its presence on earth would have been seen as either miraculous or magical. If, like Franklin, the Ark brought lightning to earth, or if sock footed priests charged up the gold, which is a capacitor, with their electricity, then, when it discharged, when it gave a little zap—maybe even a big zap—it would have been experienced as lightning in a bottle, or heaven on earth. It’s thus no surprise that it was exactly the spark that was associated with God.

When Benjamin Franklin attatched a key to a kite and brought the power of lightning down to earth in the form of electricity, he may have enacted the same miracle as the Ark, which, is repeatedly associated with lightning and is said to have created sparks between the wings of its cherubim. As Prometheus stole fire from the gods, the stories of Moses and Benjamin Franklin brought the power of heaven down to earth.

Lightning belonged to Yahweh, Zeus, Indra – alongside the meteorite, it is the supreme power from above.

To bring the light of heaven to earth has been repeatedly associated with divine authority. Where the Ark represents divine power on earth, its descriptions look like those of lightning and meteor stones, both of which bring heavenly light down to earth. Where the ability to draw the first swords from such meteor stones was associated with the divine right of kings, lightning has been repeatedly associated with divine patriarchs like Zeus and Indra.

entries.question: Describe the temple of Salomon. What was its purpose?
entries.text: Like the Ark, the temple of Salomon was covered and gold and filled with treasure. Like the Ark, the temple of Salomon was located at the center of the world, where God, one hopes, can be found.

entries.question: What does the Menora mean relating to the temple of Jerusalem? What does this tell us about the whereabouts of the Ark?
entries.text: Israel has been repeatedly looted and excavated by its conquerors, from the Phillistines and Babylonians to the Romans and Templars. Any and all are believed to have taken possession of the Ark. So when we find a menorah on the Tutus arch in Rome, some see it as a clue.

entries.question: Which parts/ books of the bible are clearly fiction, which ones can be a version of a certain real memory?
entries.text:
While the Greeks seem to have made a relatively clear shift from mythology to history in the first millennium BC, the jews were in the process of deepening the relationship between their religion and history.

It’s believed that there was a new emphasis on the written tradition when the oral tradition came under threat – this is common throughout history. For the Jews, this was the time leading up to and into the Babylonian exile. Not only do stories seem to get increasingly historical as they approach this period in their record, it’s also the exact time during which the Ark went missing. So while the breastplate of Adam might seem like a more mythic artifact, there’s a temptation to see the ark as a historic one.

On the other hand, the loss of a connection with God was thematically consistent with other popular stories during the time of their exile, especially the story of Eden.

Most mythological traditions recognize a time before time, which is typically delineated by a flood--from the epic of Gilgamesh to the Chumash narratives of Southern California. And as we move forward in history from the flood, the stories tend to get increasingly historical. This is especially the case with myths set in the same time they were written down. When oral tradition is under threat, there tends to be a shift towards writing things down. When the temple was destroyed and the Jews were forced into exile there was new emphasis on the written tradition. This is also the exact moment when the Ark went missing, which is to say, the loss of the Ark was exactly on the minds of those historic

The book of genesis is clearly a fiction, any other book can have originated from a real memory. It was probably adjusted in many ways and many times throughout history, but it is not fully fantasy.

entries.question: HEADLINE What did the Ark do for the people of Israel during their 40-year journey?
entries.text:
The Ark was like a guiding light for the Jews.

As a star led the way to Jesus, the ark led to Israel. This is the motif of the guiding light, like the golden arrows that lead to Santiago.

When Semites ruled Egypt they identified with Seth, who used his great staff or scepter to cut through Apep—the world encircling snake. This enabled the solar prow, the seat of god, to pass into the divine realm. This world encircling snake represented the world encircling sea, or river, which is to say, Seth the semite used his staff to part the sea so that the seat of god could enter a Holy place. This sound a lot like Moses when he parts the red sea and the ark passes through.

This ark, by the way, also looks and sounds a lot like Aker, the seat of Osiris in the innermost chamber of the underworld. Aker is the secret scene at the absolute bottom of the underworld known only to pharaohs and priests, like the brother of Moses. This is the scene where the first divine spark comes into its vessel. This seat, by the way, is flanked, in the pyramid texts, by two chimera, and in the myth, two birds. Together, they look like Cherubim.

entries.question: Could the ark narrative be a true story, altered in certain ways? Why do you say so?
entries.text:
Exile from Eden and losing the Ark are stories about separation from home and god. Though they both carry incredibly ancient material, the focus on writing them down seems to have been in response to the Temple’s destruction and the Babylonian exile; so whether or not the story of the Ark is historically true, it expresses true historic experience.

When Constantine shifted Rome to Christianity he didn’t just move the capitol to Constantinople, he physically moved the pillar at Delphi, which was known as the center of the world where the God, Apollo, spoke.

Gods are associated with locations, but when you’re leaving to go somewhere new, God would have to be taken with you. It’s not just that the Ark serves as a seat for God, it also served as a transport. This is a fire theft.

ARK, GRAIL & HERCULES: We might compare the Ark with the golden cup boat of Herakles thst he rides from sunrise to sunset, where he retrieves a golden apple towards the end of his mortal journey, which culminates in his marriage to Hebe, cupbearer of the gods, who gives him Nectar or divine nourishment. This divine nourishment in the divine cup can be associated with the manna in the golden bowl within the ark. Similarly, we can compare the ark itself with the golden cupboat lent to Hercules by the sun god. Like the Ark, this is a golden vessel in which the god travels, like the ark, it’s associated with a golden cup filled with divine nourishment. One of the darkest connections can be seen in the cloak that kills Hercules like a blanket with small pox and the tumors with which the Ark smote its enemies. Both could be memories of biological warfare.

If we look for the potential presence of the Kabeiroi somewhere near the roots of philosophical history, we find them in Miletus – the storied birthplace of philosophy. Sandra Blakely recounts the story:

The king of Assessos was murdered by his brother, and his children, fearing for their lives, fled to neighboring Miletos. Their murderous uncle pursued, with the army of Assessos, and laid siege to the town. The people prayed for relief, and were told that help would come from Phrygia. This help appeared the next day in the form of two young men, Tottes and Onnes, who appeared out of Phrygia, bearing a kiste, a basket, between them that they carried with two poles; inside were the sacra of the Kabeiroi. They promised to save the town from its aggressors, if the

people would establish the rites of the gods. The city council accepted the cult, and the next day the two youths led the army out to battle behind the sacred kiste. The sight of the sacred container struck the attacking army with fear and panic, and they fled, eventually to join the Milesians in celebration of these gods. entries.text: Summary - „Israel’s Lost Tribes“

The Old Testament claims there have once been 12 tribes of israelitic people - the descendents of Joseph’s twelve sons. Ten of them vanished after an attack of the Assyrians. The prophets claim they are still „somewhere out there“ and their return to their home (today’s Israel) will bring back the Messiah. Today, everywhere in the world, people „pop up“ that either claim they are descendants of the Ten Lost Tribes or other people think they might be.

entries.question: Our main question is of course „Could the myth be true?“  or better „Could the lost tribes possibly exist until today?“
entries.text:
Historic roots in Israel

The first part of our research leads us to ruins in Israel that proof: yes, the so-called „Kingdom of Israel“ or „Northern Kingdom“ - which is supposed to be the union of 10 tribes -  did exist. And yes: it was conquered by the Assyrians. The „Kingdom of Judah“ (= the remaining 2 tribes Judah & Benjamin) was not touched by the Assyrians as they kept on paying their tributes. Our conclusion: the basic story of what Bible / Old Testament / Thora tell is based on true events. There was a divide between the Judaists and a great part of them vanished in the 8th century BC.

Numerous cases all over the world

Prof. Shalva Weil an Anthropologist from Jerusalem collects all the stories from the different possible tribes. Even though two of them have been officially recognised by Israel’s main Rabbi - until today there’s still no proof. We tell the example of the „Falashim“ or better „Beta Israel“- a jewish minority in Ethiopia. Since the 1970s they have been persecuted by different regimes so the state of Israel declared them to be descendants of the „Tribe of Dan“ and evacuated great numbers in the 80s and 90s. Calling them a „Lost Tribe“ just made things easier and was a smart move by the chief rabbi - but won’t serve as proof for the whole Tribe Story. The example also shows how closely connected religious and political questions are in Israel: being Jewish officially also means having the right to live in Israel / becoming an Israeli citizen.

The Lemba people

Our main case for trying to proof the story are the „Lemba“, a people living in northern South Africa and Zimbabwe. French Anthropologist Dr. Edith Bruder travels there. She meets a young man who wants to become the Lemba’s first rabbi, now that he knows that their own beliefs match with Jewish Religion. In general the Lemba just follow the rules of their ancestors without connecting their rituals and beliefs to religion at all. Today many Lemba are Christian, Messianic Jews or whatever… but they all avoid pork, circumcise their sons, are endogamic, slaughter their animals the same way jews did thousand of years ago. Dr. Bruder visits one of their Shabbats and experiences: it’s nothing like a normal Jewish shabbat. She then focusses on finding information about their own oral traditions. On a Lemba Cemetery she experiences that they bury their dead facing north - as this is where they believe to come from. In their oral tradition - there are no written sources - the name of their „home“ is Senna. Years ago, British researcher Dr. Parfitt claims to have found this place in today’s Yemen.

DNA samples show that some of the Lemba men - to be precise their priests called the „Bouba-Clan“ - seem to have more genetic parallels with people from Yemen than with surrounding African people. Another comparison between Bouba-Clan-members and Jewish people called „Cohen“ - which are descendants of the Jewish priests called „Cohanim“ - in 1999 indicates a high possibility they share a relatively high percentage of DNA. A follow-up study in 2013 puts numbers in question. With a German DNA specialist from Mac Planck Institute in Leipzig, we try to find out how reliable DNA tests are at all. A short experiment with up to three people shows - yes - it is possible to find out about your ancestors just by analysing your DNA. BUT the usual time frame for this won’t go back 3000 years. The set up of the 1999 test seems questionable to the expert but it still shows a high possibility for the Lemba to have roots in Arabia.

With regards to their rituals, their oral history and the DNA results, the anthropologists conclude that the Lemba might very likely be descendants from Judaic people. They are the best guess for a Lost Tribe - but it will probably never be possible to proof the myth at all.

entries.question: What makes Israel’s Law of Return so special?
entries.text:
Jews whose families have long since left Israel can project their own story onto that of the lost tribes—estranged and with forgotten links to the home world, still an essential part of the community with a standing invitation to return, which is literally provided by the state of Israel.

With Israel’s law of return, the question of whether or not the African Jews are from a lost tribe gets very important. If they are, they are entitled to a state sponsored visit and right to return. This would mean the entire group, if elevated to Lost Tribe Status by the chief rabbi, could immigrate to Israel.

It’s a strong link between religious and political matters. By allowing or even inviting all Jews (to be precise: people with at least one Jewish grandparent) to return to Israel it means: when you are Jewish - you can become an Israeli citizen. And who could be more Jewish than a descendent of the legendary tribes? That way a whole group of people could immigrate to Israel - if the chief rabbi officially gives them „lost tribe“ status.

entries.question: Why would DNA proof for the Myth be so important?
entries.text:
DNA evidence is a hard fact, and when it aligns with the Oral History of the Lemba and mythic memories of the Hebrews, and when deeper analysis shows so many similarities between their traditions, the question becomes hard to ignore. Before it was found, we thought Troy was just a myth Could this be happening with the Lost Tribes of Israel?

Jews expect a historicity to their myths, because their myths are their histories. This turns scientific investigation—like DNA testing—into religious investigation. So in the case of African Jews, DNA evidence becomes proof that their myth is historical, that they are part of the story, and that they, too, are chosen people.

The Jewish understanding of history as a living out of god’s plan gives religious significance to the historical validation of their mythic memories.

In Judaism, their histories are their religious narratives. History is the unfolding of God’s plan. And because of this, proof that their narratives are historically accurate becomes proof that their mythic memories are real.

entries.question: Lemba people claim their ancestors came as traders from Arabia - does that sound plausible?
entries.text:
Trade routes tend to outline coasts and follow trade winds. The extension of trade to the African Coast from the Arabian Peninsula was favored by both, which is why the migration route of the Lemba has become a super highway for global trade. All we have to do is get over the delusional myth that ancient humans weren’t highly interconnected, and we’ll see that their journey is not beyond reason.

In the case of Africa’s coast along the Indian Ocean, the coast of Africa is just an extension from the coast of India and the Arabian peninsula, so despite the fact that we tend to be blinded by a crazy myth that our world was disconnected, trade was far more integrated in the ancient world than most of us realize, including in this area, which is represented by era after era of cultural exchange.

entries.question: What does the lost tribe myth mean to the larger Jewish Diaspora?
entries.text: For any Jew not in Israel, they know their family left, at some point, for some reason. This personal memory and experience of separation becomes colored by religious narratives that cast such departures as tragedy while calling for return. We see it in the exile from Eden and desire to return. We see it in the Babylonian exile. We see it in the story of lost tribes. And we see the traumatic displacement from home become core to Jewish histories yet again when they were exiled from Spain, and again when they were taken to Concentration camps. This deep trauma of separation and the desire to return is more than historical. As we see in the story of Adam and Eve, it is a repetition of their experience of separation from god. To be in Eden was to be with God. To be in Israel before the temple was destroyed was to be where god was. To be forced from the Garden was to be forced from God, which was to be alone in the world.

entries.question: Where did the tribes of Israel come from in the first place?.
entries.text: According to the Jews, they arrived with Joshua after Moses led them from Egypt,and according to the historians, they began to appear on hilltops at the beginning of the Iron Age, just after the Bronze Age collapse, which is when they first appear in recorded history. The disagreement is over whether or not the Jews arrived in Palestine to displace the canaanites, or if they were a local group. On a much larger level, however, we have to recognize that The Phoenicians, who were the immediate neighbors of the Jews, came out on top when the world collapsed. In fact, the Phoenicians built the Hebrew temple. So what we have to realize is that this significantly affected migration patterns and economic realities in their neighborhood. So for me, the conclusion that Jews are just a runaway converted group of Palestinians is too simple. If you try to reconcile the historical and mythological account, you get the idea that at least some of the Palestinians who made up the Jewish community were Allies of the Phoenicians from the time of the Bronze Age collapse.

LOST TRIBE OF ISRAEL: By the time of the Khazars, Christians had been conflating the story of Adam & Eve with Prometheus and Pandora for centuries. If we go further and then conflate the scenes, which are both located at sunrise, on the world’s tallest mountain we find Eden in Khazaria, in the Caucasus, on Elbruz, the tallest mountain in the world from which the Greeks and Egyptians saw their sun rise, the mountain to which Prometheus is bound. Mythically, they are the same locations – the location at which the human condition is established—thus the common elements of human clay, mortality, suffering and labor.[1]

The imagination paves a clear road. We can see the mythic bridges from Eden to Khazaria. Are there literal ones? Could the original vision of Eden have come from Elbruz? Beyond question—it is harder to argue that it did not than that it did. When Genesis was written, Hebrew sailors shared the Mediterranean with Greeks and Egyptians, who saw the eastern edge over which their sun rose as the Caucasus mountain range. Written descriptions of Prometheus on Elbruz would have been roughly contemporary with Genesis. Unless the Hebrews had perfect earmuffs when engaging the larger world they shared, they located the sunrise and world’s tallest mountain in the same place as the other sailors with which they shared the Mediterranean. This is to say, the association of Elbruz with Eden would not have just been boosted by Christianity leading up to the time of the Khazars, it would have been in there from the beginning. Still, the connection is only in the imagination. Without a doubt, this connection in the imagination would have been significant. Did the British Royals really descend from Brutus from Troy, or is this just a fantasy maintained by the British imagination? Print the legend.

The question remains, however, could there have been a real and literal hereditary connection of the Khazar royalty with Hebrews in Israel? If Eden is the first homeland, how did Jews get to Israel? There are multiple answers covering multiple time periods, but the most recent time period of major significance was that of the Bronze Age Collapse, which is when the Hebrews first appear in written history. They appear among Sea Peoples in a raid on Egypt. Shortly after this period of Sea People raids, the population of Palestine exploded and converged to Judaism. We know that many of the Sea Peoples did indeed come from the Black Sea, where we find the Caucasus. If any of the founding tribes of Israel were from the Black Sea, if they were from the Black Sea themselves or if they settled with allies from the region, we can find a literal link and historical moment when Black Sea peoples came to Israel. This would explain why Greeks do not say they are from their sunrise mountain, but Hebrews do. It would also explain the ancient Hebrew familiarity with leading centers of iron work in the Black Sea. Genesis was written 600 years after this time. The Khazars emerged 1800 years after this time. If there was a memory of their ancient connection, could its final gossamer have been maintained by a Royal lineage? Could it have faded into legend? Would the legends have died?

Jews, today, recognize themselves as descended from Shem, and as the story goes, the Muslims are descended from Ishmael, but in truth, Jews are not the only Semites. The genetic story of the Jews suggests that they are a fraction of the semites.

When we do this, there aren’t always perfect fits, and these imperfect fits can point us back to the origins of our myths. For example, Eden is supposedly the tallest mountain in the world, and it was located at the place from which the sun rose. From Sumer to Israel, there are no mountains that fit this description. If the description of Eden in the East, at the sunrise, and on the tallest mountain, we have to at least ask, could Elbruz be an inspiration for Eden? entries.text: Dr. Will Linn, mythologist

entries.question: What makes the Mothman such a special myth?
entries.text: Mothman is one of those myths based on a major traumatic event that involved 46 deaths and multiple reports of paranormal activity. This is the stuff that becomes hard for a culture to forget. And like most historical memories, it’s become layered with mythic content.

entries.question: Can you tell us a bit about the history of American Folklore, how does the Mothman fit into it?
entries.text: American folklore is a melting pot of traditions brought over from Europe and Africa –sometimes even Asia—to a crucible that was already cooking with native narratives and ancient memories. This American imagination was then responsible for the transmutation of our democratic, capitalistic, scientific and technological revolutions into mythopoeic dreams.

entries.question: Can you tell us more about the Native American Folklore, what distinguished their myths and legends from others?
entries.text:
The recurring focus on the spirit world in Native American Folklore expresses a particularly Shamanic origin, as does the prevalence of Ticksters over heroes and the popularity of talking animals.

Native American Folklore expresses a particularly Shamanic quality in its recurring focus on the spirit world. That tricksters are more common than heroes is also resonant with the prominence of Shamanism over priesthoods and more orthodox religions. The other quality that comes with this is an emphasis on

One quality of Native American folklore is that there tend to be more Tricksters than Heroes, which is to say,

Folklore all over the world, in contrast with myth, tends to use talking animals. Much of what we think of as Native American Folklore fits into this category—Coyote, Raven and so on. This is not to say that there weren’t more developed and human state myths; the Popol Vuh, for example. It’s possible that the heavy use of animals pertains to a tradition of storytelling shaman. Unlike Europe, which was dominated by a priesthood, the Shaman was more common in Native American culture. Shaman, as Campbell points out, are more interested in a personal and fluid divine connection. Priests, on the other hand, tend to be more concerned with the Orthodoxy of their tradition. This is seen in the Native American tradition,

entries.question: Did the first settlers in America think that the Native Americans have magical power?
entries.text:
The Christian belief in the Fall leaves a back door for socalled primitive cultures to be seen by Christians as less fallen and more in touch with pre-scientific powers. At the same time, the Christian perception of the unconverted could lead to the conflation of Shamans as witch doctors if not devils. Both of these predispositions set up a projection of supernatural powers onto Native Americans, and that’s without the consideration of spectacular activities they may have witnessed.

Any capabilities that aren’t understood are typically seen as magical; for which reason both settlers and natives—in the Americas and elsewhere—projected special abilities on the other.

entries.question: Why did people tell the story that Chief Cornstalk could have put a bad spell on the land and related it to Mothman?
entries.text:
As the story goes, Chief Colesqua, also known as Chief Cornstalk of the Shawnee nation, pursued peace with Europeans until he and his son were shot dead. Whether it’s an old oral story or made up details of a 20th century play, the story is that, as he died, he cursed his assailants and their entire culture. His remains were then moved, multiple times, to Point Pleasant, which is believed to have been haunted by the Mothman. The curse of a dying foe is an old motif that’s taken very seriously – this for the same reason prophecies depend on living entrails. The notion is that something between life and death can communicate truth—if not power—from one to another.

My guess is that the curse wouldn’t be so scary if the socalled White Man didn’t actually know that what they’d done was wrong, that a curse or retribution was right. And so, when something really happened, it would have been hard for anyone not to see a connection.

entries.question: The 60s were a time of uncertainties (Cold War, Vietnam etc). Could the general mood of the society influencing an urban legend, such as the Mothman sighting? For example draw conclusions to aliens, Men in Black, government secrecies etc.
entries.text: We see through our lens that is our self, paranoia leads to projection, and the 60s were a time of paranoia. The Nazi use of state propaganda and the American use of a nuclear bomb were not yet distant memories, Cold War espionage was very real and intense. New scientific breakthroughs—some of them wildly powerful—were only beginning to be understood. This was true for government officials as much as regular citizens, for which reason the government had to take UFO and other reports quite seriously – who knew what the Russians could have made? At this time, both Russia and America were spending a lot of resources on paranormal and parapsychological research.  So as the rise of secularism left a hole in the existential spirits of populations, they transferred their projections from religious figures—like angels and demons—to the more scientifically oriented aliens and paranormal research.

entries.question: Why is the Mothman myth still known today?
entries.text: Richard Gear and a good screenplay have a lot to do with why we still tell the myth, but there’s also something interesting about the way this particular story avoids the recognizable mythic trappings that lead others to dismissal. There’s something about how secular it feels as an event—paranormal, but secular. The Mothman is not easily identifiable as anything that’s already been dismissed—aliens, Demons, reptilian illuminati. Speaking for myself here, I feel more free to project my own possibilities into the narrative—and these range from quantum speculations about the timeless of soul to mundane dismissals of statistical anomalies. The lack of identifiable detail enables people to project their own.

entries.question: Since the dawn of mankind avian humanoids are a common motif in many different cultures, mythologies and popular fiction. What are the explanations?
entries.text:
Ancient Aliens, I’m coming at ya! Sometimes the fact that deities come from above is a metaphor; and sometimes technology from the heavens means iron tools made from meteorites. The conflation of from the heavens with deities from space is just an updated form of reductive literalism.

Talking about different mythologies, what bird like creatures meant in different cultures and draw similarities to the Mothman

Birds represent an ability to traverse multiple domains—especially water birds that can dive below waves as well as fly above them. This has led to their association with celestial lights that fly through the sky and swim through the sea. It’s also led to their association with the soul, which can hopefully travel between worlds. The mothman, similarly, is seen as a being that straddles realities.

Ancient Sumerian and Babylonian deities tend to have 2-4 wings. When there are four wings, two point up and two down, like the Mayan deity associated with Venus and bees. My interpretation is that the up and down direction of wings pertains to the ability of a celestial object to go up and come down. We know that the winged disk they ride was associated with the sun, sorry again, Ancient Aliens.

Moths and Men are of two totally different genus, which means their actual blending is likely to be more surreal than biological. That having been said, as John Colarusso points out, hybrid children of dueling cultures were often created very intentionally and for the purpose of creating a bridge. IF there were aliens, a hybrid would be instrumental in such a bridge, and IF there were such a hybrid, maybe the conflict between alien powers and human sympathies could have led a mothman to try and avert a human tragedy.

The moth, like a butterfly, has transformed from a more primitive form. This relates to the belief of some that Mothmen are what we see when we look at our future incarnations. Interesting that it’s not a butterfly but a moth, whose association with the night can be conflated with an association with death. Both are symbolic of resurrection, but where the Butterfly resurrects into day, the Moth remains in night. This is consistent with the notion that the mothman comes from somewhere beyond, before or beneath life. .

entries.question: Are there any other similar monsters or bringer of bad luck like Mothman?
entries.text:
The impundulu or “lightning bird” of South Africa is especially reminiscent of the MOthman in that it’s a dark and winged humanoid bringer of ill fortune. Also like the Mothman, this creature is associated with disaster, in this case lightning strikes, and is believed to be immortal. It’s especially associated with witchcraft and vampirism.

If the bridge collapse were to be seen as just retribution for crimes against natives, the Mothman might be compared with the furies – winged deities who execute hellacious forms of justice.

Bad Luck deities are often associated with seafaring, from the Nain Rouge (or Red Dwarf) to the old belief that women were bad luck on a ship. Another example of a bad luck deity can be found in Fear Gorta, another Irish figure who responds to the lack of hospitality by instilling bad luck.

Bad luck is especially associated with curses, which are often levied by witches and other deities.

entries.question: The Appalachians seem to be an epicenter of urban legends and folklore in the United States, from monsters, to UFO sightings to the Mothman. How come?
entries.text: The weird stuff in myth is always projected onto locations beyond reach or rarely visited. For this reason, myths that spring up around mountains, seas, bottomless lakes and other unknown zones are typically more laden with the paranormal. In the same way it’s easier to believe in ghosts when you’re alone in a dark unknown place, darker less known and less populated areas tend to be more able to sustain paranormal stories. This can also be because of the way people living in urban settings see less populated areas less separate from nature.

entries.question: Is there a correlation between increasing media reports and mass hysteria in society?
entries.text:
Right or wrong, official media is associated with authoritative truth – this is why the War of the Worlds caused such mass Hysteria.

The question of whether or not an increase in media reports can lead to an increase in mass hysteria leads to the next chilling question… If more reports creates more hysteria, and if hysteria is the hardest part to manage, wouldn’t the people responsible for responding to that hysteria seek to limit or garble the reports? And if you come to this conclusion, you’ve lost trust in media.

entries.question: Is there a correlation between the origins of urban legends and places? Are there locations/places that more receptive as source for myths?
entries.text:
Myths are frequently grounded in their environment, to the point that ancient conquerors were more likely to embrace the local deities than insist on the gods from home.

See question 11

entries.question: Are there any differences how myths are born today and 50 years back?
entries.text:
Urban legends are typicall spread from person to person. They’re something different by the time they’re canonized and statues are made. For this reason, social media has been an explosive conduit for the sharing of paranormal stories. Anyone with a weird picture or experience can post and share, which throws gasoline on the spreading of Urban Myths.

Myths are always transmedia – never limited to a single form like the novel, comic or play. For more than 50 years, movies have been the dominant media, but myths can’t spread if contained to a single medium. The Mythopoeic Society just celebrated their 50th anniversary – a group that cosplayed before cosplay was a thing—for lord of the rings. By now we have Comic Con – by now cosplay is HUGE. I think the transmedia capacity of our myths has been much more greatly optimized over the last 50 years. In some ways this is commercial, but I don’t think Hercules would be as famous if he couldn’t move vases.

entries.question: What makes a Myth a Myth?
entries.text:
Myths are the biggest stories most deeply engaged by the most people for the longest time. You might say that myths are vessels made for wisdom, vehicles made for its carriage—across distances, across time. Myths, like dreams, are the translation of mental activity into sensory experience. In this way, myths, like dreams, are made of metaphor. And so how do you get there? I think myths emerge where patterns converge.

Too many people want to flatten myths into allegories – as though they can be reduced to a single inspiration. Bor-ring! Says the imagination. Too easy for a mind too smart. Allegories are but threads in the cloth of the quilt that is myth

Myths emerge where patterns converge – the myth of Osiris is the story of night and day, death and life, wake and sleep, harvest and growth, displaced Pharoahs and new reigns...all at once. Myths are made of synesthesia. Crescent horns become crescent moons become crescent blades become crescent tusks—all at once! In myth, something’s pattern drags in the meaning of everything else with that pattern. And through pattern, myth mixes the human with nature, with animals, with the heavens.

entries.question: Who was Nostradamus? What reminds people even today of the name Nostradamus?
entries.text:
If Merlin is the most famous wizard…

…Nostradamus is the most famous prophet. In the last 500 years, there’s been hardly a disaster, tyrant or pandemic, not seen in his quatrains.

Nostradamus most famous prophet for 500 years

is supposed to have foreseen the worst catastrophes, destructions and wars

Whenever something catastrophic happens in the world, the name Nostradamus always falls in media reports.

entries.question: What is Nostradamus' pattern? What do his verses mostly testify to and how does society react to them today?
entries.text:
Nostradamus’ prophecies – especially those to which we gravitate – tend to focus on disaster.

Disastrous deaths, disastrous leaders, disastrous pandemics and wars. Society would like to avert disaster, and so prophecies catch our ears.

Nostradamus is considered as the master among the prophets

large part about destruction and war, tyrants and his victims. He spreads the idea of disaster scenarios. Many see his words as a warning, others are already preparing for doomsday.

entries.question: Where do ideas for disaster movies come from? Explain what method, what kind of plot make disaster movies so popular? E.g. moral concept of Roland Emmerich.
entries.text:
From the films of Roland Emmerich to Revelations, Apocalypse stories represent the projection of our own mortality onto that of our species. This is a natural thought, so it’s a natural myth --- from the Great Conflagration of the Stoics to the asteroid in Armageddon. But where death and resurrection provide metaphors for the renewal of an individual, Apocalypse is about the renewal of humanity.

Ideas of catastrophic future scenarios: Events that have already happened.

Roland Emmerich makes people aware of everyday things: climate change or even human values.

entries.question: Why do we humans predict things? What is the higher reason behind it?
entries.text:
Anticipating what is going to happen is a survival skill – literally and emotionally. Whether it’s anticipating a predator or a war, a harvest or a romantic connection – we anticipate to avoid suffering and pursue happiness. Our desire to avoid suffering and pursue happiness, however, can motivate us to believe in prophecies that might not be as justified as we want to believe. Convincing ourselves we know the future gives us a sense of control – justified or not.

Fortune telling perhaps as old as mankind itself.

Will to keep control.

We have control over our present, know the past, but the future is completely foreign to us. Man has always tried to control the future as well.

entries.question: From the Oracle of Delphi to the astrology of the Middle Ages until today: Where does the desire to control fate come from? Which method holds up best and why?
entries.text:
Astrology is to Tarot as Relativity is to Quantum Mechanics.

Where astrology is all about the regularity of stars, Tarot is about god’s dice. Delphic prophecies, on the other hand, look more like interpreted dreams. What they all share in common is metaphor, on which every oracle depends.

Civilizations thrive on good predictions—from the anticipation of seasons to global warming and the forecast of earnings. This is what meteorologists are after – and astrologers. Both are trying to turn patterns in the sky into earthly predictions.

The difference is that

entries.question: science has not been convinced by astrologers of their evidence or logic. The question then becomes, is the evidence of astologers insufficient, or is the logic of scientists incomplete?
entries.text:
Both involve reading metaphors—like dream interpretation—which is the focus of oracles.

so astrology is about the connection between our inner movements and cosmic clocks. Tarot and the throwing of bones, however, is about reading chance.

Reading the stars is about interpreting the movements of the macrocosm as movements in the microcosm. As above so below—as without so within.

This is very different than the throwing of bones or drawing of cards, which is

The desire to control fate is man-made. So is its choice of practices. Stargazing, for example, is a practice that is still used today. It dates back to the Babylonians 3000 years ago.

Explain the logic of astrology.

Ancient civilizations tended to represent their vision of the heavens in the construction of their cities and the configuration of their courts – On earth as it is in heaven, as above so below. What myth should we believe in? Are we lonely specs of dust in a huge universe or are we microcosmic miniatures of the cosmos itself? World religions and mythologies repeatedly present a vision of the individual as a piece or recreation of the creator or cosmos. And from this perspective, one might ask if there is entanglement between the shifting of inner and outer constellations? Of Macro and microcosmos?

entries.question: there a pattern that repeats across the octaves of being? Can the form of the cosmos be found in an atom? In Adam?
entries.text: It is the simple principle of analogy. According to ancient belief, the world is built according to ratios and proportions. The proportions in the universe are mirrored in man. And vice versa: "As above, so below; as within, so without; as the mind, so the body".

entries.question: How does Nostradamus connect his learned knowledge of history and his subjective observations of the present?
entries.text:
When Tolkien was pressed to admit that Lord of the Rings was about World War I, he replied that the audience’s closeness to World War I is what enabled them to see what he recognized as recurring narratives. Nostradamus seems to have similarly accessed perennial patterns through the comparison of historic repetitions with the time in which he lived.

His observations of the present suddenly sound strongly like the past events of which Nostradamus had read: epochs of religious discord, revolutions, ostracisms and civil wars seem catapulted into his time. He realizes that the future of his country looks like the destroyed past.

entries.question: How fatal can an error in print be in a prose text compared to Nostrdamus' verse form?
entries.text:
When looking for hidden meanings and codes, a misprint or misplacement – even of a coma or single letter – can make all the difference.

In a prosaic narrated text, such errors can still be easily read over. In Nostradamus' poetry form, however, already a wrong or not at all placed comma can result in a completely new sense.

entries.question: Interpretations have been taken from faulty editions and mistranslations that collide and confuse, which can be said of any esoteric text—from the Tarot to Revelations. How far back does a mistranslation go? We should ask. What meaning was lost or distorted?
entries.text: Later translations into German and English - If thereby faulty editions were used also the translations were wrong. A chaos!

entries.question: There is a verse about two lions in battle. What is special about this verse in relation to the Nostradamus myth?
entries.text:
The resemblance of a quatrain with his own king’s death is, uncanny:

He and his younger adversary are baring lions, it’s single combat, he’s stabbed in the eye, through his visor, it’s a double wound, and his drawn out death, was certainly cruel.

entries.question: What makes the verse of the death of the king wrong?
entries.text:
The least obvious detail is that of the gold. The helmet couldn’t have been gold. Did it have gold trim? Is it a metaphor for royalty, were there crown-like elements in the helmet, or was there no gold at all, and should we be paying more attention to the reality that this quatrain didn’t get connected to Henry until he was dead for 50 years?

Unfortunately, the prophecy of the death of King Henry II remains a myth. Only 50 years after Nostradamus' death this verse was first associated with the death of Henry. Nostradamus himself may never have meant this. It is a pure matter of interpretation.

entries.question: Which meaning has the verse of the lion in the golden cage for the notoriety of Nostradamus? Assuming most details will be narrated

One of the most detailed examples of a potential Nostradamus prophecy is that of King Henry’s death. He and his younger adversary bore lions on their shields and he was killed by two shards of lance – one through his visor and one through his temple. Could this be what Nostradamus meant when wrote that a younger lion would be killed by a pierced eye and double wound?

These are seen as consistent with the prophecy of a younger lion    and detailed prophecies seems to be that of King Henry’s death. It’s said that the young lion will overcome the older one, which he does,

entries.question: What is the difference between being able to predict the future and being able to influence the future? How many chances does a future algorithm program have of actually being successful at some point? What else does it need?
entries.text:
In the last few years, major shows like Westworld and Devs have featured the idea of predicting the future with algorithms and exerting control. Jung was wary of this. The problem is that while the probabilities predicted by Quantum Mechanics are incredibly accurate, variation and anomaly is part of the prediction. So the question becomes, is it irresponsible, if not tyrannical, to impose a statistical prediction on the individual level.

(Anticipating crime to prevent it is a noble goal. But computer algorithms recognize patterns that make it possible to see the future. But what if the future has no patterns? What if everything is chaos? Perhaps Nostradamus' verses are so chaotic precisely because he knew there are no patterns and anything that can happen will happen.)

entries.question: Is there a scientific explanation for visions of the future? Are they imagination or a real glimpse into the future?
entries.text:
The first question is if there is a phenomena through which future participates in the present. The second question is if we could or have build a sense around that phenomena. And the third question is if this has been convincingly demonstrated. While I’m not convinced of any demonstration or aware of a sensory organ that detects the future, there are phenomena

Prophecy may not be provable or even probable, but it is not scientifically disqualified either. Actually, there are some pretty interesting qualities of time, entanglement and M-Theory that raise questions about the participation of our future in the present. The question then becomes, if our future self is in some sort of participation with our present self, can we access what it sees?

entries.question: What is the state of "trance"? How does it work and what does it do to us? Is it something like hypnosis?
entries.text: By writing poetry in a trancelike state, Nostradamus was a predecessor of the Surrealists and David Lynch, who seek access beyond their conscious mind. Neuroscientific studies on mystics—especially Tibetans—has shown that altered states of consciousness can open access to thoughts and insights that would be otherwise inaccessible.

entries.question: What is the hindsight error?
entries.text:
People are looking to validate their beliefs. Those who want to believe in prophecy and what that means to them will see Nostradamus hit the mark. Those who want to believe there is no such thing will find fault. Both can be projected on the range of possible interpretations.

If a disaster happens, e.g. accident or pandemic, then often afterwards the headline appears: "Did Nostradamus foresee it".

People are really looking for a Nostradamus verse that could fit.

entries.question: Which oracles/prophets from history are best known? Which ones are simply known?
entries.text:
From John the Revelator to the Oracle of Delphi, no prophet is more famous, today, than Nostradamus.

The Maya calendar, the John revelation, the world history is full of prophecies about the forthcoming end of the world.

But the most famous prophet is Nostradamus.

entries.question: Which indications speak for the coding of the verses, which against it?
entries.text:
Nostradamus wouldn’t have been the first to encode a message in his poetry—in the metaphors of his imagery or the math of his meter. Both encode meaning in the Tarot, in Alchemical Recipes and Astrological interpretations. At the same time, mystics tend to see patterns in their sacred texts.

Poetry and meter brings math to language, which is often seen in sacred texts. From the quatrains of Nostradamus to the Talmud and Rig Veda, mystics look for codes.

Nostradamus was a strict catholic, but also a scientist

in the writing of his verses he was a poet.

Many people believe behind the poetic writing is a kind of code, because it is so much different than normal text
