entries.text: ITV Questions Will Linn: Tunguska

entries.question: Why are there so few eyewitness reports of the event?
entries.text: Luckily, the meteor did not explode over an urban area – it was remote. That having been said, it was also the case that locals were so affected and superstitions about it; talking about it was not encouraged.

entries.question: Why was Tesla and his “death rays” suspected to have caused the explosion?
entries.text: My favorite part of the story is that it brings in Tesla, a mythic figure on his own. The theory is that Tunguska was produced by the deathray he claims to have been working on at that time. According to his account, he accelerated particles from the ionosphere with the help of a teslacoil. This is a guy who invented the remote control and what seems like half of the world’s technology while claiming to be in conversation with Martians. I find I never know what to believe when it comes to this guy, but I do know that he would have had a hard time creating the vacuum tube he should have needed to accelerate particles from the ionosphere. Then again, who am I to question Tesla?

entries.question: There are also theories that a black hole or the crash of a UFO caused the event. Why do people come up with these kinds of theories?
entries.text: If you can’t explain something completely, all bets are off. And when you’re talking about a ball of fire from the sky, UFO’s are going to be an obvious explanation. Some might point to the discovery of meteorite shards, but if our fighter jets use camouflage and drop flares, why wouldn’t we think UFO’s drop meteorites when they have to self destruct to preserve the prime directive? I’m not saying it’s the easiest explanation, but I want to point out that most scientific reductions are worlds away from the scientifically possible.

entries.question: Are there any other similar events?
entries.text: There have been many recorded examples of meteorites that explode when hitting thicker layers of the atmosphere, which is the story of what happened. There are also accounts all throughout history of fireballs and strange phenomenon in the sky.

entries.question: Why is Tunguska still a mystery today?
entries.text:
Truth be told, the lack of a crater can be explained by a meteor’s explosion in the atmosphere. It’s even possible that an exploding meteorite could have caused such destruction. The real mystery, is the strength of its shockwave, which shouldn’t have been generated by an exploding meteor—even a big one.

The level of consensus required to really move on hasn’t really been reached—110 years later. And we haven’t changed – we’re still drawn to the unexplained with every possibility we want to explore!

entries.question: Could such an impact happen again? And if so how bad would the damage be?
entries.text:
The realest fear is that this is what it looks like when a very big meteor luckily explodes just before impact. If a meteor this big had hit the earth, the damage would have been overwhelming; and we all know, extinction events like this CAN occur.

Let’s just hope Bruce Willis isn’t busy.

episodes.title: Megaliths & Stonehenge
episodes.summary: They spread throughout most of Europe – megalithic monuments. Stone circles, dolmen, burial chambers and megalithic temples. They’re the only remnants of peoples that have long vanished. As they have...

entries.text: They spread throughout most of Europe – megalithic monuments. Stone circles, dolmen, burial chambers and megalithic temples. They’re the only remnants of peoples that have long vanished. As they have left us with no written records these monuments are the only sources to get to know them. Who were these people? How were they able to construct these elaborate megalithic monuments? And for what purpose?

entries.question: Stonehenge is one of Britain’s most well-known touristic attractions and famous for its alignment with the summer solstice. Hundreds of people come together to celebrate the event each year. But how was it built around 4.000 years ago? And what was the monument’s purpose?
entries.text:
But Stonehenge is not the only remaining stone circle from prehistory. In the UK there are several hundreds of them spread throughout the country, some small in size, some big, some have almost vanished, some strangely aligned – they prompt speculations: Do they have an astronomical significance? Are they constructed using mathematical laws? A knowledge that has now been lost?

The sanctuary Pömmelte in Germany is a circular structure built in the Bronze Age – not from stone but from hundreds of timber posts. Its architecture and alignment, however, are very similar to Stonehenge. Archaeological findings of skeletons of women and children that are severely damaged suggest brutal rituals. Have these people sacrificed humans during their feasting?

One of the most advanced and secluded prehistoric cultures has existed on the Islands of Malta around 3.000 BC. They have left an unparalleled density of megalithic temples which survives to this day. The temple Ggantija on Gozo shows the unique architecture of these prehistoric people who not just celebrated elaborate feasting rituals but also developed a unique art style with figurines mostly showing obese women. The “Fat Ladies” are often interpreted to reflect a mother goddess that was supposedly worshipped by this culture. However, experts suggest that they symbolize fertility as Malta has always struggled with harsh and unwelcoming environmental conditions.

entries.question: Why is the sun an important part in many pagan beliefs?
entries.text:
We see our own journey in the journey of the sun—from the projection of death on sunset to birth or rebirth on sunrise. We also wake up and go to sleep with the sun, with its high summer days and long winter nights. But these weren’t just clocks and metaphors for Neolithic humans. These great structures were built by Communities who sought alignment with reality’s rhythms.

This is to say, they projected the human journey onto the journey of the sun. Life is a journey from sunrise to sunset, and the afterlife is a journey from sunset to sunrise.

What walks on four legs in the morning, two at midday, and three in the afternoon? This is the riddle of the Sphinx, and it points to the essence of solar symbolism. First and foremost, we see our journey in the sun’s. We see our birth in sunrise, after which we crawl on all fours; and we see death in the sunset, before which we walk with a cane.

For them, the winter solstice wasn’t just the first light of a new year. It was also the beaconing of new light in all journeys, including a loved ones journey through death.

In sunrise we see awakening and birth. In sunset we see death and ends. But these aren’t just metaphors for Neolithic humans, and The winter solstice wasn’t just the first light of a new year. They built these monuments to align their own spirits with the cycles of their world.

entries.question: Why would it have been important for neolithic man to align their monuments to the sun?
entries.text:
The solar day and year weren’t just clocks for Neolithic humans, nor were these monuments. They were built to align the journeys of life and death with the rhythms of creation.

When people participate in ritual together, they don’t feel alone, and loneliness is one of the great curses of humanity, which can turn into hate and violence if not resolved. So if we learn anything from these monuments, it should be the importance of being together.

These great monuments enabled early humans to synchrionize with one another by aligning with the world. This provided major relief to the all to common experience of lonely estrangement, which becomes violence and hate, if not resolved.

The alignment of human life with the solar journey isn’t just about having a healthy and prosperous life, aligning with the winter solstice is about aligning the self with renewal—if not eternity.

The division of religion and culture is a recent development, so when we think of the practical and technological value of aligning a society with the sun, we cannot separate the spiritual quality of this alignment. Ok, yes, it helped with farming and organizing life, but it also helped the individual feel in participation — with each other and with the cosmos. Aren’t all our worst problems today the product of estranged lonely individuals? And so even the spiritual answer isn’t just spiritual, there’s practical value to making sure there aren’t extremely alienated individuals who would damage society.

The Summer and Winter Solstice are the turning points of the year, with which megaliths are often aligned. At the Zenith of the Summer Solstice, the year reaches its height and begins to cool and darken. At the Winter Solstice, the days transition from getting colder, darker, drier and more dead to warmer, wetter, brighter and more alive. And it’s not just the resurrection of nature we associate with this solar return—this is also the core metaphor for the resurrection of an individual, which is why Easter is celebrated at sunrise.

entries.question: Could megalithic monuments have been a solar calendar?
entries.text: Megalithic monuments functioned as celestial clocks and terrestrial calendars that were anchored, like our calendars, by ritual holidays with spiritual meaning.

entries.question: Why are so many monuments aligned with the winter solstice?
entries.text:
For the same reason the Green Knight is decapitated in Arthur’s court on Christmas Eve—because for the Anglo Saxons of that time, Christmas and New Years were on the Winter Solstice, and the decapitation of the Green Knight represents the annual death of nature. The Winter Solstice is when the year goes from getting colder, darker, drier and more dead to warmer, wetter, brighter and more alive. And it’s not just the resurrection of nature we associate with the solar return—this is also the core metaphor for the resurrection of an individual, which is why Easter is celebrated at sunrise.

Many megalithic monuments are solar calendars, some are lunar calendars, some track the movements of Venus and some track the journey of earth through its seasons. Calendar, however, is a reductive term. They weren’t just keeping time. They were participating in it. If you know when teatime is, you can have tea with everyone—emphasis on, with everyone. Modern lovers of astrology may want to know what’s going on up there so they know how it’s influencing them down here, but what alignment with the heavens is really about is just alignment — it’s about setting tea times with the cosmos.

entries.question: How would people have felt entering the dark megalithic temples for rituals?
entries.text:
Entering a megalithic temple was like crossing the threshold between day and dream.  The shift into darkness and chanting with ritual objects and symbolic imagery was accompanied by a shift in consciousness from daily life to participation in mythic time. To enter an ancient temple or the ritual caves that came before them was to enter a womb, the source and center of all creation. And that’s how it felt — to be in the source and center of meaning. Womb to tomb?

Entering a dark temple is a full sensory experience. Your eyes will have to adjust to the darkness within seconds. There are only little flickering lights of candles illuminating the space. Next thing you see are lifesized images of saints who stare directly at you. It smells of incense, the temperature drops. Your entire body is forced to immediately adapt. And then there's deep and rhythmic chanting piercing through your body. That hits every sense.

To enter a megalithic temple was like entering an even more ancient ritual cave. It was to cross a threshold into a completely different environment than the outside world. Like the transition from day to night or wake to sleep, it was a journey into darkness. , it was a journey into a  go from outside to inside,

entries.question: How are math, metrology and astronomy connected to each other?
entries.text: Ancient humans had a lot of time to watch the sky, in which they found patterns that anticipated seasons, predicted weather, and helped them with directions. This practice gave rise to celestial navigation, astronomy and meteorology as the abstraction of these patterns in the sky became geometry.

entries.question: Might the knowledge of geometry and astronomy have played a role in the construction of the monuments?
entries.text:
Geometry and architecture seem to have co-created each other. From henges to pyramids to Greek cities and contemporary design, architecture and geometry are partners.

The construction of these monuments depended on intuitive and eventually highly systemitized mathematical forms.

entries.question: What do geometric shapes symbolize? Circle, triangle, square?
entries.text:
SWIRL: Like theaters, the temples from which they evolved were designed for good sound. Sound becomes visible on vibrating surfaces, like water, in the form of ripples and swirls, which also appear in megaliths. Could these be images of the sound in these structures? And could they have anything to do with the Greek and Hebrew records of stone assembled with sound. .

TRIANGLE: By the time of the Greeks, the triangle was a symbol of fire, change, knowledge and power, but the use of triangulation to gain power over the changing world by reading heavenly fire could have be a Neolithic breakthrough.

Today, as it was in ancient history, the triangle is a symbol of change and energy, fire or light. And if we look even further back, to pre-history, we find early humans gaining power over change with the help of triangulation, which enabled them to read and predict the heavenly fire lights.

Reading the stars is all about triangulation, which gave humans power.  humans to predict and control change. The triangle emerged as a symbol of knowledge, light and change.  For Neolithic humans, triangulation was used for power over change.

Circles convey cyclical completion — like that of a day, year or life. They also convey the notion of inner and outer. Megaliths prioritize inner circles and anyone who did not participate in the ritual holidays would have been left out. Like a music festival today, some people would have journeyed to sites they saw as centers of essential activity. Others would have gone out of fomo, or fear of missing out.

Squares appear as symbols of material solidity — even a three dimensional triangle has four sides – like a square. This is why the root chakra in the Hindu tradition is represented by a square. Even basic experience tells us that a foundation becomes sturdy with a fourth side.

entries.question: What would you say drove the megalithic man to build these monuments?
entries.text:
Most megaliths seem to have been built by communities who wanted to align with their cosmos for practical and spiritual reasons that included everything from more successful planting to more successful sex, social lives, afterlives and meaningful play.

Celebrations at these monuments would be hard to distinguish from parties.. I suspect there was even fun involved, maybe love, maybe sex, and certainly celebration.

In a pre literate society, the paper on which they wrote was nature itself. Instead of putting ink to paper, they put stone to earth.

Megaliths are testaments of human motivation, and I think it took every motivation we had—from better timed planting seasons to a more successful afterlifes. And social life’s.

Slaves didn’t build these things. They were built by communities who wanted to align with their cosmos for spiritual and practical reasons. I suspect there was even fun involved, maybe love, maybe sex, and certainly celebration.

In a pre literate society without paper, maps, calendars and ideas were modeled with stone monuments, which made them a sort of half step between writing surfaces and a memory map.

entries.question: Why is the assumption stone circles in general were constructed by mathematical and astronomical rules problematic?
entries.text: The alignment of megaliths to solar and lunar cycles—all over the world—is undeniable. That geometrical and mathematical patterns can be found in the stones is also undeniable, but we can also find geometry in structures made by ants, which is to say, the megalithic period is a time during which it’s hard to distinguish intellectual achievement from intuition. It may even be a time when one became the other.

entries.question: What does sanctuary Pömmelte stand for?
entries.text:
Circular sanctuaries create a sacred reality within the circles that could be distinguished from the mundane world outside of them — a modern person might compare this with being in a church or stadium for a meaningful event. On one level, this is  about entering a sacred center for sacred moments.

By sewing the human order into the solar journey, circular sanctuaries link earth and sky, which transforms the feasts and rituals into heavenly activities.

entries.question: How was Pömmelte's sanctuary used?
entries.text: Pömmelte's inner circle functioned like a prehistoric church. It was a sanctuary for ritual performances at which groups of people would gather and feast as cultural leaders took stage to teach.

entries.question: What do we typically think about people of the stone and bronze age?
entries.text: Because ancient humans didn’t have the tools we have, we tend to think they weren’t as smart as we are, but there is no evidence of this. In fact, writing reduced many of our brain’s capacities. I don’t have the memory they had. So when we look back at ancient humans and their monuments, it’s important to not dismiss ancient brilliance.

entries.question: Do stone circles and megalithic sites have a spiritual meaning?
entries.text: Even the practical applications of a megalith are grounded in its spiritual meaning. To recognize the winter solstice wasn’t just a practical demarcation of time, it was a spiritual participation in time. Spirit is as spirit does. To time planting with the seasons is to align the activity of spirit with creation — there was nothing practical without spiritual implications.

entries.question: How are archaeology and astronomy connected? How about Mythology?
entries.text: Over and again, we seek answers about the beyond from above and below. Where do we come from, where do we go? The answers aren’t here or now.  According to myth, the first philosopher fell into a well when looking up at the sky. This is no different than the astronomers who study patterns in the heavens dig up by archaeologists. (?)

entries.question: What is the legacy of the megalithic cultures?
entries.text:
Megaliths are like time machines — on one hand, they were machines that used for the measurement of time, and on another, they traveled to the future and take us to the past.

Megaliths speak across vast distances of time. In the first well documented epic quest for immortality, Gilgamesh landed on the conclusion that his immortality would be preserved in a stone monument. That’s what these are — at least for us today, monuments of great humans and  ancient memtories.

PARTICIPATION & ESTRANGEMENT

There’s a big leap you have to take to understand megaliths, and it’s not that hard, t you have to take it. Megaliths are about PARTICIPATION—participation with nature, participation with cosmos and with other humans. By aligning the individual w the rituals of the monument the individual became aligned — socially, professionally and spiritually, with each other and their world. This participation has practical and social benefits, but first and foremost, it’s the spiritual answer of the day to the devil of estrangement.

From Adam and Satan to a modern shooter, the pain they feel is estrangement — separation from the divine and from one another. That’s why we go to music festivals and parties and churches—to be with, to be in participation—with each other and our world. Aligning rituals with monuments aligned with the heavens and earth created an existential experience of alignment between the individual and their reality, which is perhaps the most important experience for a human.

More key one liners.

We learned to dance by imitating the dances of reality around us—from the movements of moon to the dance of deer. From these dances and movements came ritual gestures, like the folding of hands when we pray, or spell casting of a dramatic wizard.

Early dance and ritual gestures came from the imitation of nature—from animals and stars to plants and storms. Like folding our hands when we pray, participate in these gestures was to participate in the divine.

Burial chambers and mythic underworlds often look like one another, for example, as in Valhalla, we find a central pillar and hanging sword in the burial mounds we call Kurgans.

entries.question: Humans throughout time have come to believe that the afterlife can only be enjoyed if the rituals around their death and corpse are properly executed.  and what if not?
entries.text:
It’s possible plant medicines were used by those who designed, built and worshipped at megaliths, but it’s also possible that altered and group states of consciousness were achieved through chanting, breathing and dancing.

As ritualistic as it would have been to celebrate in these monuments, we have to recognize how ritualistic and spiritual it would have been to build these time machines.

If these wonders of the world weren’t made by aliens or time travelers, we’ve got to accept that they were only accomplished through the comprehensive participation of an inspired population.

When Edward Leeskalnin built the Coral Castle and Wally Wellington showed how he could move gargantuan stones on his own with the help of pebbles, we learned that it’s possible to create these great monuments if massive groups of people could be mobilized.

Gilgamesh, in his great quest for immortality, lands on the idea that his immortality will be in the story he leaves behind in stone. Megaliths, great monuments of stone, give eternity to all who build them. To participate in the building of an enduring monument is to transcend the limited range of time in which the individual lives.

Brilliant individuals in the last hundred years have shown an ability to move fifteen ton stones and create massive monuments entirely on their own with a combination of basic pulleys, levers and the clever use of pebbles.

In Ancient Mesopotamia, important texts were inscribed in clay and paper because one survives flood and the other survives fire—monuments, can survive both.

entries.question: Where can a story be stored for eternity? The stars! The stones? :D
entries.text:
The Mayan throne is a weaving that tells a story that is itself a weaving of stories — all the stories that culture tells, the story of life and death, the story of the seasons, the crops, ball games and social responsibility. It’s possible that authority and power structures came to centralize around these centralizing monuments.

Saturn or Cronos, the classical lord of time and king of the golden age, could be a memory of leadership during this time of clock building.

Authority and power comes from alignment. To build a Wonder of the World takes such a beautiful and comprehensive push of so many people all working together. This is the miracle of civilization itself.

Today, if you wanted everyone to be all in on a great challenge, like the Moon Shot, you’re going to have to activate the athletes and scientists alike, the students of the sky and the masters of material science. It’s going to take military-like logistics and the excitement of pop culture. It would have been the same then.

Some would have been excited about how it aligned with the stars, others would have been fulfilled by the profound purposing of their masonry skills, their animal training, ability to organize, and capacity to feed. Something so big as a wonder of the world doesn’t get assembled without the inspired participation of basically everyone.

Humbling — these monuments should be humbling, first and foremost. That is what we should feel when we see them. They are the death of arrogance. Anyone who thinks they can explain them fully runs up against something impossible they have to leave out. How were stones moved, how were they cut and placed, and how in the hell do you get the level of mass participation required to build them? If you think they were built w the help of lost powers, technology or aliens, arrogance dies at the threshold of proof. You just can’t get there with certainty. If you think it was done by humans, the disconnect between the actual achievements and the technologies  we know they had during the dates with which we associate the monuments, huge gaps are left or denied.

The Dolmon Chapel in Portugal, which has become a church, shows us how ancient ruins can be integrated into new religions. All over the world, religious sites sit on older religious sites. Megaliths the world over have been integrated into worship that has little to do with the spiritual intentions of their builders. The Aztecs, for example, claim to have moved into an already built city of the gods, where they performed rituals.

entries.question: Megalith builders were maritime people — do we normally think of megalith builders as maritime people? And when we do, is it easier to recognize the brilliant minds behind them as the minds of travelers, exposed to the best and worst of cultures around them?
entries.text:
Monuments sink as the ground level raises around them.

The linear thinking of scholars has blinded our ability to see what’s really going on with these monuments. You’ll hear arguments that it’s about aligning with the stars for religious reasons or aligning with the seasons the the benefit of farmers or even the fertility of mothers. Until we recognize that all of these are relevant, we’ll remain blind. These monuments were the center points for weaving, integrating and participating in reality. This is where they aligned their stories with their worship with their sexuality with their crops with the seasons and the stars. Mayan kings sat on mats on which all the stories of their world were woven. The center and position of leadership is where all the stories weave together, and when you are in that center, when you are in the moments and locations where the lights of the heavens align with your life and your world, you feel at one with the cosmos. And it made everything you did feel one with the cosmos — not just your spiritual practice, but also your ball games and your farming and your love life.

The purpose of funeral rituals are typically to ensure an afterlife. All the work to prepare an individual in Egypt is to ensure they are able to empty their tomb, like Jesus or like Hercules who leaves behind only his empty armor. And so it’s fascinating to find these ancient burial mounds so empty.

The megalithic way of doing things went on for thousands of years. It is a big part of human history in which we were talking major next steps. All of our major next steps were incubated with and in these megaliths. Like a seed that would define a whole society, the core patterns enacted ritually and by the heavenly lights with in the monuments would encode the ways we lived beyond — like going to church on Sundays and for a holiday then being Christian at all other times. You go to take communion and get aligned then go be out and about. Same. They checked into these big religious ceremonies and got aligned with the cosmos and then went about their aligned lives — farming playing loving, all following cultural patterns that were derived from natural patterns

Things the same today

entries.question: So even when monuments arent for burial they can be — when the burial is to the sky — sky burial?
entries.text:
Stone tongue and grooves — masonry and technology — know how

Henge Predates wheel by 500 years — log rolling — proto wheels

In the Brut Chronicle of British history and Arthurian legend, Giants help build Stonehenge with the help of Merlin after the stones were stolen from Ireland.

entries.question: HOW WERE SUCH LARGE STRUCTURES MADE WITHOUT MORTAR?
entries.text:
The lack of mortar with these gargantuan stone walls that fit together so well is awe inspiring and mysterious. The way this was accomplished was through the use of acidic paste in place of mortar. This paste broke effectively melted and broke down the heavy stones so that they fit together so well. This is best understood when we look at the case of the great Incan stone walls. In this case, we see the idea of melting and molding stones in their stories in addition to a ready made acidic paste in their landscape.

Acid melts down stone, and there is evidence of sulfide mining in areas where stone was mined by Incans, and so they would have been exposed to the melting of the rocks. They could then use an acid substance as a paste or mud that’s put on the surfaces so that they melt into one another. Red acid mud was discovered in the area and would have worked. So it’s not that there wasn’t mortar, it’s that the mortar was an acidic paste that molded them together. There is a story of melting down rocks in the Incan stories.

entries.question: Participating in a chanting ritual, what would this have done to a person? Did it affect the brain? Did it affect the body?
entries.text: Prehistoric temples are ancient churches. They are places where people participated in ritual activity, feasting and praying and in communal life itself. Much like we do today.

episodes.title: Curse of King Tut
episodes.summary: For millennia, the strength of the Egyptian state was contingent with the convincing coherence of its myth, which wove Egyptian life into a single tapestry. To teach story structure I teach the...

entries.text: ITV Questions Pharaoh

entries.question: Why are the Egypt pharaoh´s such a great myth?
entries.text: For millennia, the strength of the Egyptian state was contingent with the convincing coherence of its myth, which wove Egyptian life into a single tapestry. To teach story structure I teach the Osiris myth, which modeled the journey of pharaohs, who modeled the journey of sun, season, crop, regime and the lives of Egyptian people, animals and plants—to say the least.

entries.question: What makes especially King Tutankhamun such a famous Pharaoh?
entries.text: Not only was the discovery of King Tut’s tomb and treasure one of the greatest discoveries in modern archeology, King Tut also played one of the most interesting roles in Egyptian history. His father was Akhenaten, who radically transformed the Egyptian religion into a kind of monotheism, which his son was forced to undo by the traditional priesthood.

entries.question: How come the mysterious deaths of the members of Carter’s team and the deaths of some prominent visitors to the tomb became such a famous story?
entries.text: Not only did the high profile financier of the dig, an English noble, die a mysterious death, it was also written about and described as a curse by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, the author of Sherlock Holmes. Some will say it was just a mosquito bite, not a curse; others will suggest such an either-or is reductive.

entries.question: How was the curse of the Pharaoh originated and how did it evolve (culturally)?
entries.text: There were definitely Egyptian curses concerning grave robbery, as seen on walls of pre-Pyramidal tombs in Giza. That having been said, it seems such references weren’t required by performers who made shows of unwrapping mummies and popularized such notions of a curse well before the discovery of Tut. Of course, this is when it exploded – on the back of a huge discovery, mysterious death and the contributions of a famed writer, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. From there it was a runaway. Despite various efforts to debunk the story, it was as big of a hit as anything the author wrote, and now, after countless movies and spinoffs, the myth seems to be going nowhere.

entries.question: Was the curse a great marketing tool for archeologists as well?
entries.text: The curse gave the archaeologists a juicy story without having to relent on giving press access. This didn’t just reduce their disappointment, it excited them more and their audiences even more still.

entries.question: Are tomb curses common in ancient Egypt? If so, at whom were they directed?
entries.text: There were definitely Egyptian curses concerning grave robbery, as seen on walls of pre-Pyramidal tombs in Giza. Shakespeare did the same thing. If you don’t want people messing with your grave, put a curse on your tomb, whether you believe in it or not.

entries.question: Are the curses of the tombs and Tut the result of an increasing Egyptomania in the Western world?
entries.text: Throughout the Victorian world, people were holding unwrapping parties in which they removed relics from the bandages of mummies. It was all the rage! When Tut was found, the Egyptomania exploded, and the curses – we all know the power of a good horror story. We might not like what we see, but we really wanna look. Something about the tiny keyhole through which his treasures were first seen feels like a perfect metaphor. Egypt was far away – spatially, temporally, philosophically and mythically—our view was but through a keyhole

entries.question: Was there really a curse?
entries.text: The average life expectancy of those who were supposedly affected by the curse was actually longer than the average Englishman of the day—that doesn’t sound so bad. And the mysterious death of the financier has been explained by a mosquito bite. So I can’t say there was a curse bringing down these archaeologist. That having been said, I don’t want it gone from my movies!

entries.question: What is special about this saga for you?
entries.text:
Mytholigzation of History: I’m especially interested in the way it shows the mythic mixing of history with divine narratives.  It gives a sense of how this could have been happening behind more ancient myths that are more difficult to compare with their related history. And this isn’t just about how myth is reduced to history, far from it, I’m interested in how history becomes endowed with myth. Arthur gives us another great example, as a historical figure (or five) who became a magnet for mythic material.

On one hand the dueling families represent the dueling mythic pantheons of the Asuras and Devas or Ahuras and Devas or Olympians and Titans... on another, it’s a historic narrative...

Evolution & Time: A story we can see evolve across a large span of space and time. In addition to the three tight waves of the Poetic Edda, Nibelung Saga and Saga of the Volsungs written down between the 10th and 13th century, Wagner carries these stories into the 19th century, which are built on motifs that extend into ancient memory.

Metal: Personally, I’m interested in the mythopoeic expressions of iron-work. For example, the strength of Siegfried’s blade comes from plunging it in blood and his single weakness is the leaf that covered him when he bathed. These details pertain to the tempering of iron, which is strengthened by dipping it in cool water but is weak where held in the process. This is a motif shared with achilles and Sosruquo, in whom the origin is apparent. Not only is he freed from stone and dipped in water by a blacksmith, he is also described as steel and is only vulnerable where held when dipped. This is probably an older story, which is more poeticized by the time we get to Achilles and even more so by the time we get to Siegfried. But though Superman, Iron Man and Wolverine are dressed far differently, these men of steel all carry its core motifs.

Psychologically: The story is certainly interesting from a psychological point of view. If it was a dream, what would be going on in the mind of that dreamer? Jungians are certainly interested in the dragon slaying motif. Some see it as a defeat and subjucation of one’s own inner monster or ego, some see it as the defeat and subjugation of the feminine or earthly principle by masculine solar consciousness. We can certainly see the connection between the dragon faced by Siegfried and the serpents or dragons seen in Eden or blocking the boundary to the Egyptian Underworld.

Warrior Women: One of my interests are mythical warrior women, ever since I had a cruch on Teela from He-Man; and so I’m very interested in the Valkyries and Amazons. One of the most cheaveneistic things I’ve ever heard is that women warriors are masculinized heroes; as though Artemis, Amazan and Brunhilde never were—not Sekhmet or the Maenadic fighters. One of the motifs we see is the ritual fight between Brunhilde and her suitor. This is seen in the story of Atalanta and might date back to a ritual in which men and women litereally met their match. We also see the emphasis on her girdle, like Hippolyta, queen of the Amazons.

In the story, Siegfried actually enters the bedchamber in an invisible form to subdue Brunhilde.

This is reminiscent of the story in which an invisible mesh us used by Hephaestus to capture Aphrodite’s infidelity – a story that Newton saw as a particular copper-iron alloy.

entries.question: Why were myths like the Nibelungenlied often reproduced in verse?
entries.text:
Orally delivered content is much more likely to be delivered in verse, because rhythm and meter support the memory and focus of the storyteller and audience. AND, Verse brings artfulness—it’s like cinematography for words.

Meaning can be embedded in any pattern, including verse. For example, Homeric meter is called dactylic, a word for fingers applied to the deities that elevated Zeus. In this way, you might see meter as the hand of God. Of course this resonates with the Egyptian and New Testament ideas of God’s creation with the word.

entries.question: Siegfried is murdered by Hagen, in the only place on the back that is vulnerable (a leaf has prevented the dragon's blood from making him invulnerable here). What does that remind you of?
entries.text:
The most famous comparison is Achilles, whose weak spot is also where he was dipped when made impervious. Both are later poeticizations of earlier figures that more clearly reveal the steel origins of this motif. Sosruquo, from the Caucasus, is weak in his thighs, where the black smith held him with tongs and tempered him before calling the child steel. In this story, it’s on the surface, and it shows us what’s really going on with Siegfried, Achilles and Jason, who, like Siegfried, baths in a special elixir to become impervious, and like Sosruquo, becomes impervious in the Caucasus mountains. In his case, the magic ingredient comes from a flower that grows at the sunrise, from Prometheus‘ gore, where the Eagle eats his liver. The fire of Prometheus was associated with metallurgy and iron, which appeared in the Caucasus far earlier than almost anywhere else. It was then under the instruction of Hekate that this gift of Prometheus was prepared by Medea for Jason. The impervious skin enables him to withstand fire and defeat dragons. Such association of the impervious skin with dragons is also found in the Caucasus, where the charcoal used to make steel is described as the bones of dragons.

One might ask – how come they kept using tongs to dip steel if they knew about the weak spot? Hilariously enough, they shifted to stories in which the knees wouldn’t fit below the trough of water—as though there was an effort being made to retain the motif of a single weakness despite the technological solution.

The single weakness of the steel heroes is also conflated with the corruption of steel and the heroes through which it’s personified. The single weakness of Achilles becomes the place on the body where he sacriligously injurs Hektor, who he witholds from burial while draging around Troy by his achilles heels. This small corruption of the strongest hero is a mythopoetic expression of steel itself, which is stronger (and more immprtal) as a result of its corruption—carbon. Personified, this is the Anti-Hero, which we also recognize in the Steel Narts, Sosruquo and Batraz, who are simultaneously the strongest heroes and at odds with the divine order.

Purity & Fire The focus on purity, which is required to pass through Brunhiilde’s firewall, is also a motif associated with metal and steel heroes. For centuries, the purity of metals was the path towards their quality if not immortality. This was mythopoeically consistent the religious understanding of self --- that it should be purified to achieve strength and immortality. Such golden boys can be seen all throughout mythology—Gallahad, for example. And among the Narts, their metal is only as strong as their people are courageous, and honest.The quality of the people’s mettle translated into the quality of their metal.  This is what’s going on with Siegfried. However, with the discovery of steel came the discovery of a metal that was lighter, stronger and more immortal when mixed with impurity. This is seen in the personification of this material in the form of heroes who are at once the strongest, but who are also corrupt.

Voices – I love how Siegfried hears the birds and the bees when he tastes the blood of the dragon. It’s like an inversion of the Eden myth, where the ability to speak with the animals is lost as a result of eating the fruit. We see the same thing in the Grimm Fairytalle called White Snake, where a servant of the king gains the power of hearing animals when eating a bit of the king’s secret dish—a white snake. And we get another example of the motif when Fin burns his thumb with oil from a great fish, which gives him wisdom. It’s like a return to the pre-edenic wisdom of Adam, or, even better, a completion of a journey that’s led back to such wisdom. Psychologically, one might suggest that the defeat of one’s inner tyrant or ego, which is focused on consciousness and reason, permits the restoration of one’s relationship with emotion and intuition. Sufi’s mystics believe we should clean the mirrors of our heart – this is consistent with the idea that we have to empty and free ourselves of ego, will or spirit so that something greater than ourselves can come through and be heard. Some see this as what’s going on when Sigfried has defeated the dragon and tasted its blood.

The single weakness is symbolized by the Linden leaf, which represents Freya and is a symbol of truth. Like someone in the golden lasso of Wonderwoman, it’s impossible to tell a lie when under the Linden tree. This connects that weakness back to noble honesty and purity. Siegfried, as a man of steel, is not perfectly honest or without corruption. In fact his fatal flaw involved his lie about sleeping with his friend’s wife, which led to a spear in his weak spot.

entries.question: Can stories like the Nibelungenlied really have a real core?
entries.text:
In the Nibelung, History, myth and metallurgy align around core patterns capable of reflecting more than just historical, mythic or metallurgical meaning. For example, the single weakness of quenched steel becomes the single weakness of a hero’s personality becomes the mythic downfall of a historic culture. The pattern of the single weakness then sustains the projection of whatever flaw concerns its audience.

Myth is like nuclear fusion, it requires the combination of multiple cores to create something new. Is the core of the Nibelungenlied a set of Germanic or older Indo-European motifs? Is it grounded in metallurgy? History? Is it woven around the deep wound of a fallen culture? Is it constructured for the spiritual or psychological training of the audience—like a dream? I find searching for a single core to be perilous if not reductive. History, myth and metallurgy become aligned around core patterns, which support layers of meaning beyond anticipation

Metallurgical core: One of the core inspirations to the Nibelung is metallurgy—from Siegfried’s personification of ancient iron with impervious skin and a single weakness to his magnificent sword and the focus on rings.

Core Wound: The Nibelung revolves around a wound—symbolically, this is the wound of Siegfried’s, but it is also the wound of a fallen culture, which his death portends.

Indo European: An Indo-European core can be recognized in several motifs. The most striking examples involve ancient mating rituals—from competitive matching with warrior women to the way Siegfried pretends to be Gunnar in bed—an act that can be compared with the conception of both Hercules and Arthur.

Psychological: From Jung’s point of view, the defeat of the dragon was the defeat of the inner tyrant that limited the flow of life’s forces. The defeat of the dragon and Sigfried’s new ability to understand nature become seen as outward mythopoeic expressions of an inner transformation—one that inverts the fall of Adam.

Cheauvenism: One of the cores, unfortunately, is a conflation of women with the fall. This is seen in figures that range from Eve and Delilah to Helen, Guinevere and Kriemhild—this is the archetypal woman who is a beautiful and seductive wife who brings a whole world to ruin. This has been one of the more damaging archetypes in human history, and it’s ultimately related to the conflation of the mother with matter, both of which go by Mater in Latin, and which share the root word with Matrix and Matriarchy. This is based on an understanding of the woman as the vessel from which all life is born, like the earth. In this way the mother is a personification of the earth – both fertil wombs and vessels, but also, both matter. Everything comes from the matter of mothers, which comes from the matter of earth. This sets up the story of the spirit’s fall into matter, which recognizes the spirit, like semen, as masculine, and the body, like the womb, as feminine. Thus the religious battle between spirit and body is symbolized as a tension between the masculine reason of spirit and the body’s feminine emotions.

entries.question: Why have we always been so fascinated by myths like the Nibelungenlied?
entries.text:
Freud thought dreams were driven by wish fulfillment. Jung thought they were part of psychological homeostasis, which seeks balance and wholeness. For him, this meant dreams provide compensatory content that counterbalances daily experience and conscious thought. I think it’s both – I think myths and dreams draw us in with the promise of wish fulfillment and then drag us through a process of development.

Joseph Campbell saw myths as spiritual training – I think we get the training from the heroes, who we emulate, and also in the morality of the authorship, which isn’t always aligned with the protagonists. Spiritual training also comes in the form of metaphors and patterns that remain hidden to those focused most on the surface.

I think there’s also something just existentially authoritiative to us about what’s big for all of us – what reaches all of us – just that it’s so significant to so many, it tells us it’s significant and make sus want to understand..

entries.question: Why is the Rhine considered to be mentioned particularly often in myths? Do rivers in myths often play a crucial role?
entries.text: The most ancient cities emerged around rivers, which offered water for crops and routes for trade. We think of The Nile & Egypt, the Indus & Harrappan, the Adonis & Byblos, and of course, the Tigris & Euphrates. The Rhine is no different. By supporting core crops and expanding horizons, rivers have been instrumental to the development of culture and central to the stories they tell.

entries.question: Apparently the Nibelungenlied refers to historical facts. In what way?
entries.text:
Arthur’s defense of Britain, the Iliad, and Genesis concern the fall of regional powers in the context of collapsing world orders. The same can be said of the Nibelung, which is about the fall of the Burgundians, which was contingent with the fall of Rome. This can be seen in the fact that Attila, the Burgundian nemesis, was the reaper of Rome.

In the historical narrative, Attila was killed by his wife, Ildico, whose name influenced Kriemhild, the mythic wife of Attila who kills him in the Nibelung.

entries.text:
“He opposes the dragon like David against Goliath. Achieves something almost impossible ... He defeats the dragon – a personification of evil. And he does it to gain power. "

Siegfried is endowed with the love adoration and powers of a true culture hero. Into him is projected the inner heroism of a nation.

A. Dragon Slayer

B. culture hero

entries.question: Could it be that the old recipe (Schmied Wieland forges a sword made of steel and goose droppings) is correct?
entries.text:
(The theory: nitrogen in bird droppings makes the sword harder)“That's the exciting thing about such myths: the question of what is real - what is fiction. Such detailed recipes often contain real knowledge. Such myths not only dealt with historical events, but also passed on concrete knowledge. Because not everyone could read and write it. And so such myths were also there to convey information about generations. (Or similar) "

Myths as Recipes – Newton, Magic Mushroom Tea, Wine Making Process, etc.

When Nitrogen is added to steel, it can improve strength, reduce its corrosiveness and increase its durability. There’s a lot of nitrate in goose poop, so if it was mixed with powdered metals that were then melted down, it could create some good iron.

That having been said, my tendency is to see the goose poop as just as an alchemical symbol. The goose, often conflated with the swan, is believed to have layed the cosmic egg, and it’s from the goose egg that came Helen and her siblings. The goose is also a symbol of the sun. And so I can’t be sure that the droppings of the goose don’t relate to a symbol of something else, perhaps even something that, like goose poop, falls from the sky. This brings us back to the metal we’re talking about – steel – which falls from the sky as a meteorite.

entries.question: Why do powerful swords always play such a big role in legends? And why has Siegfried been credited with such a wonderful sword?
entries.text:
Swords are incredible symbols – the first long swords were made of iron, and the first iron was made of meteorites – so the first sword is a meteor sword, which colors its symbol forever. In that the sword is made of a light from heaven, it’s often associated with the divine right of rule—as seen in the Arthur myth. In that the sword is a death bringer made of a fallen light, the fiery sword can also represent the fall—as seen in the Eden myth. In that it cuts, it can be associated with knowledge. The same can be said of fire, which is symbolized by the triangle, or blade, even still. The word Science comes from a root word that means to cut or divide, which highlights the notion of knowledge as discerning. At the same time, to cut is to divide into two, which highlights a dualistic vision of knowledge. In the Tibetan and Jedi tradition, the flaming sword is the instrument used to cut oneself free of attachment and ignorance.

GRAIL SWORD - The great sword of Sigurd is Gram, which shares the same prefix as the grail, as grain grapes and grass.

The sword is retrieved in a manner similar to that of Excalibur. When Odin thrusts it into a tree, he declares that it will belong to who can retrieve it. This related to an old Indo-European ritual in which the sword of the deceased hung on the central pillar of the kurgan burial mound; it also relates to the old motif of retrieving the father’s weaponry from a tomb-like basement—sometimes even a dead horse. In the case of Sigfried, like Arthur, Theseus and the Nart heroes, he inherits the sword from his father.

The sword of his father, however, like the sword destine for Aragorn, has been split in two. But when it is remade, when Sigfried learns how to work the forge, it is restored to its great strength. Not only can it cut an anvil in half, it’s so strong, it can also cut floating wool, it’s so sharp.

As with the sword of Atilla and Arthur, the sword of Siegfied vanishes with him.

The sword is used as a symbol of chastity when laid between Siegfried and Brunhild, which is afotif that repeats throughout Arthurian legend.

entries.question: Why do treasures like the Nibelung treasure keep appearing in myths?
entries.text:
So long as there’s treasure in the imagination there will be treasure in myth. As long as we treasure something, even if it’s something immaterial like love, it will be symbolized as real treasure—like the grail, fleece or pot of gold.

Oh and… there’s a lot of real treasure in the world – tons of raids, tons of hoards. Gold is found in recovered tombs and shipwrecks all the time. And money’s a thang, people want treasure – we buy lottery tickets and move our whole loves to rush for gold. Telling stories about it is all but a given. But because we so frequently see treasure corrupt the people who pursue it, we end up with cautionary tales—from Tolkien’s notion of Dragon Sickness to the Ballad of Buster Skruggs. It’s a running motif in Family Guy – The poop made of treasure corrupts.

Insofar as wealth is power and power corrupts, wealth corrupts.

It’s not just that some people want to go pursue treasure, it’s that all of us can dream of it. It’s a dream we’re always renewing.

entries.question: Could the Nibelung treasure still be out there somewhere?
entries.text:
In there, out there, I bet it can be found. There’s a spot you can stand in Roslyn Chapel from which they say you can see where the grail is, and one of the obvious statements is that it’s in you. The best treasure is within.

Of course some people believe it was found in 2014 – objects found with a metal detector and dated to around 400 AD, which is the historical period of the Sagas.

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/10653180/Has-Richard-Wagners-mythical-Nibelung-treasure-been-found.html

The pathway of the Rhine has changed over the years,

Troy, just a myth for millennia before the historical period associated with the Nibelung, was found, treasure included. If there’s a historical thread beneath the Nibelung treasure, then it would seem more a matter of when than if.

entries.question: Is the Nibelungenlied a typically German story?
entries.text: "The legend is THE German national epic. Siegfried is considered the typical German hero. Etc.

entries.question: ?? How does a story become a national epic? "
entries.text:
The Nibelungenlied is a typically Indo-European story.

The conflict and fall of divine families can be seen from Vedic India and Persia to Greece and Rome – all of which spoke Indo-European languages, like the Germans. The Nazis wanted to see themselves as the direct descendants and inheritors of this language and culture group, which it wanted to see as racial; but the Indo-European language cannot be pinned to a single race, and the Germans are no more the inheritors of that tradition than any of the others. They aren’t the oldest wave of Indo-Europeans to hit Europe, and they aren’t the youngest. Either way, many of the European motifs seen as Celtic, Classical, Norse or Germanic are more fairly classified as Indo-European. For example, as John Colarusso points out, the hanging of Odin’s sword on the central pillar of Valhalla mimes the hanging of the sword on the central column of the Indo-European Kurgan or Burial Mound, which is to say, this Norse myth carries a memory of the much earlier Indo Europeans.

Similarly, the swords of Batraz, Arthur and Atilla are all returned to water when they die. This motif pertains to metallurgical breakthroughs of early Indo Europeans.

John Colarusso has argued that the more direct continuation of Indo-European culture can be seen near their homeland in the Caucasus, where horse-riding and pastoral lifestyles were maintained.

entries.question: A hero who defeats a dragon, a camouflage cap that makes you invisible, a dwarf, a wonder sword - where do these motives come from?
entries.text:
invisibility cap also seen associated with Hades and given to the hero Perseus and is associated with Hermes. It has to do with the invisibility of the dead and the lack of visibility in the night, which is intuitively understood anywhere. Death and darkness, death and night—these are aligned in myths just about everywhere.

Is it as simple as the fact that fighter pilots have to be short and that dwarves made good miners? Or that dwarves were lumped in with the one-eyed and injured who were of more value making armor than wearing it? There are always literal layers… but then there’s also the way these images play in dreams while miming patterns beyond belief. For Freud, the little man represents the penis, which enters the mother’s cave. If you’re reductive, you pick one answer. If you’re honest about how the imagination of artists and audiences work, you realize that the more answers there are, the further these stories go. The dwarf is also associated with the little man in your head—ever done enough drugs to see him in there choosing between the thousands of thoughts you ignored for this one? We saw the image in Men in Black and across the Enlightenment. Thousand Frames – Dwarf of a thousand frames. If you’re an alchemist, the dwarf represents the homunculus or little self, which either symbolizes the self on which you work while creating the philosophers stone or is some actual literal little creature—think the Golum. You see this image in Jodorowsky’s Holy Mountain. If you worship Shiva, then you see the dwarf beneath his dancing feet as a symbol of his own conquered ignorance – the ignorance of the little grubby egoic self that tries to pull the levers and mine for gold… We could go on. On one level it’s key to see how the various expressions of the image resonate and relate to one another; on another, it’s essential to wake up from hypnotic projections of such myths onto real people. It’s not fair or kind. The same can be said of the way caucasians project their own shadow on the dark skin of others.

Dwarf as opposite of giants, giants as mountains and elements, dwarves as us – the little crafty ones who can outsmart and outcraft the titans of nature or industry or government or religion. Dwarves are the little guy or underdog and those fighting against tyrant – see Bilbo or Willow. In this way, they’re also associated with Children, who look up at the big unknown world of giants.

For Nietzsche, all the things society thinks thou shalt do have been accumulating as scales on the dragon, Holdfast. The Ubermench is the hero who sees that the status quo is managed by the tyranny of this dragon, thou shalt, which he slays.

For Tolkien, the Dragon was also a tyrant, and more specifically a hoarder. The dragon bursting forth from the mountain with fire in the Hobbit is aligned with the eruption of Mount Doom in Lord of the Rings. Both climax with the eruption and flow of a mountain – both are concerned with overcoming the desire to hoard and keep wealth and power – this is the tyrants impulse, which is represented by the Dragon and its gold as well as the Mayor and his wealth. The flow of wealth from the mountain and the eruption of the volcano are both representations of the Tyrant’s violent defeat and the subsequent restoration of life’s healthy flow. In this way, his notion of the Dragon’s defeat is not particularly different than Nietzche’s or Jung’s. In all cases, the Dragon is seen as that which is hoarding the flow of life in a tyrannical way, which becomes associated with the self-centered nature of the ego, which seeks the role of tyrant within the psyche.

Sets the Mythical fall of the Gods during the Historic Fall of Rome and within the fall of a specific family.

entries.text:
“The Scandinavian sources show how incredibly popular the saga of the dragon slayer must have been throughout Europe at the time.

From the Rhine to Scandanavia, the Poetic Eddas, Volsung Saga and the Nibelung—not to mention the pervasive artistic references—all point to a period during which the story was extremely well known.

Meanwhile, the myth of the dragons layer can be seen even further afield – Zeus and Hercules to Saint George.

CURIOUS ABOUT: “Around 800, the preserved memorial books from monasteries document that nobles in the Worms area and in Bavaria were strikingly often called “Siegfried”, “Hagen” or “Kriemhild”. Apparently it was a story that has been told everywhere. "

JAVELIN – the use of a javelin to kill Siegfied is like Perceval’s use of a Javeline to kill the red knight, or the Jedi’s use of a blaster – all were looked down upon as dishonerable. entries.text: The secret of the Fourth Pyramid

The Egyptian pyramids have fascinated and attracted us humans for thousands of years. But only three pyramids in Giza are known, they belong to father, son and grandson. Built by the 4th dynasty of pharaohs by the kings Cheops, Chefren and Mykerinos (2590 - 2470 BC).  There is said to have been a fourth pyramid in Abu Rawash, about 8 km north of Giza, which dwarfed all the other structures. Built by a pharaoh Djedefre, also called Radjedef. Many mysteries surround this pharaoh. This much is certain: he was a son of Cheops. But why did he build his pyramid so far away from his family?

entries.question: Drive to Abu Rawash - What lies hidden here?
entries.text:
In 1995, in a spectacular excavation, the Egyptologist Vallogia was the first to decipher the buried tomb of the pharaoh Djedefres, thus confirming the theory that a pyramid stood here.

He wanted to build bigger and be closer to the sun.  From Abu Rawash, one can look down on Giza. Since Djedefre built on a mountain, his pyramidion was 20 metres higher than that of Giza. Djedefre used the logistically good building site to be able to build as high as possible in the shortest possible time.  On the east side of the pyramid, Chris discovers a kind of ramp, which presumably leads to the underground burial shaft. This must have been the sarcophagus of the pharaoh Djedefre.

The burial chamber was now again built underground, as in the pyramids of the 3rd Dynasty. It seems that Djedefre was a real pragmatist.

entries.question: Was the pyramid willfully destroyed by its own family? Was there a family dispute?
entries.text:
A ship's barge, discovered by coincidence in 1954, could provide definitive information about the family construction. Experts speak of one of the largest and oldest organic artefacts made of wood in the history of mankind. When the ship was found, archaeologists found several ceiling stones engraved with the name of the pharaoh Djedefre.  This clearly proves that Djedefre was responsible for his father's burial. The theory that his family deliberately destroyed his pyramid is therefore unlikely.

William Linn - Mythologist

entries.question: But where did the pyramid disappear to?
entries.text: There is the historical mystery about where all the stone went, and then there’s the mythic narrative that comes through. This is the story of a hubristic rise and humbling fall: the story of a Pharoah who declares himself the son of god while building a ladder to heaven, which, like the Tower of Babel, came down.

entries.question: Why did the Egyptians build in pyramid form?
entries.text:
Pyramids inherit the mythological qualities of holy mountains, where above meets below. In the case of the pyramids we are specifically looking at Ra’s light beams from above meeting Egypt below. this also represents the descending of Ra’s authority to the pharoah, who rules in his name. And so we see the rise of pyramids in Egypt concur with the rise of emphasis on Ra and Pharaohs who identify as his sons.

The Egyptian perception of sunbeams as Piramidal can be seen in the extended arms of aten that reach down in triangular form from the sun and in the pyramid itself, who’s Kapstone was associated with the sun at its zenith.

Mount Hermon is where the Angels come down to mate with humans. Mt. Sinai is where God came to give Moses his word. Zeus and Indra are atop their mountains, and Pharoahs build pyramids.

The Cosmic Mountain wasn’t just a place over there, it was once a symbol for all of existence. Falling from Eden wasn’t about falling from some random mountain, it was about falling from the center and top of existence. The mountain is a symbol of existence itself. The top is where God creates the first humans and communes with them—whether it’s Eden or Sinai. This is where the tree of life sprouts and where Angels mate with humans.

The core existential question is and always has been if and how we can participate meaningfully in existence. For as long as we can remember, this existential need has produced efforts to align the individual and society with nature and cosmos. The individual wants to participate in our universal drama in meaningful ways. The alignment of monuments with stars and seasons is common around the world, but the first and most foundational metaphor is the mountain or tree, which represent the union of above with below.

entries.question: Why was the path to the burial chamber built at an angle of 27 degrees?
entries.text:
The path of the burial chamber is built at an angle of 27° to point at the pole star, which the Egyptians associated with rebirth — why? It’s the center around which our sky revolves, the one fixed spot in all of human experience, which sometimes appears in myth as the unmovable spot or center of reality. In the case of the Egyptian‘s, this was also recognized as the top most point of the cosmos. So when the djed pillar provides a ladder to heaven, it’s to the polestar, and it’s constellation, the adze, which For the Egyptians was an opener of the way for seed and soul.

(Images: Seth poking the way through up office with a was scepter, An ads being used to till the earth. A image of the opening of the mouth ceremony, one with the was scepter. An image of the was constellation.)

What’s interesting about this of course is that the Djed pillar is a representation of Osiris . So the pyramid becomes the jet pillar to the top of the sky, which is seen in the pole star. What then is the constellation that the pole star is in? At one point in Egypt it was the leg of Seth, and later, it became the adze of Seth. The ads is what we use to cut through things and it was used ceremonially to open the mouth of the pharaoh for the soul to re-enter the body. And so we see this ad in the sky cutting a hole for the soul to climb through, and we see the chamber in the pyramid pointing the soul directly to that point.

The pole star is the only spot in all of existence that, from our perspective, isn’t moving. In the story of the Buddha, this is called, the immovable spot. It is the center of existence, and it is where Siddartha sits when he sits beneath the world tree. The world tree, like the Djed pillar and Acacia tree in Ancient Egypt, is a bridge from below to above. When Osiris is reborn from the Acacia tree, he is reborn through the Djed pillar, which is the Egyptian ladder to heaven. The ladder to heaven, like the tree of life, is teathered to the immovable spot. This is where the chambers of the pyramid are pointing. This is what they are aligning with. They are aligning with the point to which we climb when we climb the ladder to Heaven. This is the alignment of the Djed pillar.

The pole star is the immovable spot in our reality. Everything else moves. Not the pole star, which is the center.

For the Egyptians, the pole star was part of a constellation called the Adze, which was previously known as the leg of Seth. The Adze is a cutting instrument, which can be seen cutting its way through our cosmic ceiling. But why the Leg? The leg of Seth was later replaced with a ceremonial Adze known as the Was scepter, a symbol of Seth. Both were used in what was called the opening of the mouth ceremony, which is when the Ba Soul, which has journeyed through the netherworld, returns to the body. There is no more integral moment to the Egyptian hope for life eternal. Interesting to see the instrument associated with our pole star, as though the depositing of the Ba soul is through the top of our existence. This was associated with the primary role of the Adze, which was to dig a way for seeds to be deposited in the earth.

We see Osiris with three instruments in his hand — a was scepter, djed pillar and Akh. These three symbols are keys to the reincarnation process. Where the Akh, like the cross, symbolizes resurrection, the Was symbolizes the ability to penetrate into another reality, and the Djed is a ladder to heaven. The ladder to heaven might be seen as pointing towards the pole star, the top of our reality, where we find a constellation they knew as the adze, or was.

entries.question: What is the significance of the sun god in ancient Egypt?
entries.text:
In the same way a divine monarch of europe derives authority from a Christian god, a pharaoh derives authority from the sun god Ra, who governs the living day and guides our souls  through night and death. These roles are conferred on his son Osiris who the Pharoah becomes when he or she dies And who confers them again to Horace the next Pharoah. That the lineage of the Pharoah points back to ra and the suns authority was absolutely imperative.

Djedefre was the first Pharoah to declare himself the son of Ra, which the Pharoahs continued for thousands of years until even their conqueror, Alexander the Great, was received as Ra’s Son. As the lord of daily and annual rhythms, the sun presents an image of governance, leadership and stability. These are qualities with which monarchs have identified all over the world and for as long as we can remember. The sun, however, doesn’t just govern the day, it journeys through night and promises a new sunrise. This is what we see in the Pyramid texts, the journey of Pharoahs, in the form of Osiris, from sunset to sunrise, from death to rebirth; and in this journey we don’t just see the resurrection of an individual, we see the annual return of Nile floods and the life they bring, we see the cyclical defeat of occupying invaders, and we see the eternal renewal of Egypt itself.

Djedefre became seen as the son of Ra when he gave rise to a tradition that lasted thousands of years and would be emulated by Alexander the Great, when he declared himself Pharoah and the son of God.

As the Egyptians shifted away from Pyramids, they began making tombs in mountains. This is for the same reason the fourth pyramid was likely built on a mountain — because the core symbolism was inspired by the mountain.

This shape is still definitive for us today as the pattern for capitalism, monotheism and monarchy.

This structure is then saturated by amplifications that include the triangular shape of refracted sunbeams and build on the symbolic heritage of the holy mountain as where above meets below.

“I am he of the Djed pillar,” says Osiris, as he enters the underworld, says the dead Pharoah, as he takes on the role of Osiris. The Djed pillar is Osiris’ ladder to heaven and forerunner of the pyramid.

Like Holy Mountains and Tree tops, the root metaphor of a pyramid comes from the fact that it rises to the heavens, for which reason, like the older symbolism of mountains and trees, pyramids present the meeting of heaven and earth. Eden, Zeus and the Ten Commandments — all on mountain tops.

Mountain and Treetops appear in the mythological records as places where human and divine — above and below — converge. In Egypt, the archetypal qualities of the divine mountain become seen in the Pyramid, and the qualities of the tree are seen in what they call the Djed pillar, “I am of the Djed pillar,” says the pharoah who dies and becomes Osiris.

entries.text:
Pyramids build on the symbolism of holy mountains. So when Djedefre literally built his pyramid on a Mountain, He didn’t just save time, he also assimilated the meaning that was already associated with the local high point —like building a church from a pagan temple he repurposed what was already there.

the  did it for the same reason new temples are built on top of old temples — to assimilate what was already there. No example is more clear than a mountain made into a pyramid — this is one holy high point becoming another.

entries.question: Horned serpent as dragon - solar ram atop river?
entries.text:
As the Egyptian shifted away from Pyramids, they began making tombs in mountains. This is for the same reason the fourth pyramid was built on a mountain — because the core symbolism was inspired by the mountain.

When the pharoah dies, he becomes Osiris, son of the sun god who personified the djed pillar, a tree or ladder to heaven. To build a pyramid was to build Osiris’ ladder to heaven—the Pharoah’s ladder to Ra.

If the pyramid complex at Giza is anything like other monuments and holy cities from around the world, the story of one pharoah independently deciding what to do with his pyramid doesn’t fit. Instead, it would be more like each Pharoah was participating in a multigenerational plan, and it seemed he may have drawn the short straw — it seems he was the one asked to make a pyramid that represented something different than the others, for which reason it was distanced and made dark.

ALIGNMENT: All over the world, monuments are modeled and aligned with the heavens — this has to do with the core spiritual or existential need to transcend the daily experience estrangement from everything else. We want to experience oneness with the heavens, with the earth, with humanity, with the divine and our lovers. The pyramids are fundamentally motivated by this desire to meet the heavens and become one with divinity. This is not an exercise in individualism. The prideful attempt of the individual to reach and declare oneself god is what results in the fall of Satan, Adam and the Tower of Babel. Islam, means submission. The way to become one with god is not to rebel, it is to make below as it is above — to model reality after the heavens, which is fundamental to all megaliths. So when the pharoahs start building pyramids and calling themselves the son of god, are we looking at a narrative of Hubris? Or is this a misunderstanding. Is it possible that the pyramids were built following a design inspired by the heavens? This would take us to the idea that the pyramids are actually inspired by Orion’s Belt, which would make sense, because Orion was known as Osiris to the Egyptians, and when the king died, they became Osiris. So it’s not just that we see the perfect alignment of the stars and their brightness, it’s that it’s the right constellation to be aligning. But then what of the fourth pyramid? Does it blow that theory? No, this would be an oversimplification of the sky to the stars. The sky also tells the story of storms, and if we look at the great pyramids of the americas, we see a clarifying parallel. Distant from the great pyramid of the sun, built atop a higher mountain, is the temple of the moon, which is dedicated to the storm god. Similarly, the fourth pyramid was built atop a higher mountain at a bit of a distance, and, it wasn’t made to shine like the sun. It was covered in dark materials. Could this have been a temple of moon or storm? And if so, why Djedefre? The answer may be in his name. The EF in Djedefre is symbolized by a horned serpent. With the american pyramids, it’s the horned serpent who brings wind and rain. The same is true in china, where their dragons are horned serpents who bring storms. For the Egyptians, storms were associated with the desert, where the horned serpents can be found — both were imagined at a safe distance from daily life. This is to say, the layout of Giza would match the layout of the great Mexican pyramids if we can recognize the dark-distant pyramid built as relating to storms. Not only would this be consistent with the way the Egyptians imagined the layout of their world, it is also supported by the appearance of the horned serpent in Djedefre’s name, which is associated with storms around the world and in other pyramid complexes.
