entries.text: The tomb of Alexander the Great

Alexander the Great is the most famous stratelates of all time. The location of his tomb remains a mystery to this day. Since the 19th century, over a hundred official attempts have been made to determine the location of Alexander's tomb. Alexander the Great had a short life, yet he achieved immortal fame. He changed the world with his conquering campaigns. He ushered in the age of Hellenism. This era continues to have an impact to this day. And so hundreds of researchers have been hunting for countless years for clues to the final resting place of probably the greatest conqueror of all time. Will it ever be found? Archaeologists, researchers and other discoverers dare to hope. One thing is certain, however: if the tomb of Alexander the Great is ever found, it would in any case be the greatest archaeological discovery of our time. Also for author and Alexander-expert Andrew Chugg.

He is discussing events after Alexander's death, the initial entombment at Memphis, the transfer to Alexandria, the appearance and location of the tomb in Alexandria and giving the idea of the theory that Alexander's remains may have been passed off as those of St Mark in the 4th century AD and are now kept in Venice in the Basilica of St Mark.

Alexanders former general Ptolemy may have overtaken the catafalque and escorted it to Memphis. It now appears likely that Ptolemy adapted a vacant tomb that had been prepared by and for the last native Pharaoh of Egypt, Nectanebo II. However, this Pharaoh had fled south to Ethiopia, when Egypt had been invaded by the Persians in 343BC, so he never had the opportunity to occupy his tomb. The site of the prospective tomb was a chapel within the temple complex of the Serapeum in the cemetery area of ancient Memphis at Saqqara. The Serapeum complex was rediscovered by Auguste Mariette in 1850-1851. Guarding the entrance to the chapel of Nectanebo II, Mariette discovered an incongruous semicircle of life-size Greek statues of poets and philosophers. Some of them can be identified, including Pindar, whose house and descendants Alexander had saved at Thebes, Homer, who was Alexander's favourite poet, and Plato, who had been the mentor of Alexander's tutor, Aristotle. Could these statues have been erected to honour Alexander's tomb? Could Saqqara be the first burial place of Alexander the Great? And would Ptolemy adapt the vacant tomb of Nectanebo II?

Napoleon's expedition to Egypt in 1798 discovered an ancient Egyptian sarcophagus in a chapel in the courtyard of the Attarine Mosque in Alexandria. The local people asserted that this was the tomb of Alexander the Great. When hieroglyphics were deciphered, it was realised that this sarcophagus was inscribed as the royal sarcophagus of Nectanebo. Furthermore, it is known that Alexander's tomb was moved from Memphis to Alexandria by Ptolemy's son, Philadelphus. So does this explain why the sarcophagus turned up in Alexandria and is it a proof that Alexander the Great was first buried in the sarcophaguses of Nectanebo II? But the sarcophagus was empty so there should have been a new location of Alexanders tomb. There are some several ancient references mention that the Soma Mausoleum lay at the centre of the ancient city in a district named after Alexander where two grandly colonnaded streets intersected at right angles. Referring to the map of Mahmoud Bey the indications of the Greek scholars lead to exactly one place: the Shallalat Gardens. One small section of the medieval walls survives today in the Shallalat Gardens of modern Alexandria. Could this be a part of the enclosure of the Soma? And where is the body nowadays?

entries.question: Is the tomb in Greece after all?
entries.text:
The Greeks have proclaimed the discovery of Alexander's tomb several times in recent decades. Two years after Alexander's death, the body was actually supposed to be transferred to Macedonia. At that time, Ptolemy attacked the funeral procession and had the mummy brought to Memphis. So the tradition goes, but what if the dead body was brought home after all? One current archaeological find in Greece in particular have caused a stir in the past in this context. In 2014, experts discovered another burial mound in Greece. The complex with a circumference of 500 metres is located not far from the ancient city of Amphipolis. Amphipolis was an important city of the Macedonian Empire under Alexander the Great. This is one of the reasons why scientists speculate whether the tomb of Alexander, his mother Olympias or his wife Roxanne could be found in the complex.

At the same time Andrew Chugg has made a new suggestion regarding the current whereabouts of Alexander's corpse. Only one existing ancient, mummified corpse is known to have appeared in central Alexandria at the end of the 4th century AD, just when Christianity triumphed over the pagan religions in the city, and Alexander's body mysteriously disappeared. This was the set of human remains which was said by the Alexandrian church to be the corpse of St Mark the Evangelist, the founder of Christianity in Alexandria. It happens that this same corpse was subsequently taken from Alexandria after the city had fallen under Arab rule. In AD828 two merchant-captains smuggled the richly perfumed mummy past the Alexandrian port officials and sailed back with it to their native city of Venice. For centuries it lay in a tomb in the crypt beneath the church built to house it by the Venetians, the Basilica of St Mark. But instead of the saint's bones, the Venetians could have got hold of Alexander's mummy. After all, one embalmed person looks like another. Is it actually possible that traders at the time were smuggling into Venice not the mummy of St Mark, but that of Alexander the Great. The Macedonian king buried in Venice's St Mark's Basilica, hidden from the eyes of the world for centuries? Has Andrew Chugg solved the mystery? Is the tomb of the Macedonian ruler neither in Egypt nor in Greece? At least the Greeks would vehemently deny this theory. After all, Alexander's tomb is an important aspect of identity for them in terms of the country's national self-image.

entries.question: Why does even the corpse still exude such fascination? Especially on subsequent primarily Roman rulers like Caesar?
entries.text:
Alexander was the mark against which Caesar and the Roman emperors measured themselves. He was an example for Roman conquorers just like his empire was an example for Rome.

When Caesar allied with cleopatra, the tomb of Alexander came under the patronage of Rome, and Caesar, who immitated  Alexander and would have seen the Roman acquisition of his divine body as a right to rule as well as evidence that his own conquest had been a continuation of the great legacy Alexander left behind.

The Vatican’s authority over the Christian world has to do with the belief that it was built on St. Peter’s tomb. Similarly, Alexandria’s leadership of the Alexandrian world had to do with the presence of Alexander’s tomb. If we start where we’re born and end where we’re buried, the tomb of a great leader is representative of where they left off, and the point from which the story continues.

entries.question: Where did the idea of Alexander's divinity come from?
entries.text:
There are several contenders for the divine source of Alexander’s conception. Firstly, we learn that his mother, Olympias, met Philip at a Kabeiroi ritual, which may have been an orgy, not unlike the orgies of Dionysus, who she is known to have worshipped.

Arthur, Hercules, , Christ, Alexander — according to myth, they were all conceived by a great father who came to their mother before she was known by her husband. It’s a major motif from myth that shows up in the story of Alexander.

episodes.title: Cleopatra's Legacy
episodes.summary: Cleopatra the 7th; once the most powerful woman on earth, today, one of the greatest mysteries of mankind. Her story is one of beauty, political manipulation and love. But her story is also ancient....

entries.text: Synopsis and Structure

Cleopatra the 7th; once the most powerful woman on earth, today, one of the greatest mysteries of mankind. Her story is one of beauty, political manipulation and love. But her story is also ancient. In this documentary, we will reveal the latest archaeological findings to relive historical truths. Making out her family, her home, her political motifs, or even her final resting place, we might get a glimpse of an idea of the real Cleopatra: was she merely the naive mistress of Julius Caesar and Mark Antony or Rome’s most threatening enemy? Who was the famous Cleopatra?

Power. Love. Death. Cleopatra's myth is a drama in five acts. It has everything: seduction, political intrigue and a heroine who will die for love. The Artists of the last two millennia are inspired by her story and turn the last Egyptian ruler into an icon. Many legends entwine around her. Only some of them are true. Historian and author Christoph Schäfer studies the historical Cleopatra. What we know about her is fragmented. Literary sources give us a legend. But are these sources legit?

As her predecessors did, Cleopatra rules from Alexandria – a magnificent ancient city, full of luxury and Intellectuals. Today, this city is either built upon or sunken into the Harbor. However, thanks to the rather young field of Underwater Archaeology, divers discover the long-lost remains of the Ancient city. Self-claimed Archaeologist Kathleen Martinez and Underwater Archaeologist Emad Khalil discuss recent discoveries in the Harbor. If there were any 2000-year-old tombs here, they are now gone for good. But Kathleen has another theory. What if Cleopatras tomb was not hidden in Alexandria?

Cleopatra stands for beauty, exoticism and dangerous calculation. A femme fatale who becomes the undoing of not one, but two Roman leaders: Julius Caesar and later Mark Antony. Both maintained an intimate relationship with her. Both were doomed to fail. Literary sources are important, but without historical evidence, 2000-year-old documents, a story remains only a story. Papyrus, coins and letters make a legend become real. What do these documents tell us about the real Cleopatra?

As Kathleen Martinez’ excavation goes on, she uncovers proof that this temple was an Isis temple. An important clue, because Cleopatra claims herself to be the reincarnation of Isis. A goddess herself. But could she be buried at Taposiris Magna? 500 Meters from the temple walls, the team uncovers a large Necropolis. They find the remains of around 400 skeletons, most recent discovery a mummy and an offering table. It’s another clue: Only important and rich people were to be mummified. And all these tombs are from the time of Cleopatra. Does this Necropolis indicate the existence of an unopened tomb of the last ruler of Egypt?

The past 2000 years, painters and sculptors show many faces of Cleopatra. Each one clearly influenced by its time and ideology. However, there are portraits of Cleopatra dated back to her time. Many heads of stone and marble are believed to be resembling the queen quite nicely. Scientifically, though, heads are identified by Coins. And only two heads are confirmed to be the confirmed resemblance of the coins. One of them is displayed in the Old Museum in Berlin. Is this the real face of Cleopatra?

How much truth is there in portraits? Police profiling phantom sketch artist Liane Bellmann is trained in sketching not her own fantasy, but detailed descriptions of people’s faces. Today, she will be sketching one and the same person, but with two different descriptions. One given by the model herself and the other given by a total stranger. Although the self-description should be rather different, it turns out: both sketches emphasize the same prominent features. The model and the stranger have independently described the features that stick to the head. Both sketches look quite different, but none of them looks like the original.

It could be the same with Cleopatra’s bust. Certainly, the queen did not model in person. We do not know how ancient sculptors came to the features for Cleopatras face, but one thing seems to be quite clear: Certain features of her face seemed to have been eye-catching enough to be repeatedly noticed, retold and reproduced over and over.

Whether of much beauty or not, Cleopatra made an impression. Its how she befriends Caesar. And it is Caesar who paves her way back to the throne of Egypt. After the civil war of Alexandria her brother and husband king Ptolemy 13th is being killed and her sister displayed in Caesars Triumph. At the end of the 19th century scientists find a skeleton in Ephesos, Turkey. Thanks to Radiocarbon dating, scientists can date the age of the bones to the time of Cleopatra. Martin Steskal suspects this to be Cleopatras sister Arsinoe 4th. “I believe Caesar kept her as a Cleopatra substitute, just in case she does not function as he wants her to”. But who killed her?

Cleopatras family was the Ptolemy’s.  Their family loyalty means everything, but nothing. Her line of Ancestors was secured from strangers, but within the family, there were killings and incest. If this is the sister of Cleopatra, she was most certainly killed by the order of Cleopatra, because she, as the last living family member, threatened her throne.

Cleopatra was a mother of four, but none of the children were children from her brother. Here she breaks the family tradition and positions herself as an untypical queen and woman. Especially in Rome, this makes her a target. Just like Caesar. When Caesar is murdered in 44BC, Cleopatra needs a new ally: Marcus Antonius. Their relationship is displayed in art and drama since Shakespeare’s “Antony and Cleopatra”. People love this story. Rome not so much. Octavian, Caesars official heir to the Roman Empire, declares war to Egypt and Antony. He challenges them at Actium and wins the sea battle. But is this really what happened? Christoph Schäfer and Konstantin Zachos doubt certain facts in Octavian’s memoirs. This combat has something else to it.

After the battle of Actium, Kleopatra and Antony were alone. There was no legion left wanting to fight for them. Both accepted to have lost. Both killed themselves. Kathleen Martinez still searches for clues to a tomb. She digs through her 17th tunnel. 8m underground, leading towards the sea in the north and towards the south, under the temple. Why there was a tunnel system underneath the temple is still a mystery. But Kathleen Martinez strongly believes to soon be finding a secret here. And she hopes it to be the lost tomb of Cleopatra the seventh. The Queen whose life and rule became one of the greatest mysteries in history.

entries.question: Isis – Why to look at Isis to understand Cleopatra?
entries.text: To understand Cleopatra, we have to understand the goddess with whom she identified—Isis, who, as a Greek, she recognized as Aphrodite, and who, as a Roman, Caesar knew as the consort of Mars, Venus, the goddess coupled with Caesar in the War God’s temple.

entries.question: How as Cleopatra like Isis?
entries.text:
From Isis and Aphrodite to Inanna and Astarte, the mythic goddesses of Venus have been archetypal expressions of feminine power, and Cleopatra was Venus incarnate.

Venus: Star light, star bright, the first star I see tonight…is always Venus. Greeks associated her with Aphrodite and the Phoenicians with Astarte, all of which were seen in Venus. Like Cleopatra, these goddesses personified the epitome of feminine power.

Cleopatra personified the epitome of feminine power like all the goddesses of Venus.

When Isis restores the first spark of life in the dead corpse of her husband Osiris, it’s concurrent with her own conception of his son Horus, which depends on the wooden penis she’s made to replace her husband. So when Cleopatra filled gords with bees for for her pleasure, she became an incarnation of Isis.

Like the fairy that awakens Pinocchio with a spark from her magic wand, the first spark of Osiris’ resurrection is delivered by a wooden phallus invented by Isis. So when Cleopatra is credited for inventing the vibrator, everyone in Egypt saw Isis. This recurring motif of the wand and life-spark concerns the mystery of life itself, a secret kept by Isis in the quiet of her cosmic womb, the source of all life.

Mother of Divine Child:

like Isis, her goal was to bare a divine child that would lead a new world order, which is exactly what would have happened had she been able to clear a path for her son with Ceasar, Caesarian. Had she succeeded, her people would not have been subdued by an invading force, which they would have associated with Set. Instead, Egypt would have been a partner in Rome.

Power over Ruler:

As Isis held power over Egypt by holding power over Ra, so did Cleopatra hold power over Rome.

In Alexandria, Isis was associated with Aphrodite, both of whom were seen in Venus. So when Cleopatra appears to Marc Antony as Aphrodite, she’s appearing as Venus in her most romantically erotic form.

When Cleopatra appeared to Ceasar in a carpet, she appeared as the fabric of reality with which Isis was associated. When she appeared to Marc Antony as Isis-Aphrodite, she appeared in her most romantic and erotic form. This wasn’t just targeted seduction that recognized Antony as romantic and Ceasar as a man who wanted the world, for her, this would have been part of her magic.

who wanted to rule the world as the fabric of reality with which Isis was associated,

Aphrodite: Alexander’s conquest led to an era much like globalization. This led to an intellectual and religious period that emphasized comparisons and connections between gods from different regions. In Alexandrian Egypt, Isis was seen as Aphrodite, which is the form taken by Cleopatra when he appeared to Marc Antony. And what’s so important about this is that it shows us where Cleopatra gets her  into

When Cleopatra appeared as Aphrodite to Marc Antony, it was not a departure from her role as Isis, who, for the Greeks, was associated with their goddess of love.

To appear in a carpet to Ceasar is to associate herself with the carpet, which is associated with the fabric of reality, which we see in the wings of Isis. In Latin, we see this connection in the word mater, which means both mother and matter, which are related to the word, matrix. The matrix of reality is the maternal fabric of reality. Everything in our reality is born from that matter of mothers — this is the maternal matrix of matter. This is the carpet in which Cleopatra appears. She is not just offering herself, she is offering the wings of Isis.

The association of carpet with a woman’s sexual organs isn’t just about hair, it’s about the fact that the fabric of living reality is woven by and from the wombs of mothers. All of us everywhere were born from mothers. Maternal Matrix, matter mother — these words point to an understanding of the maternal as the fabric of reality that wraps around us and holds us, this is what the wings of Isis are all about— these are the wings that wrap around us like a womb, like the wings of a chicken around her chicks. So when Cleopatra arrives in a carpet, it is a deeply symbolic gesture. She arrives offering so much more than her body — she’s offering the wings of Isis — arms in which the world’s greatest leader might truly rest. And he did.

When a Pharoah died, he or even she, became Osiris, who was the Djed pillar. The Djed pillar was a ladder to heaven and model for the Pyramid, which we recognize as a tomb and monument to Osiris. But Cleopatra, didn’t identify as Osiris. She identified as Isis, which begs the question, could she have had herself buried in a tomb and monument to Isis? If so, it would have looked very similar to the way her family had created a tomb and monument for Alexander the Great, which served as a center for a cult that presented him as, like Osiris, the son of Egypt’s god.

She was quite familiar with the way Alexander’s tomb had become a religious center for his cult, which presented him as the son of Ra, like Osiris. If Cleopatra wanted the same for herself, she would have built a tomb to be a religious center for the cult of Isis.

entries.question: Hearing it for the first time, what is your first impulse on the story of Cleopatra? How would you describe it? And what is wrong with it? Her story is a Hollywood Movie. Why is that?
entries.text:
Cleopatra was modeling her personality and life after a myth long before her life was mythologized by painters and poets—and it shows! Her life was like a movie, which is why there are so many movies about her life.

The history of great figures seems to include more and more mythic motifs over time. What’s so interesting about Cleopatra, however, is that she was modeling her life around a myth before it was history.

We always see ourselves in every retelling of an old myth, and so we are always updating myths as mirrors of ourselves, and so we have had a different cleopatra at different times in history. Sometimes she’s a corrupting eve, or Pandora, and sometimes she’s an ultimate icon for feminine empowerment. By now, she is as much myth as she ever was history.

entries.question: In short, what is the story of Isis? And how important is Isis/ What does this god embody?
entries.text:
In the central narrative of ancient Egypt, Osiris is just a corpse. Isis is the star—Venus actually. And like an ancient super hero, she rescues her abducted lover and leads the conspiracy to save Egypt. This is Isis’ role — she is the queen mother and protectres of Egypt and her family, a role to which she brings the full force of femininity.

Isis is a myth of feminine power, and we have been deprived of it. The persecution of witches is indivisible from the reduction of Isis in our collective conversation. Master of the mysteries, she is brilliant, powerful and nurturing, sexual and dignified. So too, was Cleopatra.

you remind the world that women can be powerful. If one woman could do it, others could as well.

You’re putting forward a role model and an option. It’s hope for women and danger for men.

Christians are always looking to retell the myth of Eve, and to keep women in their places. So the story of Cleopatra gets turned into a story of Eve, because, she’s not in the place that the patriarchy would make for a woman.

She’s one of the best and most repressed role models in the history of human femininity. And it’s because she’s one of the most complete and empowered female role models in history that she is the most repressed.

entries.question: What do you think is the problem with women in power? How is it our society’s fault? And what could we learn fom Ancient Egypt?
entries.text:
Patriarchal societies fear and dismiss powerful women.

Society is unspeakable cruel to women that don’t fit traditional feminine values

Society today, and society in ancient Egypt, might not have been so different. Or they are.

We have demonized women who demonstrate ambition

Ancient Egypt reminds us, there was once a society that valued a womens calmer more nuanced political skills

entries.question: In which relation do the Pharaohs and gods stand? What do we see in the depictions of Cleopatra in Egyptian temples?
entries.text:
Each pharaoh image of his mirrored god.

Cleopatra always wears the headdress of Isis.

entries.question: Why do the ancient Pharaohs in temple depictions always look the same? How can we distinguish the one Pharao from the other? Is there a mythical reason?
entries.text:
Why wasn’t Isis featured in popular media like Disney’s Moon Knight or Alex Proyas’ Gods of Egypt? One answer is that it would be like having Superman in a story and waiting for someone else to save the world. There is no one more competent or powerful in Egyptian mythology than Isis. As Cleopatra holds sway over Caesar, it was Isis who knew Ra’s weakness.

Cleopatra and Isis

Knows Weakness / Has Power Over/with Ra / Roman Emperor

We sometimes think of female leaders as having to play a man’s game. This was as true in ancient Egypt as it is in the modern world. Hetchepsut, for example, wore the goatee of Horus. She did this, because, in the myth, the new Pharoah is always Horus. This is why male pharaohs wore the goatee, to be Horus. Cleopatra was the rare female pharoah who didn’t play Horus. She played the Queen. She didn’t wear the pantsuit. No way. She was Isis and she knew it. Imagine president Beyoncé, imagine a woman as a head of state actually using her femininity. That was Isis. That was Cleopatra.

Cleopatra was not a repressed or secretive Christian monarch. She was a sexually empowered queen of Egypt — a woman in full force. Not another Egyptian queen with the goatee of Horus, she was Isis!

There has been a propaganda campaign against Cleopatra that is the same we’ve seen against Isis, witches, and Mary Magdalene — and it has to do with the way we see prostitution and sexuality. Mythological Warfare

Season 3

Tomb of Alexandre

4th Pyramid

El Dorado — Pyramids, gold, sun worship, mythic overlap

Holy shit, Christianity fulfilled something that would have already been fulfilled, had the Emperor been equally Egyptian. The Pharoah was a god on earth associated with the sun, a literal son of the sun god, of the father god, Ra. Though Egyptian religion is polytheistic in structure, it is also monotheistic in its hierarchy, which is why it was possible for Akhenaten to attempt monotheism. Any emperor after Ceasar must have thought about what it would have been like to have been Caesarian, to have been Horus the son of god and the emperor of Rome. This kind of alignment wasn’t achieved until Christianity was adopted, which draws heavily from Egypt. I’m not sure there would have been a Christian conversion had Cleopatra succeeded, which means no burning of Alexandria and no end of Paganism. But that couldn’t do, because the Egyptian and Roman religion, much as they can be fit together, are not perfectly compatible. I suppose they could try to make them, but they aren’t. Mother Earth and father earth, for example. No, tehre had to be one true accurate religion for people to really believe. History couldn’t go that way.

episodes.title: The Amazons
episodes.summary: This episode is about the famous-infamous female warriors of the Greek mythology – the...

entries.text: The MYTH OF THE AMAZONS
This episode is about the famous-infamous female warriors of the Greek mythology – the Amazons.

A group of female warriors and hunters, who were as strong as men – or at least almost. Their society was closed for men and they only raised their daughters, either killing their sons or returning them to their fathers, with whom they would only socialize briefly in order to reproduce. In most descriptions/ vase paintings they are practising horse riding archery (as opposed to the Greek army who fought mostly on the ground with swords and spears).  Some of the most famous Amazons are Penthesilea who fights against Achilles, Hippolyte who fights against Herakles and Antiope who fights against Theseus. Their stories all end with a defeat – either death or marriage – through the Greek hero.

The oldest mentioning of the Amazons is in Homer’s Iliad where they only appear briefly – Although in such a passing mention that it seems that the writer took the reader’s knowledge about the Amazons for granted. The Amazons are portrayed in many legends, poems, vase paintings and even ethnographical descriptions.

The film looks for traces of whether the Amazons have a real origin or what historical facts could have influenced the myth. We also try to answer the question whether women can be successful warriors. And finally, we look at the extent to which the myth of the Amazons is influenced by the role of women in the respective time.

At the beginning of the film we go in search of clues in the museum. In the "Antikensammlung" in Munich, together with the archaeologist Anja Hellmuth, we look for indications and clues in the Amazon depictions on Greek vases as to whether the female warriors really existed. The equestrian and archery tradition, as well as the clothing of the depicted Amazons point in a clear geographical direction: The Amazons on the Greek vases look like Scythians!

We travel to Ukraine, in the middle of the former Scythia. Here we meet Elena Fialka. Elena Fialka is an archaeologist and has been researching female warriors for many years. In the past, all graves with weapons burials were automatically attributed to men. The existence of female warriors did not occur to anyone at that time. Until, at some point, a female anthropologist was present at an excavation. She saw at first glance that the skeleton of a supposed warrior was actually a woman. Since then, archaeologists have found many graves of female warriors. In some areas, there are even up to 30%. But the museums still show only male warriors. Elena wants to change this and tries to convince the museum director of the Scythian museum in Kiew Juri Bogdanovich that the Amazons are not just a myth and deserve a place in the museum.

Can women have been successful warriors? In an exciting experiment with a real Amazon from Germany, we prove that a woman on horseback armed with bow and arrow could indeed be dangerous to the Greek foot soldiers. Pettra Engeländer has been practicing this sport successfully for many years. She effortlessly hits all the gelatin blocks 40-50m away, which are supposed to represent the Greek foot soldiers.

Orissa Kelly is also so skilled with bow and arrow that there is no doubt that an Amazon could have been a successful warrior. Orissa was a stuntwoman in the remake of Wonderwoman. Wonderwoman is a superhero story derived from Greek myth. In its creation in the 40s, the idea of having a female superhero was a progressive one….maybe until now. However, the story of Wonderwoman is not the only one that tells the exploits of a female warrior....Wonder Woman, Xenia, Alanna.....Amazons, in various forms, still have a place in pop culture today. In addition to their exciting adventures, they are an interesting and revealing reflection of the times.

But there are still many cultures today where female warriors are nothing unusual. A trip to Mongolia shows us how much the imaginability of women as warriors is a question of culture instead of a question of gender. And how much life on the steppe is linked to this tradition. Tsetseg, a 72-year-old grandmother tells us how she was taught archery by her grandmother and how important she thinks it is that this tradition is not lost, especially among women. Therefore, she regularly teaches her 10-year-old granddaughter how to shoot perfectly.

Finally, we go back to the sources. Because some time ago, a team of archaeologists in Turkey made an exciting discovery. The young archaeology student Tugce and her lecturer Professor Kaymakci recently stumbled across the description of an Amazon island called Aretia in the Saga of the Argonauts. It struck them that the description of Aretia's geographical location fits quite closely with a real-life island in the southern Black Sea: Giresun Adasi. The two wait for weeks for the right weather to go to the island. On the island, they make amazing discoveries: Under the ruins of a Byzantine monastery are much older steps...steps like those leading to an altar. And they also find a black stone that fits very well the description of the sacrificial stone from the Argonaut saga. Are we on the former Amazon island of Aretia?

entries.question: What made those women dangerous (when was a woman considered dangerous?
entries.text:
Atilla’s army was defined by the advantages of archers on horseback, and there’s nothing that could stop a woman from learning this skill. A group of women on horseback with bows would be devastatingly dangerous on any ancient battlefield

In representations of divine feminine figures we often see a convergence of both the power to bring life into this world and the authority to take it away. Durga from India gives birth to men but also eats them—not unlike Ishtar, who would both mate with and destroy zgilgsmesh. When we confront a band of woman warriors, on one level, they can be seriously fierce fighters, and certainly with bows on horseback. On another level, they represent the power over life and death we often see in mythic women—from Durga and the Maenads to Ishtar and the Amazons.

Diana or Artemis is not an Amazon in mythology, but, like the Amazons, she wields the bow. The bow represents aiming focus. Where the Dionysian Maenads enact the destructive force of feminine fury, their scariest quality is unthinking billigerance. Athena bares the gorgon on her shield to display her inner mastery of this feminine fury, and Artemis bares a bow—like the Amazons—to demonstrate the focus of this feminine ferocity into a single penetrating dart.

Some Amazons bare the image oft he Gorgon on their shield—like Athena, another woman warrior. This represents the warrior woman’s ability to harness her inner Gorgon, which is a nightmarish interpretation of feminine vitality. Women can fight. And as with male Berzerker warriors like Hercules and Ajax, those woman warriors who can channel their inner rage and wildness into a disciplined fighting style are the most fearsome of all. This is what we see represented when we see the Gorgon on shield of Amazons and Athenians. It’s the same reason we see it on the shield of Zeus, whose Olympian order subdued the Titanic – it represents the ability to harness that more raw part of ourselves with inner discipline and intellect.

What’s so precious about the image of Diana or Artemis, the huntress, is that her arrow represents the focusing of her ferocity. She carries the same energy as the Dionysian Maenads that can absolutely rip a man to shreds, but in the figures of Athena, Artemis and the Amazons, we see women capable of focusing and aiming this feminine ferocity.

Zeus, whose Olympian order has subdued the Titanic, also bares the Gorgon on his shied. Throughout Greek myth, one of the key themes is the focusing of raw psychological energies into characters like Athena and Zeus definied by the strength of their minds.

entries.question: What was the image of women in ancient Greece?
entries.text: It’s not only that women were oppressed in Ancient Greece, it’s that they saw femininity as to be oppressed. This is because—from Pandora to Eve—there’s an association of mother with matter. In Latin, they share the same word—Mater—and from Christianity to the philosophy of Socrates, there is a belief that matter and embodiment is a prison that corrupts consciousness. This hasn’t just led to the repression of qualities identified as feminine, it’s led to the objectification and oppression of real women in our real world. The subduing of bodily sin has been indistinguishable from the suppressing of females and femininity—from Ancient Greece to modern day. This subduing takes the form of myths in which women are subdued or defeated by men—the Gorgon is a perfect example, because we also see the Gorgon on Amazonian shields.

entries.question: In what sense were the Amazons contradictory to that image?
entries.text:
Amazons might be seen as perfect shadows for ancient Athenian wives, who did not govern or fight.

In contrast with the highly oppressed lifestyles of ancient Greek wives, their images of Athena and Artemis were as warriors.

In fairytales we have the contrast between wicked witches and fairy godmothers, which represent two sides of feminine potential. In Greek Mythology we see this contrast between Athena and the Gorgon on her shield. On a group level, we see it in the disparity between Amazons and Maenads. Where the frenzy of a Maenad represents unbound and unthinking instinct and urges, the discipline of Amazon archers represent the potential to focus that destructive potency into a single aimed shot. This is what Diana or Artemis represents—she is as wild and potent as nature itself, but she’s not without thought or focus. As Athena is to the Gorgons, the Amazons are to the Maenads—powerful masters of the feminine vitality.

entries.question: Was there maybe also an erotic aspect of Amazons in mythology?
entries.text:
There’s no doubt that Amazons served as wonder women for ancient Greek men, whose heroes sought them as brides.

Myths often transmute what can’t be said into dream-like poetry, for which reason sexual taboos and secret lusts tend to show up in our myths. That there are men with fantasies of dominant women would have been as true in Ancient Greece as is it on Wall Street.

Heroes and Amazons fall in love with one another on the battlefield once one has bested the other in a very close struggle. On one level this might be a memory of a very real mating ritual in which indo-european war bands set out in search of women. On another level, lovers continue to look for their “match” – and I’m not sure love is ever free of power. In this way we might see the fight between male and female warriors as a poetic expression of love—and lust.

Women were treated so unequally in ancient Athens that a peer-to-peer relationship was unthinkable enough for men to only know peer-to-peer romance as existing between men. In a society like that, the male wish for a peer might look like a fantasy tale in which warrior women were found on an adventure.

Romantically, you might say we are looking for our match—someone that challenges us, you might say.

Psyche doubts cupid until he’s beneath her knife, at which point her love becomes unshakable. Hercules similarly falls in love with an Amazon queen at the moment he’s killed her. These are poetic expressions of a common experience in love,

Myths tend to have erotic implications, and that of the Amazons is no different.

One of the memories echoing through Amazon mythology seems to be a forgotten mating or matching ritual in which Indo-European war bands selected their women in ways that resulted in onlythe strongest women becoming their wives.

What are the sources that tell us about the Amazon myth (vases, "the comics of antiquity")

Many of our sources on Amazons come from vases, which were popular for Symposia in which men gathered to drink wine. Though I know men would never objectify fantasy women while getting together for drinks in the 2020’s, this may have happened from time to time in ancient Greece.

entries.question: In what occasions were myths told in ancient Greece?
entries.text:
Myths, like dreams, entertain and teach. At the same time, myths were often public versions of more secret stories about the mysteries of the soul.

Myths thread together a culture—it’s agriculture and rituals, it’s values and spiritual insights, it’s traumas and aspirations, art and theatre, war and sport, technology and medicine, astrology and meteorology,. Myth weaves it all together. No matter the profession, no matter the angle, no matter the activity, we experience it through the languages of our mythologies.

entries.question: What was the purpose of myths?
entries.text: Joseph Campbell describes myths as spiritual training, and the spiritual message represented by the Amazons is also seen in the shield of Athena and the arrow of Artemis. Gorgons and maenads represent a feminine fury that can rip men to shreds and turn them to stone. When the Gorgon appears on Athena’s shield, it doesn’t represent the her lack of Gorgon energy, it represents how she’s mastered it and put it to use as a defender. This is the mastery we see in Artemis’ arrow. She is as wild and potent as any Maenad, but she’s also able to focus that feminine potency into a highly aimed attack. So when we see an Amazon carrying the shield of Athena and a bow like Artemis, we see them as women who have mastered and focused their own inner vitality.

entries.question: How literally are these myths to be taken? (Geographical data...cultural descriptions like taking off the breast?
entries.text:
To displace the crescent breast with the crescent bow is to replace the first crescent sliver of moon that represents new life with the last crescent sliver of moon, which, like the reeper’s sickle, represents death. To displace the crescent breast with the crescent bow is a poetic statement that these women are not in the business of nursing life into existence, they’re reapers of death. There is no evidence of any literal truth when it comes to the sheering of their breasts.

The cutting off of the breast seems to represent a choice having been made between motherhood and war fighting, and it may even represent the author’s sense of their archetypal incompatibility. The breast nurses life into this world, the arrow kills.

Myths are often better seen as questions than answers. If a myth says it’s set in the Caucasus mountains, then we should go looking in the Caucasus mountains. Sometimes we’ll find something and sometimes we’ll find out that even the specific geography was meant as mere poetry. The truth myths are trying to get at is not limited to the literal or the historical, but that’s not to say storytellers haven’t been highly interested in cataloguing history. Myths don’t delineate philosophical, psychological or literal truth, in fact, they emerge exactly where there’s overlap. Where historical truth mimes a philosophical truth mimes a psychological truth – that’s going to trigger myths and dreams.

The crescent shape of the bow, breast and moon has led to their association.

There are pictures of Amazons from the Greek period that show women with both breasts, and we aim from our eye, not from our chest.

In Sarcacian, the name for forest and moon were similar, and so you see this moon like forest mother. The moon is the crescent of the moon.

entries.question: What can you tell from grave goods? (status, profession?)
entries.text: Grave goods give us a good sense of someone’s status and profession, which is why when we find the graves of women warriors with a high status, we have to take seriously the possibility that there were fighting women held in high regard.

entries.question: What roles do women generally take in myths?
entries.text:
The word for mother and matter is the same in Latin. We see this in the figures of Pandora and Eve – the original matter and mother from which all humans have come. And in the myths, body and materiality are presented as prisons for a fallen consciousness. They’re also seen as the sources of pleasure, emotion and thereby the corruption of spirit by sin. This philosophical enmity between spirit and matter has become a mythic enmity between masculinity and femininity has become real enmity between men and women.

The male quest for a woman—or even the grail—is, one one level, a poetic expression of male consciousness trying to integrate the femininity it’s split off from itself. At its worst this is a journey in which femininity is subdued. At its best, these are journeys in which men do things they’ve repressed as feminine and materialistic—this can look like developing a relationship with the body and nature. It can look like the opening of the heart and the integration of an emotional reality. It always includes the death of a hypermasculinized ego.

Women are mythically associated with the material vessel of life, whether that’s the pregnant mother or mother earth. Unfortunately, Western philosophy and religion has been defined by its recognition of materiality and earthly existence as a prison into which we’ve fallen that corrupts our spiritual purity. Because women are mythic personifications of materiality, the spiritual and philosophical attack on matter has become a social and political attack on mothers. In Latin, mother and matter share a word – mater – and so the anger and blame pointed at Eve and Pandora is anger at the material world for imprisoning and corrupting the soul. This is how we thank our mothers for bringing us into this world.

Women have been historically and mythically conflated with matter,

entries.question: What role do myths play in comics?
entries.text: Comics have come from and become mythology. On one level it’s direct, like Diana and the amazons, and on another it’s more archetypal, like the way these stories engage feminine experiences that are more universal than Scythian. On yet another level, comics perform key functions of myth in that they represent cultural ideals, introduce us to spiritual training and offer resonant psychological experiences while providing texture for our cultural experience.

entries.question: Wonderwoman: who is she?
entries.text:
Diana is the Roman name for Artemis, goddess of the hunt, who, like the amazons, is defined by her skill with the bow. In Artemis we see shades of the Egyptian Nepthys, a ferocious huntress of the Egyptians who appears as the second woman in a dynamic with Osiris and Isis—not unlike the inspiration of Wonder Woman, who became the third in a relationship between the creator of Wonder Woman and his wife.

Diana or Artemis is not an Amazon in mythology, but, like the Amazons, she wields the bow. The bow represents aiming focus. Where the Dionysian Maenads enact the destructive force of feminine fury, their scariest quality is unthinking billigerance. Athena bares the gorgon on her shield to display her inner mastery of this feminine fury, and Artemis bares a bow—like the Amazons—to demonstrate the focus of this feminine ferocity into a single penetrating dart.

entries.question: What was William Marston trying to tell with Wonderwoman?
entries.text:
William Martson was a psychologist and writer who believed in love and women at a time defined by men at war. From then to now, she represents the salvific capacity of love and femininity in a world defined by hypermasculine power.

The Carole of Wonder Woman was a psychologist who believed in solving problems with love instead of war and that this was a more natural response of women, who he supported as an early feminist and defender of taboos who’s wife and he brought another woman into their relationship, the same woman whom inspired so much of Wonder Woman. He was an early feminist who worked on the lie detector and believed in solving problems with love instead of war.

In one of the most meaningful scenes in recent memory we see Diana emerge from the trenches to stare down the full fury of the Nazi army, and in that moment we see the rising of repressed feminine vitality against the very worst of our world’s hypermasculine toxicity.

entries.question: How has the Wonderwoman mythos (or even the Amazon myth) perhaps also changed over the years?
entries.text:
Feminism has evolved since the time of Wonder woman’s creation by an early feminist, and we’ve seen the twists and turns of feminism represented in the stories. Once an ideal is clarified, the story will forever trend in that direction, and because the ideals of this story involve feminism, righteousness, truth and love, we haven’t just seen the story do a better and better job of representing these themes, we’ve also seen the story evolve and change alongside feminist philosophies.

Each story will fail to perfectly reach those ideals, but each story will strive to improve on their expression in the next telling.

entries.question: From the Amazons to Wonderwoman...what does Amazon tell us about the image of women?
entries.text: Female action heroes are not masculinized women – women can fight, with their bodies and minds, which finds expression in the poetic stories of Diana and the Amazons. And when women fight, they use feminine power, which is related to their sexuality as it is their motherhood. And when women fight, it tends to be for feminine motivations, from exacting revenge on the unjust treatment of women to the defense of their nests—from the island of the Amazons to the families a mother will defend with her life.

entries.question: Do you believe in the myth of the Amazons?
entries.text: I believe there really were women warriors who inspired myths about Amazons and that there would be myths about warrior women even if there never were any. Their stories are brimming with as much psychological and philosophical meaning as they are historical influence.

entries.question: Where does the myth of the amazons come from?
entries.text:
Amazon Myths are a conglomeration of several things, They represent a memory of what may have been a more matriarchal period in human history. Their battles with men may capture memories of an ancient mating ritual. They are certainly shadow figures for oppressed athenian wives and fantasy figures for athenian men. Beneath all of this, they may be a real historical group of fighting women that doesn’t deserve but might actually appreciate their emergence as poetic representitives of repressed ferocity and feminine focus.

A memory of matriarchy

A memory of a mating ritual – there is a story of Hercules falling in love with the woman he defeats and another story of an Amazon woman falling in love with a man she has defeated. In some way the myths look like a mating ritual or contest in which we are looking for our match.

A shadow of athenian wives

Real women warriors who sometimes don’t deserve all the extra projection

A repressed dimension of what the feminine represented symbolically and mytholgically as matter – we see matter as dead and inhabited by life, but that’s a repression of a shadow reality that the material and feminine is alive.

Female Berzerker mode

Recent discoveries have shown that many ancient Amazonian names are Abkhazian, Ubek and Ossetian. To this day, these people tell stories of legendary figures called Narts, and among these Narts is a figure names Amazan, a woman warrior who leads a band of women who live in the forest. The location of these Forests in the area of the Black Sea is consistent with the mythic memory of the Amazons in this region.

Amazan – woman warrior leads a band of women warriors who lives in the forest, she’s called Amazan because it means little golden knees, because her boots and trousers don’t quite meet, so she is sun tanned between them. This is a motif in the culture – other characters are held on their thigh when dipped in water and that is their one weakness.

Feminine Ferocity Continued

On one hand, Amazons represent the powerful destructive force we see in those maenadic women who rip men to shreds, and on another, they represent the focusing of this ferocity into the discipline of a warrior. This is seen in the bow, which focuses aggression into a pointed shot, and it’s also seen in the Aegis, which they sometimes share with Athena. This shield, which bares the image of a gorgon, is consistent with the personality of Athena. While there’s no warrior more feared, there’s also no warrior more thoughtful or focused. She and Artemis, like the Amazons, represent women who have learned to channel and focus their inner fury. This is the same fury we see in Hercules and Ajax when their Berzerker energy is aimed at friends and family. Over and again in Greek Mythology we see this focus on mastering our inner titanism.

Mother and Matter Continued

From Pandora to Eve we’ve seen the mythological alignment of the mother with the material. In Latin they share a word, mater. In contrast, Pater gives us the words for both pattern and father. This is to say, the duality of male and female has been mythologized as a tension between matter, which is seen as inanimate, and pattern, which is associated with fire and consciousness. This sets up an understanding of materiality and femininity as a prison that corrupts our minds or souls. Unfortunately, what’s really corrupted is our culture’s relationship with both women and its understanding of femininity. The oppression of the feminine is co-emergent with the association of femininity with materiality and emodiment, sense perception and biological urges. These aren’t just seen as sin in Christianity. Socrates presents the same understanding of body as a prison that corrupts our souls with urges we must learn to silence. The silencing of the inner feminine has coincided with the silencing of women.

Once we recognize this backdrop, we start to see mythic warrior women as both older than this worldview and as an exact response thereto. Where Pandora represents a woman made by a man – a woman whose mater is inanimate before fire is added—older figures like the Gorgons and Maenads represent an vision of the feminine as overwhelmingly powerful and certainly animated. In these figures we see feminine fury that can shred men and turn them to stone. When Greek heroes confront these forces, we might see it as an effort to repress or deny the reality of the feminine. While the fantasy is that matter is inert, it is actually animated. The feminine is not dead matter to be animated by the masculine. The moon is more than a reflector of the sun. In the myth, the Gorgon is subdued, but in reality, it’s the Gorgon that haunts us.

This is something I talked about in the documentary on Alien. We think we’re in a gargantuan universe of dead matter, but when we get deep in space to mine that matter, we find that the mater is alive, it’s a mother, and it’s going to haunt us until we see a new ideal, represented by Ripley, who champions female values from within a patriarchically structured crew. The alien is like the Gorgon and Ripley is like Athena. Where the Gorgon and the Alien represent the potency of femininity at its scariest, Athena and Ripley represent that same energy in its most victorious state. We see the same thing in Artemis. She represents all of that Maenadic energy—a blur of life giving power with unbound emotional energy—brought into the focus of a single arrow. This is the Amazons. They are the women able to channel the raw energy of a Maenad or Gorgon through the discipline of a warrior and with the aimed focus of an archer.

On one hand, we have Matrix, Meter and the Egyptian Maat thst point towards the the order and patterns of our materiality, on the other side we have Mater, which means both mother and matter.

episodes.title: Pope Joan
episodes.summary: Our documentary is part of a series called “Myths – the Greatest Mysteries of Humanity” in which we are looking to find an explanation for several myths. This particular 45 minutes episode revolves...

entries.text: Our documentary is part of a series called “Myths – the Greatest Mysteries of Humanity” in which we are looking to find an explanation for several myths. This particular 45 minutes episode revolves around Pope Joan a supposedly female pope whose probable existence has been strongly debated for centuries. We want to find out: Could a female pope Joan have actually existed?

One of the earliest and well-known written documents is Martin von Troppau’s chronic of the popes dating back to the 13th century. In the text he mentions a “Johannes Anglicus” allegedly a female pope who disguised as a man became pope in the 9th century. However, during a procession she gave birth to a child revealing herself to be a woman. She was killed right there by the angry people.

Our protagonist Jacqueline Straub is looking for evidence of Pope Joan. Her starting point: the Abbey library in St. Gallen, Switzerland. Here, she finds a chronic written by Martin von Troppau mentioning Pope Joan. To investigate her case Jacqueline travels to Rome following traces of Joan – in St. Peter’s Basilica and the Vatican museum but also in the underground catacombs of the city.

Jacqueline is not the only person trying to find out about Joan. Marguerite Spycher has been analyzing coins minted in the 9th century during the papacy of John III. She is sure that one of these coins actually belonged to Pope Joan and therefore serves as evidence for her existence.

A woman being pope is not entirely far-fetched. In 1300 in Italy a new church was established. Devout Christians chose to believe in a female Jesus Christ. The devotees of the cult declared their very own Pope, Maifreda da Priovano. She was supposed to be the representative of women in powerful religious positions – up until she was killed for Heresy.

In our film we also want to talk about the role of women in the Christian church in general. We will show women in several religions including paganism and their agency and importance before Christianity. Many women used to be priestesses or played an important role in practicing the religion. However, at some point patriarchy took over and limited their powers or abolished it altogether.

entries.question: Whether or not Pope Joan actually existed, her myth has lingered through centuries. In an experiment we want to find out how myths actually work. How are they passed on from one generation to another? How well do we remember stories we hear? And, how reliable are such information for us today?
entries.text: Meta-Experte Will Linn

entries.question: Why is it such a big scandal that a woman supposedly sat on the pope's throne?
entries.text: Can you imagine a worse nightmare for patriarchy than a matriarch on its throne? Beneath the story of a scandalous affair and its defiance of church law is a more profound challenge to patriarchy itself…And it’s not just divine patriarchy. Pope Joan is a reminder for paternal kings and husbands that Mothers control creation.

entries.question: What makes critics doubt the story?
entries.text: It’s hard to trust a story with a motive—in court or in church—and not only do we see a story about female empowerment, we also know that it was important to women who were pressing for their rights when the story was popular. And…it was a scandal, and what we know about scandals is that they get juicier and juicier as they spread through parties and popular discourse. Deception, fornication, murder, cover-up—IN THE CHURCH! It’s a good story, and some of it might be too good, or too sinful, to be true.

entries.question: 3What kind of woman was Pope Joan according to legend?
entries.text: On the surface, Joan out mans the men as a leader and scholar who the men all recognize as an ultimate male patriarch. Beneath the surface, however, she’s a perfect Eve – not only does she disobey the divine patriarchy for sinful sex with a presumably innocent man. Like Eve, she becomes a personification of exactly what the Christian consciousness is trying to oppress, repress and “purify.”

entries.question: Why was it possible for her to ascend the throne?
entries.text:
Women would have never been allowed to ascend to the papacy. This is the story of a world in which women have to be as a man to succeed, and in these stories—some fictional, some real, some ongoing—it’s not enough for a woman to be as good as the men, she has to run circles around them to even be noticed.

At the same time, this is the story of how powerful a person can be in a male dominated world if they just integrate a little feminine. She may out male the men at their own games, but she’s also a woman, and she has qualities they haven’t engaged. As a more whole person, she runs circles around her peers.

This is the story of a woman having to be better at being a man than other men in a man’s world, which has been as relevant in our lifetimes as it was in hers.

entries.question: What reasons does the church have to cover up Joan, should it really not be a myth?
entries.text: Pope Joan is a perfect shadow figure for a Medieval Christian worldview that presented Mary, a virgin, as the ideal woman. Where women have been associated with materiality and the body, Mary conceives without intercourse or lust. She is Ave, the exact opposite of Eve – Mary is Eve redeemed. Pope Joan, however, is just Eve – a disobedient seductress who hides her sin from the divine patriarchy. This isn’t just a story of feared femininity, it’s a paranoia about it’s ability to secretively climb the ladder. What would she have done if she stayed in power? Would the whole church have become filled with witches in hiding? There are certainly nightmares throughout history in which the Catholic church is controlled by the Devil.

entries.question: Why does the myth persist until today? What is so fascinating about it?
entries.text:
Pope Joan offers a particularly pointed example of the eternal power struggle between men and women. This story is older than our species and it continues to this day—in every government, in every business, in every relationship and every psyche. Strait, gay, bi, trans, he, her, they, them—there’s not a person to whom the inner and outer power stuggle of femininity and masculinity doesn’t matter. And in the story of Pope Joan, everyone can see what they want to see: a nightmare that curses women, a nightmare that curses men, a story about the power of women, a story about the dangers of femininity—it’s all there, and when a myth is serving everyone in the conversation, it stays in the conversation. (especially when it’s a juicy scandal!)

If it were not still a scandal that a woman ascended the throne, then the story of Johanna would probably no longer be on everyone's lips.

entries.question: Is the legend not at the same time a criticism of today's church politics?
entries.text:
A new image of a pope giving birth would be as subversive today as it was in the time of Pope Joan. It’s like the graffiti of a punk artist saying, oh, so you think a patriarch has the monopoly on divinity and creation all by himself? He can’t even do THIS. Women literally have the authority to create life, and as much penis envy as there may be, it pales in comparison to the existential response of a man to the woman’s ability to create life…all the life. This queendom we live in, it came from mothers. And when you know that, and when you’re watching the Catholic church take the patriarch so seriously, the prank becomes an irresistible temptation, and there’s no better subversion than to enter the pope’s clothes as a woman, as a mother.

While the Catholic Church has elevated Mary to a higher status since the time of Pope Joan, in some ways, this only cements its idolization of sinless women uncorrupted by the embodiment of their own sexual potency.

entries.question: In the same way we’re all born from the darkness of the womb, Europe was born from the darkness of the 9th century, when Rome gave way to chaos. Creation begins with chaos, from Genesis to the Theogany. And so is it any surprise that a spiritual monarch associated with this time was a woman?
entries.text: The 9th century is predestined to be filled with speculation. Rome sank into chaos, the list of popes broke off. Records were destroyed. It is also called the "saeculum obscurum", the dark century.

entries.question: Why were the reformers so interested in the story of the pope Joan?
entries.text: Pope Joan is a personification of exactly what the church represses, and her birth in the Pope’s clothing represents that which has been repressed finally forcing its way to the surface. Such a disruption, however, is only an inciting incident—an inciting incident that reformers experienced as a call to adventure—a call to change. Reform always follows disruption—in the self and in the world—and this disruption tends to take the form of a subversive act by a shadow figure that personifies exactly what her culture represses, oppresses and… needs.

entries.question: How is it that the myth has remained in people's minds until today?
entries.text: There will always be reformers, and they will always preserve stories that criticize the status quo. If the status quo had truly changed, if the Church had fully reformed, I’m not sure the story would still be on our minds. Until and unless there is real change, the reformers of our day will renew the cries of their predecessors.

entries.question: Are the laws of the Roman Catholic Church made by God? (Conclusion)
entries.text:
Wastelands are defined by the vitality they marginalize and repress. By now, our marginalization of the feminine is inseparable from the threats of climate change and nuclear extinction. But though the west has been defined by its oppression of femininity, our times are defined by its rise. Good thing, because without it, we’ll waste.

We have to recognize that a healthy culture and individual holds a balance between conservative and liberal forces. We are always seeking to integrate and conserve our past while moving towards a future we see as progressive. An increased emphasis on change will trigger a backlash of conservatism. Too much conservatism will trigger subversion and change. A culture or person that only identifies with one of its feet is doomed to trip. A culture or person with both identities steps forward.

The story of Pope Joan points to the eternal tension between conservatism and changeThere is always a tension between conservation and liberal progress. Cultures and individuals identify with the past while projecting hope into the future.

Identities of both cultures and individuals hold tension between a past with which they want to identify and a future they’d like to see.

State and religion are invested in the status quo, and so they tend to be aligned with conservatism. Liberals have never accepted the limitations of church or state.

entries.question: Was Hillary Clinton blocked from becoming the president and leader of the free world because she’s a woman, or did her gender help her win the democratic nomination? BOTH.
entries.text: Pope Joan would face the same problems today she faced in her time, BUT, I think she’d have more help and more hope. In fact, I’d love to see a pope joan today, and if we did, I think… she might be unstoppable.

entries.question: How is the church different from other institutions?
entries.text:
The Church is eternal and immovable; it has survived the trials and tribulations of millennia unscathed: The end of the Roman Empire, the migration of peoples, the Crusades, the Reformation and the confessional wars, the Enlightenment and the age of anti-Christian dictatorships.  The Church is the mystery par excellence.

Christ was a reformer whose message of love continues to inspire progressive perspecties and liberal values. At the same time, the Christian church and priesthood, like the Jewish patriarchy of Christ’s time, is a pillar of conservatism. Religious organizations always are. And so the change bringing love of Christ is preserved by a conservative institution who’s stability has been a cornerstone of stability for Europe and beyond. Institutions have come and gone in the last two thousand years. The Catholic Church has not.

A culture is stabilized by its conservatism and expanded by its newness. In the western civilization and Christianity, the church has served the conservative function of a stabilizing pillar that anchored a huge range of disparate identities.

Scientists tend to be reductive, for which reason the diversity of narratives about Pope Joan are taken as evidence of their fallacy. But in a world overrun with comparable cancellations, we have to ask ourselves, even when there’s an objective truth, do we not end up with countless competing narratives?

To dismiss a historical origin of a myth based on the existence of another historical origin is to be blinded by the linear reductionism of an overly masculine mind. Arthur, Hercules, you name it – good myths are almost always informed by more than one historical figure.

There’s a rumor that Pope Joan was actually a form of bullying or critical satire towards Pope John VIII, who was seen as weak when dealing with his enemies and ridiculed as feminine behind his back.

History or not, there is a story of Pope Joan, and the question of whether or not she’s historical is consistent with that story. This is the story of women’s oppression, suppression and repression—from church, state and history itself. And notice, in stories about women dressing as men, they aren’t just stories about how women are forced to conform to masculine ideals in a masculine culture, they’re also about how they are forced to conceal their femininity. She doesn’t just have to hide her body, she hides her pregnancy—she hides the very expression of her most divine creative energy. And what else is suppressed? The sexual scandal—the same scandal of Adam and Eve, who’s original sin is to disobey the divine patriarchy by having sex and making babies. The demonization of Pope Joan is a repetition of hatred for Eve, and what that hatred represents is an anger at having fallen. This is the fall of spirit into matter. Matter isn’t just seen as a prison that corrupts the soul, it’s also the word for Mother. Eve and Pandora don’t just represent the mother, they represent materiality. And so whether it’s Greek Orphism, Platonic Philosophy, Ascetic Hinduism, Judaism, Christianity or Islam, there’s a mythical alignment of the material and the maternal. As matter and body are seen as corrupting prisons of falling consciousness, the mother is a representative of the fall and a personification of corruption with a seductive body. Pope Joan may be historic. She’s also a perfect mythic repetition of Eve. And for the same reasons, she became associated with the Whore of Babylon.

Women heroes are often more than representative of women, they can also be representatives of femininity. The success of a woman can be a story about the value of femininity. These stories can be written in response to a climate that devalues qualities that have been identified as feminine.

And once we start talking about the oppression of women, we have to start talking about the collective repression of what we associate with femininity.

Notice that both Zeus and Jehovah or Yahweh are presented as procreators – makers of people. In reality, this is something mothers do, and Goddesses have been worshiped as divine creators for as long as we can remember. With the rise of Zeus and Jehovah we see a mythological degradation of femininity. Pandora and Eve are blamed for all humanity’s problems and the two Patriarchs claim the creative power of a woman. In Pope Joan, we see the mythic tension between Patriarchal power and the reality that it’s the Matriarchs who bring life into this world.

I can’t help but see the story as something like Mythic graffiti, to paint a mother giving birth into a Pope in a procession is like subversive joke that pokes fun at a self-important Patriarchy in complete denial about where the real power of creation comes from.

She is an Athena or Hermione like figure – a brilliant thinker who excels in the scholastic environment.

episodes.title: Illuminati
episodes.summary: Conspiracy theories concern the conspiring of a small group around secret plans. On a personal level, there might be a fear that someone is out to get you, but typically, Conspiracies concern the...

entries.question: What characterizes a conspiracy theory?
entries.text: Conspiracy theories concern the conspiring of a small group around secret plans. On a personal level, there might be a fear that someone is out to get you, but typically, Conspiracies concern the manipulation of society itself. This isn’t about the standard efforts of companies and governments to make money and expand power, conspiracy theories are about Hidden powers.

entries.question: How do conspiracy theories work and what makes them so appealing to many people?
entries.text: In the 2020s, it’s become increasingly important to address our susceptibility to conspiracy theories and how big lies work. Why are bigger lies more convincing? Part of the reason is because they force us to Find a way of thinking in which they might be true. This is enabled by the greed of scientists who have eroded trust in “facts” by auctioning their authority. The subsequent recognition that the truth of a motivation is more reliable than facts has led us to prioritize narrative.

entries.question: What makes the conspiracy theory about the illuminati order so interesting?
entries.text: The myth of the illuminati is so successful because of its flexibility. What do you want to project into the illuminati? Whatever your belief system is, you can find it in the Illuminati conversation. Are they a caring group who want to bring peace and enlightenment? Are they a secret kabal of tyrants? Is the world full of dupes? Whatever you want to believe, you can find it.

entries.question: Why do conspiracy theories exist at all?
entries.text:
Conspiracy theories present the world as more predictable and managed than the alternative, which plays off our childhood psyche.

The first all-seeing eyes are those of our parents, who limit our freedom to keep us safe. This is nurturing for a child but oppressive to adults.

Our inner child feels both comforted and stifled by the notion of a ruling elite. So whether you want something secure or something to rebel against, Conspiracy theories Fit the bill .

The conspiracy of conspiracies is, of course, that theories are labeled conspiritiorial as a way to ensure their collective dismissal. This is about their

entries.question: Since when do conspiracy theories exist? Have they always existed?
entries.text:
Ancient humans knew that an unseen group of predators could be tracking them at any moment, which set up an instinct to always be wary of unknown predators. This is how the fear of wolves becomes a fear of secret societies.

To be seen by an Other is to exist, like a tree that's heard when it falls. On the other hand, to be seen is to be vulnerable--especially to manipulation.

Some parts of us want there to be an illuminati out there seeing us and watching us like Santa and Mom, but On the other hand, we don't want Hal over our shoulder and controlling what we do.

So in some ways you might say there has always been an illuminati, as we’ve always

entries.question: Why do people tend to see patterns in things?
entries.text: Humans are abstract geniuses who don’t just see patterns everywhere, but even across the senses. We call cheese sharp, music soft, a touch sweet… Poetry and metaphor emerges when we synthesize recurring patterns. This is when the passage of time becomes the melting of clocks, when sunset becomes the planting of a seed and burial of a loved one—when sunrise becomes birth and resurrection.

entries.question: Why can it be dangerous to see patterns and stop giving chance a chance?
entries.text:
We see what we are looking for and we are looking for confirmation. We spiral into delusion when we want confirmation enough to, consciously or unconsciously, ignore facts.

It would be unrigorous to dismiss them without investigation, and some interesting questions have been raised. The problem is when we leap to conclusions – when we are so motivated by a potential answer that we blind ourselves of what else might be.

entries.question: Does gambling work on the same principle as conspiracy theories or where is the connection?
entries.text:
Wayward conspiracy theorists and troubled gamblers are comparable – both maintain a sort of tunnel vision around their own beliefs and expectations, typically against the odds, despite their large bets.

A gambler gets in trouble when they believe they’re going to win as opposed to recognizing the odds. This type of tunnel vision around their beliefs and expectations is exactly what’s going on in a wayward conspiracy theorist—especially when bets are placed.

entries.question: Why are the symbols of the Illuminati so popular in pop culture (musicians like Madonna, Lady Gaga, etc.)?
entries.text: Don’t be surprised by attention seekers seeking attention, and don’t be surprised by power seekers pretending their power. This is what I see in celebrity references to the Illuminati. And I get it, this very second, all I want to do is break the wall and pretend like I’m part of the conspiracy to mess with people and draw attention. It’s so tempting. I could tap into a franchise sized audience with a well timed wink. But it’s too irresponsible in the 2020s to toss fuses like that anymore.

entries.question: Is Christmas Christian, or has the Christian narrative become a spine that invites all the solstice stories? The same question can be asked of the Illuminati, which have become the mythic spine for all conspiracies.
entries.text:
Fact or fiction, the myth of illuminati is alive in our imaginations—as seen in literature, film and music. Notice, however, the storytellers behind these stories are rarely interested in creating conspiracy theorists. Their use of the illuminati has more to do with the plot and its metaphors.

a myth—not unlike King Arthur or the Holy Grail. And this myth fills a crucial role in the human psyche. Whether it’s God, Santa Clause or Mom, there’s a space in our minds to imagine someone watching and responding. Unlike the divine notion of God, the children’s story of Santa or the parental experience of mom, the Illuminati provide a more rational vision of our controllers as just a set of humans.

entries.question: Why did the Illuminati come into being during the Enlightenment? /Does the Enlightenment have anything to do with the Illuminati foundation?
entries.text:
The belief in a logical and coherent universe is more ancient than the Tao or Logos. But it was Newton who showed the math. This breakthrough, more than anything, gave birth to the Enlightenment. The real reason we adopted Enlightenment values is because the Newtonian paradigm was more convincing than the state or church—especially after Copernicus.

Email Will Linn: It's likely they were just part of a larger zeitgeist.

entries.question: Did the Illuminati actually represent Enlightenment values in reality?
entries.text: The values of the illuminati were grounded in the Enlightenment zeitgeist. This was about trusting science and questioning the supernatural.

entries.question: Did the Illuminati spread Enlightenment values, or did they emerge with a zeitgeist? The illuminati worldview is grounded in Enlightenment values, which present
entries.text: , They wanted to achieve freedom and maturity primarily through education. On the other hand, they had this highly hierarchical system of informers….

entries.question: How prestigious was the Masonic League at that time?
entries.text:
When the Illuminati was formed, such covens were the rage, and Free Masonry was the gold standard.

Freemasons had a different standing than they do today. It was in the spirit of the times to organize in such circles and the Freemasons were certainly the largest and most prominent coven of all!

entries.question: What was the difference between the Freemasons and the Illuminati?
entries.text:
Freemasons don’t share their secrets, but they don’t hide their participation either. The Illuminati, on the other hand, was a smaller more secretive club.

Unlike the Illuminati, they also did not keep secret that they existed - on the contrary, there were prominent members who publicly stood by their membership.

entries.question: Why are the Illuminati always brought in connection with other so-called secret societies?
entries.text:
The abstract notion of a secret elite is like a center of gravity that draws in historic and fictional examples that converge in the form of a myth. Even if there were a real Illuminati, their truth is enhanced.

the Illuminati myth may have less to do with its historical origins than the abstract notion of a secret elite.

In the past it was the Freemasons who were infiltrated by the historical Illuminati. Today it is said to be other organizations like the Skull & Bones or the Bohemian Groove that are infiltrated and secretly directed by the Illuminati.
