However, there is no proven connection between the historical Illuminati and the so-called secret societies of today.

entries.question: Why is so much political power attributed to the Illuminati in conspiracy theories?
entries.text:
Conspiracy Theories gravitate towards power brokers with secret agendas, and because PR firms are hired by every politician and company, their effort to be convincing is apparent.

Convincing is not the same as lying, but telling the whole truth is rarely prioritized. What’s said behind closed doors is not in commercials, and we know it. This is why companies get accused of Greenwashing and virtue signaling. It’s also why we speculate, because we know we aren’t getting the whole truth. Within this room for speculation, everything is possible—including the notion that it’s all connected.

Every PR firm, politician and storyteller is in the business of convincing. This isn’t the same as lying, but most of us know agendas to be developed and sold separately. What’s said behind closed doors is not in commercials. This is where we get terms like Greenwashing and virtue signaling. It’s also where

the inability to know what’s really going on leaves room for speculation.

entries.question: What are the major power positions in our world? Where can a few people leverage major influence? What are the choke points? That’s where the illuminati would be – from bankers and executives to politicians and the Suez canal.
entries.text:
Bullshit is distinguished from lies when you recognize the difference between hiding and convincing.

Every commercial PR campaign

Governments and large organizations hold a lot of power in our globalized world today. It is true that we cannot know what is happening behind the many closed doors in front of which the ordinary citizen stands. It is also certainly true that politicians and others do not always tell us the truth. It is tempting to want to see a pattern behind this. To bring all this under one hat with the Illuminati, however, is pure speculation in my view.

entries.question: Why do most conspiracy theories have a historical core? Or rather, how/ why does a historical event become a conspiracy theory?
entries.text: There is a difference between lying and convincing. Convincing is more successful when it draws on the truth. The same can be said of conspiracy theories, which operate like tricks. Magicians fool us with partial, misleading truths.

entries.question: There’s truly an eye on the dollar bill, and in the church of the Holy Sepulcher. The aereal views of Karlsruhe and DC share true similarities. But are these partial truths misleading?
entries.text:
Magicians present partial truths to trick our belief. Conspiracy theories, are like tricks.

The more truth the more convincing—like the arial images of Karlsruhe and DC. Magicians make us believe with partial truths. It’s their skill.

fall into trouble is where the magician gets us to believe something based on the manipulation of a partial truth.

. They are convincing because It is typical of conspiracy theories to link things that have a true historical core - such as the coincidences between Washington and Karlsruhe - with other things that are fictitious. That's what makes it so hard for laypeople to separate what is truth and what is fiction. Because if you research what Washington and Karlsruhe look like, they can see the pattern quite clearly. The theory that it's because of the Illuminati, on the other hand, they can't verify. But if one is true, many people tend to believe the other.

entries.question: Why are symbols so often used in conspiracy theories? Are symbols at all something "typical" for conspiracy theories or do we see them elsewhere as well?
entries.text:
The pyramidal eye of the Illuminati, on the dollar bill and in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the Eye of Sauron and Santa, of Hera and Hal, the big eyes of alien others—these are like the eyes in place of breasts, in ancient figurines. A mother sees her child into being, in the same way a tree falls if it’s heard. But as much as we like feeling seen, by mom and Santa, we don’t want Hal over our shoulder—the same can be said of the Illuminati…or five eyes.

It is not uncommon for conspiracy theorists to go on quests—for the Holy Grail or some other truth. This is typically guided by their pursuit of symbols, and when you start visiting churches in Israel or Europe, you see Masonry symbols everywhere—and Cistercian.

the Eye Goddess figurines and the gargantuan eyes of aliens. To be seen by an Other is to exist, like a tree that's heard when it falls.

The eye of the illuminati, like the eyes of the mother, make us feel seen. On the other hand, to be watched is to be controlled. Some parts of us want there to be an illuminati out there seeing us and watching us like Santa and Mom, affirming our existence. On the other hand, we don't want mom or Hal or the Illuminati looking over our shoulder – controlling what we do.

Email Will Linn: What I've gotta gotta gotta encourage is that you get the image of the pyramidal eye at the height and center of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher. When I saw that, I was like... dang.. And seeing all the ancient masonry logos all over Israel is really quite something.

entries.question: The myth, by now, is far more than its history. Does the all seeing eye recur as a symbol of omniscience because some secret society is diffusing it through time, or does an ability to see everything just look like an eye in the sky?
entries.text: The all seeing eye is a recurring symbol of omniscience. One could argue that it recurs because as a result of some single society diffusing through time, secretly, or, it could be because an eye on a mountain is a great metaphor for omniscience. Once you’re running with the essential mythology of a global elite, it’s just a matter of time before every relatable image, figure and example, becomes integrated.

entries.question: How does the image we have of "today's Illuminati" come together?
entries.text:
Tolkien recognized that storytellers tend to ladle their narratives from a cauldron of stories—myths, folklore, religion and gossip, memories and dreams. the Illuminati myth, is more grounded in the abstract concept of a ruling elite than a specific secret society.

The illuminati may have less to do with what it is than what we want to believe.

entries.question: Why is this image so absurd/ironic compared to the historical Illuminati?
entries.text:
The stated agenda of the Illuminati had everything to do with grounding the world in science and fact – that minds are lost in their pursuit is terribly ironic.

So we end up aligning around resonant narratives and psychologies more than facts, which we've come to believe are secondary to motive. How ironic, as this is exactly what the Illuminati was against insofar as their stated agenda had everything to do with creating a more secular world grounded in science and fact.

Additional Notes

It does not follow that because conspiracy theories are misguided we should accept surface truths. If we take everything at face value, we can’t even have good relationships. That doesn’t mean, however, that there’s a conspiracy.

episodes.title: Attila
episodes.summary: Atilla was the key figure in bringing down the Roman Empire, and he’s a crucial nemesis in the epic cycle of Nibelung, which climaxes around the death of Attila & loss of Treasure to the Rhine....

entries.question: What makes the Attila myth so special?
entries.text: Atilla was the key figure in bringing down the Roman Empire, and he’s a crucial nemesis in the epic cycle of Nibelung, which climaxes around the death of Attila & loss of Treasure to the Rhine. Historically, Attila’s death was highlighted by the burial of he and his treasure in the Rhine. One might similarly compare the great sword of Siegfried with the famous blade of Attila, which, like Gram, was lost just after his life.

entries.question: Why is so probable, that there can still be found remains of the Huns in the Danube?
entries.text:
The Huns are a historic people that spent a lot of time around the Danube – finding Hun artifacts in the Danube should be no more surprising than finding WWII bombers or Roman ships. So though much has been claimed by its mud, if Attila’s grave is there, given the amount of Iron in his coffin, we’ve just got to beat the rust.

Can it really be that Attila was buried under a river?Attila’s grave was not meant to be found; This is to say, there would have been motivation to tell a misleading story, which could have led to a pretty big heap of myth. Maybe he’s not buried in a river at all, or maybe he’s buried in the Rhine, where his death takes place in the Nibelung. Whether or not he’s buried in a river, it’s especially interesting that his sword would be, as the return of a King’s magical sword to water is an ancient Indo-European motif seen Arthur & Batraz. This is why we find swords in rivers.

entries.question: One should be especially interested in the legend of King Alarich, a Visigoth, who was buried in a river. Could the story of Attila’s grave have been based on similar religious beliefs? Or could this be just one of several mythic threads in his burial designed to elevate his memory
entries.text:
According to the story, the Nibelung treasure was lost to its unknown location in the Rhine when Kriemhild and/or her husband, Atilla, killed those who knew its location.

Attila died of a “hemorrhage”. What could that mean?The Huns were a warrior culture—especially under Attila. Warrior ideals—from Achilles to the Samurai—is to die a warrior’s death. At the same time, everyone wants someone or something to blame. So when Ildico was found cowering next to the dead Attila, there were multiple motivations for assuming her guilt.  What we know is that he bled from his nose. Whether he choked on his blood or died from a hemmorage, the real question is if he was poisoned or just too drunk to sleep safely?

In the Edda’s, Atli’s death is caused by his wife, which is true to history; but in the Edda’s, motifs that can be identified with older myths are introduced. We first think of Medea, a witch of the Caucasus who, like Guorun, killed the chilren she bore to Jason. And like Georun, who sent the hair of a wolf to Gunnarr, Medea’s witchcraft, which she learned from Hekate, was associated with the wolf. This is an old indo-european association of the mother and dog that can be seen in Satanaya as well as the wolf who suckled Romulus and Remus.

Why were the undertakers killed?The secular answer is that the slaves who dug his grave were killed to bury its secret location. The religious answer might be more comparable to the not-uncommon practice of the dead monarch’s desire to have slaves in his afterlife. Both could be true, and both would be consistent with the burial of various Chinese emperors. The Hindu ritual, which is perpetuated by some still today, the good wife of a dead husband will throw herself on his pyre; otherwise, they would not be together in the afterlife.

What is the triple coffin of gold, silver and iron that Attila is said to have been buried in?I am intrested in this reference but could not find: Another myth and also a modern translation error. In reality it is a triple thickening decorated with different metals; this actually occurs in some graves of the Asian Huns from this period.

The Egyptians and Ancient Hindus, among others, buried the dead in sheaths. This is related to the notion of body as a sheath for the soul. In Christianity, this motif can be seen in the comparison of the soul’s separation from body with wheat’s separation from chaff.

entries.question: Why are lost tombs like Attila's always the subject of myths?
entries.text:
Arthur & Attila, great leaders of their people, were lost upon death. According to the Arthurian tradition, he was taken to the isle of apples, “Avalon,” from which the King will Return. So on one level, the lack of a grave or body permits the fantasy of return or resurrection among their followers.

Great kings are typically buried with great treasure, for which reason the lost grave of a King becomes a myth of lost treasure.

King Tut’s grave was of course found after more than three thousand years.

Tombs are fertile ground for myths of the underworld, no pun intended. For example, the sword of Odin was withdrawn from a central tree in Valhalla—like Excalibur from the stone. Well, if you look at Indo-European Kurgans or burial mounds, what you find is a central pillar on which the old father’s sword will hang. So what we see is an image of Valhalla that relates to a much earlier burial practice.

How are the Huns and Attila perceived today?The longer and harder you hold something down, the more violently it will surface. This happened to the Romans in the form of Hun and Visigoth raids. Both were symptomatic of the same oppression, but where the Visigoths seem more like rebels seeking rights, the Huns seem more like terrorists seeking revenge. Given all the shooters and terrorists in our world, this is something we should all be thinking about. Oppression leads to terrorism and rebellion. Or rather, terrorism and rebellion is a response to oppression—real or perceived. The question is then if we should be focused on Attila as the destroyer of civilization or as its Shadow incarnate?

What myth about the former royal city of Buda still exists in Hungary today?People in Hungary still perpetuate the myth of a lost Hun capitol in the Pilis Mountains—Buda to the Huns or Ösbuda, as it is called in Hungarian. Though archeologists have never found the city, many Hungarians believe in its existence. Some are committed to its discovery.

How were the different legend traditions mixed up? How did Attila become King Etzel of the Nibelungenlied?Attila, Atli, Etzel – these are likely just the translations of his name—little father—into different languages and dialects. Notice, by the way, that his name shares a prefix with Atlas, an Indo-European war-leader of the Titans. Insofar as the Romans sided with Olympus, you might say that the Titans—and all the raw drives they represented—finally won.

Fathers Eating Children: The scene of Atila eating his children in the Nibelung, intentional or not, aligns him with the mythic figure of the devouring father—most famously in Cronus, who ate his children to resist their power and retain his own. The devouring of the son is the ultimate expression of the patriarchal tyrant that hoards power. By adding a mythic layer in which Atila ate his children, he was aligned with the most evil tyrannical behavior in Indo-European memory.

What was the "concept" of the equestrian people in battle?The real advantage of the Huns was their mounted archer – a motif that goes back to the centaur, which was likely inspired by the Hun’s Indo-European ancestors. If the stories are to be believed, they were so fluid on their horses, it might as well have been part of their body. At the same time, their swift maneuvering also reduced the efficacy of opposing archers. Have you ever seen a sports match where one team is just faster than the others? That was the Huns, running plays and running circles around their enemies.

While some believed they didn’t wear armor, that doesn’t seem to be the case, though there are many accounts of sleeveless armor, which would have been more conducive to their focus on archery. What armor they did wear was lamellar or scale armor—an older form of armor that they have seen as traditional.

The Indo-Europeans were among the first true equestrian cultures, which were nomadic and typically had two leaders. This can be seen in Hengist and Horsa, who threatened Arthur, as well as Attila and Blada. When you see a double headed horse on the top of a barn, that’s what you’re looking at. That having been said, the pattern can be seen in both Romulus & Remus as well as the the Dioskuri, who are not particularly associated with horses. What’s going on is that an earlier horse culture entered the sea, which has to do with why the sea god, Poseidon, was also associated with horses. This is also why Trojan and Roman helmets are modeled after the horse. Though early indo-europeans were horse riders, not all waves of their migration retained such an equine focus. It’s also the case that some who did, particularly those in the Caucasus, who seem to be most comparable with the original Indo-Europeans, armored their horses heavily. These heavy-armored horse riders became prototypes for knights. Like the Huns, the people of the Caucasus are all but glued to their horses; so what led to the difference in their approach? Like the Narts, they were known for their bravery and battle cries.

Why were the Huns so feared?We always fear what we don’t understand—especially when it can sneak up on you so quickly and wants you dead. Not only were the Huns somewhat foreign and beyond understanding; their mobility on horses and their prowess as archers must have had everyone everywhere on edge. This is a people that left wakes of carnage and intentionally spread fear, a people that cut themselves to morn and faced battle fearlessly. It would have been incredibly hard to look at the threat they represented and find something in yourself that could have matched it.

Why were the arrows of the Huns considered magical?The Huns were spectacular mounted archers—something beyond the skill of Roman militaries. Because anything someone can’t do or understand becomes quickly associated with magic, and considering that Generals like Attila were seen as supernatural until their first loss, the Hun arrows of mounted archers, which could sneak up and kill you at a distance, would have been seen as almost magical

Sword of Mars – Atilla is said to have possessed the sword of Mars, or a more native war god. It was given to him by a Shepherd who found it in the grass. Symbolically, this may be a memory of the Shepherd as the ancient patron of the pastoral indo europeans and a recognition of the sword as a harvester of souls, as represented by its discovery in grass.

The sword of mars is not unlike the sword of Sigfried, Charlemagne or Arthur – all of which represented great might.

episodes.title: Ghosts
episodes.summary: The beliefs of different cultures in the soul and afterlife are modeled in their myths, often in the form of ghosts, shades or spirits. The various beliefs about the afterlife then inflect the...

entries.text: ITV Fragen Wiill Linn:

entries.question: How does mythology explain the belief in ghosts?
entries.text: The beliefs of different cultures in the soul and afterlife are modeled in their myths, often in the form of ghosts, shades or spirits. The various beliefs about the afterlife then inflect the disposition of their ghosts. In Greece, Herakles shade is found in Hades while another part of his being went to Olympus. In China, to be a ghost means you’re attached to move on, means you’re to attached to your appetites, for which reason you’re punished with a tiny mouth. These are called “hungry ghosts”

entries.question: Why are ghosts something people believe in since the beginning of mankind?
entries.text:
Most cultures describe the awakening of first humans as an integration of fire, breath or divine essence with a clay or dough-like body. This symbolic distinction of soul and body predates the mind-body dualism of Descartes and Socrates by a large margin, as does the overlap of words for breath, air and spirit – Pneuma, for example, in Greek.

When you see someone moving and then just stop dead, it’s like something is gone, they’re gone – this is so basic I’m not sure dogs don’t believe in ghosts; in fact, many ancient cultures thought they could see them.

entries.question: Why are ghosts something that is popular in cultures all over the world?
entries.text:
Death is the greatest of human concerns, and seeing a ghost would be the ultimate confirmation that life doesn’t just end—not for you and not for your loved ones, some of which may already be gone. So to the extent we want evidence that life doesn’t just end, we want stories of ghosts.

Also, IF there is an afterlife, and there are ghosts, they would probably be everywhere.

entries.question: How do you explain that believing in ghosts is lived out so diversely in different cultures?
entries.text:
The different beliefs cultures take towards ghosts tend to emerge from their deepest worldviews, which are informed by religion, science and more. Catholics, for example, are for more receptive to ghosts than Lutherans.

Modern Science does not disqualify the possibility of ghosts. Enlightenment science did, and the western consciousness responsible for the Enlightenment still struggles with modern physics. This not as true in India or Japan, where they don’t suffer the same Enlightenment hangover or the Western predispositions that led to delusional dismissiveness and reductive thinking. They also don’t have religions that argue against ghosts, as seen in the movement of Martin Luther.

entries.question: How about England?
entries.text:
In Germany, free thinking, superstition and metaphor were attacked by Catholic inquisitions and protestant literalism. England suffered none of these, and their history centers around global trade—of both goods and ideas. That England is more receptive to the possibility of ghosts than Germans should come as no surprise.

One of the reasons Germans are less receptive to ghosts than Brits probably has to do with Martin Luther’s perception of ghosts as a “Catholic Supersition,” or, could Luther’s perspective have been emergent from an already typical Germanic realism? If so, could this have to do with all the Papal inquisitions against non-conformists that happened in Germany but not England? Plenty of inquisitions happened in Spain, and they are more receptive to ghosts, but they were led by Catholics, who believe in ghosts. So can it be as simple as the history of German religion? I suspect there’s something deeper.

entries.question: Why are most humans afraid of ghosts?
entries.text: Thinking about ghosts is thinking about death, which most of choose not to do on a daily basis. The confronting of a ghost is a confrontation with death, and not just because the ghost is dead and might kill us, but because the very being of a ghost forces an existential confrontation with death. The fact that we make ghosts scary and tell scary stories about them is like putting a Halloween mask on a face of true horror.

entries.question: Do you think ghost phenomena can all be explained by science?
entries.text: Some ghost phenomena can be explained by science, other scientific explanations depend on assumptions and reductive either-or logic. The bigger question is – IF science can explain a phenomena, does that mean it can’t be a soul? Science can model and map the movement of neurochemistry in the brain and associate it with mental activity, but they can’t translate into the language of subjective experience. The same may be true with ghosts – we may be able to see weird energetic phenomena, but that does not mean we can dismiss the possibility of a subjective experience pertaining to that energy. Science, left to its own devices, will deny subjective consciousness in our own brains.

episodes.title: Frankenstein
episodes.summary: Sensorium Dei means that we are the sensory organs of the divine. Scientists who shared this perspective were not just trying to decode a secular universe. They wanted to know the mind of...

entries.question: What was the main concern of medical science in Shelley’s time?
entries.text:
Sensorium Dei means that we are the sensory organs of the divine. Scientists who shared this perspective were not just trying to decode a secular universe. They wanted to know the mind of god.

Embolded by the discovery of electricity, Calculus and the Copernican revolution, scientists asked questions where before there were limits. They wanted to unlock the mystery of life.

entries.question: What is science?
entries.text:
Prometheus, the bringer of technology, strains against boundaries as bondage. There are scientists and there are inventors. There are clerks and entrepreneurs—priests and shamans. Priestly scientists are like clerks who maintain the orthodox. But Innovators, like Prometheus and Frankenstein, like Shamans and Entrepreneurs, break boundaries to go their own way.

Science means finding new ways, exploring boundaries and sometimes even crossing them.

entries.question: In what instances is science allowed to cross the boundaries?
entries.text:
Wernher von Braun said the rocket would open the gates of heaven by freeing us from our chains. All innovation is against the bondage of some status quo—labor and disease, life on this planet. This is why Prometheus, the innovator, is always wrestling with chains. Technologies—from weapons to cures—rebel against the possible. But by rebelling against mortality—the human condition itself—Frankenstein crossed the ultimate boundary.

Sometimes science needs to be daring and explore new territories in order to fight against deadly diseases or improve life quality. To that end it has to at least push boundaries but at the same time keep an eye on ethical and moral values.

Frankenstein, the modern day Prometheus, like Prometheus the titan, wrestles limitation itself. The fire he brings isn’t just the conscious vitality that animates his creatures, it’s the technologies that enable revolution—revolutions against the status quo. It is the archetypal nature of Promethean creators to challenge the limitations of their own creators—a pattern repeated by Frankenstein and the monster.

The status quo of nature, society and the mortal condition become the aims of

(2.) (please exactly like that)

What constitutes playing god? Dissecting the body was once seen as off limits. Stem cells have been seen as off limits. Both, however, have saved lives. Some see a challenge to the natural order in the corona vaccine, some see a technology saving souls. Where we all seem to stop and hold our breath, however, is when we’re messing with mortality itself—when we try to stop death entirely and when we create life on our own. Frankenstein dared both.

entries.question: Our brains grew big because our stomach needed less resources because we cooked with fire – we are a post technology species. No technology no humans. We can live on raw food, but we’ve evolved around technologies. What other inventions might redefine humanity? Pacemakers? Enhancements? Ai?
entries.text: Shouldwe be allowed to play god? Is it morally and ethically acceptable to bring a person to life artificially, or enhance its natural body? Does the medical progress made justify experimenting with nature? Frankenstein is a symbol that warns against crossing boundaries. When it comes to medical research, however, scientists may sometimes have to take extreme measures in order to achieve new goals - in a positive sense.

entries.question: Who is the monster in Mary Shelley’s novel?
entries.text:
Frankenstein is not the name of the monster, it’s the name of his creator, Victor Frankenstein, Doctor Frankenstein. But are we supposed to make this leap? To recognize the creation in the image of its creator? Or should our recognition of the monster as Frankenstein set us up to see Frankenstein as the monster?

The monster is not the creature brought to life from the dead but rather the young medical student Victor Frankenstein.

entries.question: Why does the creature not have a name?
entries.text:
Adam can be translated as red clay, which is no more a name than Monster. The Golem did not have a name either, it was animated by god’s. Such Animation by a name is about the relationship of name with soul, or essence. This is to say, ton question the monster’s name is to question the monster’s soul.

Vampires, Mummies and Frankenstein’s monster are all awakened corpses. Each asks its questions of body and lifeforce.

entries.question: What makes Mary Shelley’s novel so special?
entries.text: The story of Frankenstein isn’t just told and retold. The figure has updated and informed our stories of playing god, of creator and creation of consciousess and body, which we continue to see in Ultron and like Ex Machina Data from Star Trek or David from Ridley Scott’s Prometheus.

entries.question: Are we right in the middle of a digital revolution?
entries.text: We are in the middle of a digital revolution that is seeing the convergence of AI, robotics, mind mapping and virtual reality – all of which have opened Pandora’s box to the potential of a new Frankenstein.

entries.question: What other examples of “the reckless scientist” do we find in literature? Why does this motif fascinate us so much?
entries.text: Frankenstein highlights a lineage of Promethean figures who challenge the natural order—from the necromancy of Dr. Faustus to the alchemical creation of a Golem, the metallurgical creation of Sosruquo and the pharmaceutical creation of Mr. Hyde. These creators refocus the revelations of science on a revolution against nature – if not the divine.

entries.question: Do you think it will ever be possible to create an artificial being that is as human as we are?
entries.text: The question of whether or not we will replicate a human should be broken into three levels: First, will humans be able to learn all the scientific principals that make us human? Plenty of stories talk about incomplete replicas of lost loved ones. The next question is if we will we be able to master and manipulate the physical principles that make us human? And then there’s the much bigger question: is there something beyond the natural or scientific that makes us human? And this is where it becomes a question about the soul and free will.

entries.question: What is an artificial being?
entries.text:
We are already a post-technology species. Our brain grew when our stomach shrunk when we discovered cooking – no fire no humans. Does the blind man end at his hand or his cane? How about his pacemaker? How about our smartphones? How reliant are our lives on power? Internet? Genetically Modified Foods? Vaccines? And if we can recognize we are at least somewhat artificial, why should we resist something artificial becoming somewhat biological?

To see Golem as a predecessor of the monster is to see his creator, the Maharal, in Victor Frankenstein. The same can be said of any Alchemist who makes a Homunculus. They all copy Prometheus in the creation of humans or God, in the waking of Adam.

its jewish creator, who plays god, is also a predecessor of Frankenstein. The same can be said of any alchemist and their Homunculus. is a forerunner Adam and Eve, Prometheus’ creatures, the golem…

episodes.title: Robin Hood
episodes.summary: One of the most famous episodes about Robin is his death - killed by his kinswoman, the Prioress of Kirklees Abbey. The abbey did exist and the old gatehouse is actually still there. We even find...

entries.question: This particular 45 minutes episode of „Myths“ revolves around Robin Hood and the historical backgrounds of the legendary figure. We want to find out: Was there ever a real Robin Hood?
entries.text:
One of the most famous episodes about Robin is his death - killed by his kinswoman, the Prioress of Kirklees Abbey. The abbey did exist and the old gatehouse is actually still there. We even find Robin Hood’s grave nearby - claiming that one „Robert Earl of Huntington“ was the true man behind the legend, dying 1247. But the site cannot be authentic: the style of the grave is Victorian age, the latin dating on the tombstone is clearly wrong and it is too far away from the priory to fit to the story. Scientists today know: the whole story of „Huntington being Robin Hood“ is based on a theatre piece from 1598 and a fake biography written by Martin Parker. The epitaph on the stone in Kirklees is even exactly the same as in the play.

We use this story as an example to show why finding the „real Robin“ is so difficult - for centuries people that loved him have tried to give him a place in history, faking graves and biographies. So we focus on key elements of story: he’s an outlaw, a bowman and his enemy is the Sheriff of Nottingham.

One historical figure that fought the Normans was „Hereward the Wake“. English Literature Professor Helen Philipps acknowledges that both Hereward & Robin belong to a long tradition of Outlaw figures but there are no proofs for Hereward being the real Robin. The early ballads never put Robin in any period at all. Also figures like Richard I, King John do not appear in the early texts. And above all: theres no one original narrative like Homer’s Iliad - we have many different ballads and legends. Our modern image of Robin is rather that of Walter Scott’s Novel „Ivanhoe“ (1820).

What the oldest stories have in common is the fact that Robin was a low class „yeoman“ and a skilled archer. German bow-master Jürgen Junkmanns shows us how very deadly and accurate this simple weapon was. Engineers of TU Aachen also show that the famous „Robin Hood Shot“ - pinpointing another arrow - is very difficult and even though it is possible - clearly a fictional part of the legend.

Another central element in all stories is the Sheriff of Nottingham and the forest. In Nottingham we find authentic places of the stories, like St. Mary’s church and many inspiring dungeons.

Historian Dr. Sean McGlynn finally takes us with him on his approach of finding a real Robin. In the Chronicles of King Henry III he does find a person that fits nearly all the criteria for a real Robin: an outlaw and a bowman fighting with his men in a wood who becomes a hero in lifetime: a man called William of Kensham. Looking for his traces in southern England McGlynn finds an important historic event: the second French occupation in 1216. Fighting guerrilla style William and his men helped to defend Dover Castle and to defeat the French.

Even though Robin Hood is very likely to be a composite figure that has been influenced by literature and fantasy throughout the ages, it is very possible that real persons like William of Kensham or places like Nottingham have inspired the original story.

QUESTIONS: (Will Linn) (Often several questions can be answered together)

entries.question: What makes the Robin Hood story timeless or universal?
entries.text:
Stealing from the rich to give to the poor is like stealing fire from the gods to give to humans, and what both stories are really about is the restoration of vitality and freedom that’s been opprssed by tyranny, order and taxation.

Robin Robs from the rich and gives to the poor.

Prometheus steals fire from the gods to give tot he humans—

humans Zeus would have taxed to death.

This is the timeless story of a trickster-led rebellion against the oppression of vitality by the life sucking grip of a tyrant’s laws.

Robin Hood is the story of a Rebel vs. a Tyrant, a Yeoman vs. a king, a trickster vs. an oppressor. This is a story in which the wasteland is defined by tyrannical taxation that steals away vitality.

entries.question: What is the central motiv/topic of the Robin Hood story in your opinion?
entries.text:
This is the story of a rebel vs. a tyrant on behalf of the oppressed.

This is the story of Prometheus and the American Revolution.

All are about taxation.

But where Robin Hood and the Americans steal back taxes from the King, Prometheus steals back fire from the gods.

This is where we see the wasteland of taxation as a wasteland of vitality, which is what we really want to restore—vitality of the land and spirit.

On the deepest level, this is the story of a  trickster disrupting order to free stifled vitality.

So though Robin is healing a kingdom, he looks a lot like the green fertility figures who restore nature.

This is a story of freedom vs. order—rebellion vs. tyranny.

entries.question: Is Robin Hood comparable to any modern hero?
entries.text:
Hunting of forbidden game with a bow is an introduction shared by Robin Hood and Katniss, who can tell us a lot about him. Not only do they both lead rebellions against a scheme of taxation, but in the case of the Hunger Games, the taxation is human life, which is a more direct stand in for human vitality, which is what it’s really all about.

And, Katniss fire, points to Prometheus, another rebel who robbed the rich in defiance of taxation.

V for Vendetta is a favorite Robin Hood character. Without the bow, we see the same light hearted romantic revolutionary fighting back against an English tyrant.

This is a mythic structure we remember from Prometheus and the birth of Athenian Democracy, and we see it in the American Revolution. One might even say that Robin Hood is the prototype for the story of the American Revolution, and by extension, the American Dream.

Like the American Revolution, Robin Hood leads a rebellion of behalf of the overtaxed against a tyrannical monarch of England. Both result in a just government, and where Robin Hood has become conflated with the Magna Carta’s origin story, the American Revolution gave birth to modern democracy.

There’s a Robin figure in David Lowrey’s film on the Green Knight that recalls Robin’s more sinister side. He and his thieves present as moral, but they are only thieves.

entries.question: Was there ever a real Robin Hood?
entries.text:
There have been and there will continue to be real Robin Hoods. On one hand, there are very real historic figures who appear in the earliest records of his myth, and on the other, historic people will continue to be integrated.

For example, I wouldn’t be surprised if we saw a Robin Hood figure on Edward Snowden’s mission to steal evidence that the state is spying on its people.

Tolkien pushed back against scholars attempting to reduce Arthur to historic or celtic figures by suggesting that a good storyteller is going to draw from what he called the cauldron of stories, which meant that a good character or a good story is coming from an undifferentiated mixture of sources—myths, histories you name it. It’s less about making sense of what specific source ended up in which specific story and more about what’s in the soup and how is it served?

We keep throwing more and more Robin Hoods in soup, but we keep selecting around the same criteria. From history to folklore, we’re looking for better and better details to tell the story that wants to be told. And the story that wants to be told is one of a pure hearted rebel against a hard hearted king—the vitality of a trickster vs. the vampirism of a tyrant.

entries.question: Isn’t Robin too heroic to be true?
entries.text: While the story has gotten further and further from any single historic origin, it’s gotten closer and closer to its archetypal truth. This is why we’ve seen Robin become more heroic and pure of heart as time goes on

entries.question: What exactly is so heroic about Robin’s fight?
entries.text:
Robin Hood does two things characteristic of all true heroes, not only does he bring truth and fairness to the world, he does so at extreme risk against a greater force.

His opposition to tyranny is no less than a David and Golliath like matchup between an individual and the power of state.

entries.question: Is it realistic to assume that a simple poacher and a robber could be the inspiration for such a famous legend?
entries.text: A robber, a poacher, sure. But that can’t be all. A storyteller would never look for a story’s single source. This is what scholars do, and Tolkien made fun oft hem for it. This obsession with 1:1 comparsisons and reductive linearity expresses the tyranny of western consciousness—a consciousness that could use some arrows from a trickster. (wink)

entries.question: Could a real Robin have been outlaw AND hero at the same time?
entries.text: When the law is not just, outlaws become heroes. When laws oppress, from literal slavery to vampiric taxation, to break that law, becomes heroic.

entries.question: Why do we love sympathetic villains?
entries.text:
A sympathetic villain can help us cultivate sympathy for our own villainous behavior.

We want to love ourselves. We want to know ourselves. And the part we find hardest to identify with or love ist he part of ourselves that we see as a villain. Sympathetic villains don’t only attract our love to them, they attract our love to ourselves.

We want what we can’t have—especially the unknown and the off limits. Whether it’s the ark or the apple the villain or the devil, we can’t resist what we shouldn’t want.

We tend to think we’re only getting what we want if it’s somethign we’re not allowed. The definance on our own behalf convinces us it’s what we want. This psychology can become relevant to affairs.

To hate a villain is to tell ourselves we are not like that villain, but though we never see ourselves as the bad guy, it’s typically out of denial, which means there’s a part of ourselves with which we aren’t identifying and that we actually hate. When we find ourselves wanting to love sympathetic villains, it’s because we want to be sympathetic to a part of ourselves from which we’ve been split off. It’s not just that villains are often misunderstood, it’s also that the part of ourselves we see as villainous is often misunderstood. Is it really just the devil in me that wants great sex? Or does the repression of sexuality as devlish cost us something good for us?

We do not identify with the entirety of ourselves, and what we identify with least is our own villainy. To the extent that the psyche wants to identify with the entirety of itself, it is magnetically drawn to the same villainy it represses. This draw is to our own inner villain.

entries.question: The part of ourselves we love the least is the part of ourselves with which we refuse to identify – we never see ourselves as the villain, but is it possible that none of us have ever been villains? We hate villains with the same force we hate that we could be villains and
entries.text:
We all refuse to believe we could be or have ever been villains, and so to hate villains in stories is to tell ourselves we are not villains,

We want what we can’t have and we‘re drawn to what’s off limits. At the same time what’s beyond the limits represents what’s beyond the known. We’re drawn to the unknown as much as we want what we can’t have. This is why, or at least partially why, we’re so drawn to villains.

entries.question: Fighting back the French Invasion of 1216  -  is this an event when heroes would have been made?
entries.text:
Heroes would have been made and stories would have been told about the French Invasion of 1216. These stories would have been all about the forest ambush—the defining scene of the Robin’s myth.

By the way, it’s also the defining scene of the American Revolution, another story of rebellion against the taxes of an English monarch. And as the story oft he American Revolution has inspired countless comparable histories, we have to wonder if it could have come from English rebels who’d never heard of Robin Hood.

On one level, the story of the bowman attacking the king’s vessel as it journeys through the forest is the scene of the moon attacking sun as it journeys through night. The story of sun and moon chasing one another through day and night recurrs all over the world, and the journey of the sun through night is always associated with peril and death. We think of attacks on Osiris as he journeys through the underworld on his solar boat.

The conflict of sun and moon is a conflict defined by the sun’s tyrannical dominance and the moon’s mysterious ways. Where the solar king is linear, power driven and direct, Robin is associated with music, wine, romance and the forest. He takes no offense when losing a fight to little john as a king would. What we’re seeing is a counterbalance or healing response to an overly solar, masculine and power driven psyche with the levity of Robin’s jokster heart, with music, with wine, with the dark mystery of the forest and an understanding of those people oppressed towards the darker spaces. He is a personfiication of what the king is not, and their disparity matches that of the sun and moon.

Though the first Robin Hoods were likely more bad than good, because the archetypal essence of the story is one of a good hero vs. a bad villain, we’ve seen the narrative chyristalize in this direction over time. By now, Robin Hood has become an exemplary moral figure.

The myth of Robin Hood has been assembling and reassembling itself with all the best pieces – some of them historical, some of them mythological—all building an archetypal narrative around a few clear ideals: Good guy vs. Bad Guy, so despite the fact that the earliest Robin Hoods may have actually been more bad than good, we’ve seen the character evolve into good guy bandit.

Robin Hood is the prototype for the American Revolution and by extension the American Dream. Like the American Revolution, Robin Hood leads a rebellion of behalf of the overtaxed against a tyrannical monarch of England. Both result in a just government, and where Robin Hood has become conflated with the Magna Carta’s origin story, the American Revolution gave birth to modern democracy.

entries.text: Myths – the greatest mysteries of Humanity: Zombies

This episode explores the myth of the zombie. On the one hand, we analyze the zombie’s significance in today’s pop culture and its potential as a figure of critique. On the other, we will trace the Zombie back to its Haitian origins. My understanding of the zombie is that in Haiti there are cases of zombification via toxins as forms of punishment by the secret societies that serve the community, or as criminal acts. But at the same time, the figure of the zombie goes much further back in history and is an expression for experiences of slavery, but also of resistance during the Haitian Revolution.

Since the early 2000’s, the Zombie has made it into our everyday lives. Zombie walks, zombie survival trainings and an explosion of zombie movies and TV shows. The name “zombie” is given to a great number of phenomena.

Such as “zombie-cicadas”: periodical cicadas infected by the fungus “massospora” – a fungus that controls its host and influences its behavior. Although the cicada is only a shell of itself, it continues to reproduce itself. A strategy by the fungi to reach more cicadas. At the university of West Virginia, Matt Kasson and his team have discovered that the massospora puts its host on drugs. They have detected amphetamins that are similar to so called “bath salts”: drugs that are known as “zombie-drugs”. Drugs that are supposed to have triggered a horrible crime. In 2012 a man attacks another and eats large parts of his face. An incident that is known as the “Miami Zombie attack”.

That the zombie is such a popular monster today is due to his phenomenal film career. A career that kicked off with George A. Romero’s “Night of the Living Dead”. With zombie-expert Sarah Juliet Lauro, we travel to the cemetery in Evan’s City where the first scene of the movie has been shot. At the University of Pittsburgh we will see how Romero has shaped the modern zombie-myth. The fact that the main part is played by a black actor is not only a political statement, but also a reference to the zombie’s history that is much longer than most people know.

The first zombie-movie was “White Zombie”, a movie based on William Seabrook’s book “The magic island”. A travel report where the journalist reveals the most unbelievable observations: It seems that in Haiti people are raised by the dead in order to work as slaves. Anthropologist Nora Zeale Hurston travels to Haiti shortly after him and shoots the first photograph of a Zombie.

What sounds fantastic gets more probable with the story of Clairvius Narcisse. In Haiti, he was declared dead and buried, but came back 18 years later. He is supposed to have been raised from his grave by a Voodoo-master and forced to work in a plantation for several years. A case that made the headlines in the 80’s.

Philippe Charlier, anthropologist and director of the Musée du Quai Branly in Paris has been in Haiti in order to investigate the Haitian zombie-phenomenon. He learns that it is people who harm society that are turned into zombies. And those who decide about it are secretive voodoo-societies.

In New Orleans, we visit Voodoo-Chief “The divine prince” to learn about this animistic religion. In voodoo, the soul is believed to consist of two parts. During a ceremony, one of these parts leaves to body so that a spiritual entity can enter the body. The person is “possessed”.

The soul-concept is also relevant for the Haitian zombie because it is believed that the voodoo-master steals the victim’s soul. That’s why he can control the zombie, explains Haitian sociologist Laennec Hurbon. For him, the zombie is the perfect slave. An images that points into Haiti’s history, but that also influences Haiti’s present. The myth is so present in Haiti’s society, that it is often used to explain the inexplicable.

entries.question: During his research, Charlier has met a zombie-patient in a psychiatric hospital. He finds out that she has slight epileptic periods. Is this the reason for her mental state? Or rather the consequence of being drugged by a Voodoo-master?
entries.text:
In the 80’s, an US researcher claims to have identified the zombie poison: tetrodotoxin, the poison of the fugu. At the University Medical Center in Aachen, Angelika Lampert wants to find out, whether this can be true. She empoisons muscle- and heart muscle-cells. The stunning result: While the muscles are blocked by tetrodotoxin, the heart can continue to beat at a low frequency. The experiment shows that the buried zombies might have never been dead, but buried alive and only seeming dead.

Sarah Juliet Lauro wants to find out how far the zombie can be traced back in history. In the colonial sources, she finds the word “zombie”, but in a European understanding. But she also finds a much earlier source with a mention of a myth that sounds very familiar. Souls are stolen and people are forced to work as slaves. The myth comes from the Kingdom of Loango in West Central Africa. Is this the home of the zombie myth? Maybe. But the Haitian revolution is a crucial moment for the myth at this is the moment when the word Zombie and its meaning come together. For Lauro it is a myth about slavery, but also about resistance.

A fact that still shows today, as people are dressing up as zombies in order to demonstrate against capitalism.

Zombies and Demonization of Voudoun

When most of us think of Voudoun, we think of voodoo dolls and witch doctors, which leads to the demonization of a real religion and the people who practice it. So when you add the Zombie, which is both a victim and monster from the Voudoun tradition, it only served to scare us further away.

A Zombie is simultaneously a Haitian Monster and Victim of Voudoun, and in both forms, it serves to scare us away from even wanting to understand its practitioners or traditions, which is made to look mostly like voodoo dolls, zombies and scary witches. What I become curious about is how many Black American Christians might take interest in Voudoun, an American born Black tradition that draws from African roots—if it wasn’t so demonized. And at the same time, I wonder how the demonization of this black tradition serves to reinforce racism. In either case, keeping voudoun so demonized is a way to keep it subdued throughout the North American Hemisphere.

entries.question: Why do you think is the typical zombie-setting of a small group of survivors so thrilling?
entries.text:
The survival of few against is a theme of most Zombie stories, which is about the survival of the free will against the body which is why you always see the heroes more willing to take their own lives than become a zombie. On another level, in that it is always a story of very few against a risen mob, it presents the structure of a small elite with brains and agency against a mindless mass; which can quickly turn it into a story of the 1%’s survival against the rich-eating 99.

Insofar as the zombie is always projected onto the mindless other, it sets up a psychological configuration that identifies one's own family or tribe or the cast of a movie as the center of consciousness meant to be saved from zombie hoards.

In most zombie stories today, we follow a few brave survivors who face an overwhelming hoard, which leads us to identify with that elite one percent at odds with the masses.

The American Center of Disease Control created a lot of controversy when it released a statement that preparing for a Zombie Apocalypse will have you prepared for most major survival events.

Zombies are mirrors of us as zombies – not just as individuals but as collectives. When we see massive zombie populations creating an apocalypse, it plays into our fears of humanity consuming itself from overpopulation.

But who are the zombie hoards? Are we just thinking about a literal zombie apocalypse, or do we project our fear of over-population onto populations we other, shadow and demonize? FUndamentally,c the zombies are the many and the few escapees are the few. This, in some ways, is representative of the 1% in relation to the global population. So many zombie movies are about making it to the final encampment of well organized consciousness and governance, typically run by militaries with a white, christian and european lineages. Upper classes have always associated themselves with a higher caste and often with the head or crown, and they have often seen the masses as the body. The Zombie conflict is one of the head against the body, the many against the few.

entries.question: How individualistic is the zombie and what does this mean for its versatility? Could we say because it’s so unindividualistic that it can be used as an expression for multiple fears of society?
entries.text: The Zombie is used to show us where and how we conform. When we see them on the streets in work clothes or school uniforms, we are seeing the modes of life through which we can act like zombies. Are employees encouraged to think for themselves? Are Students given agency to choose what they learn? Can we fall into routine through a relationship? Can we give our mind over to politics, or religion? Zombies show up to help us see where we are at risk of not thinking for ourselves — they teach us to not become puppets. When there is a witch or puppet master controlling them, we learn to watch out for secret tyrants pulling strings. When they are driven by consumption, we are taught that consumerism can make us followers.

entries.question: Why do people like to watch Horror movies?
entries.text: People watch horror movies, on one level, to lay eyes on their demons — to see the mirrors of their inner threats. A good horror story teaches us to not be vampiric or zombified, and it gives us a chance to imagine conflict and resolution with these inner tendencies. And Zombie movies don’t just give us the monster, they show us the proper response. Protagonists in these stories are always arcing towards free will and agency.

FREE WILL ARC: In Zombieland and in Shaun of the Dead, we see characters stuck in their own routines, stuck in their own Zombification, which they have to transcend.  The arc of heroes in zombie movies is the transcendence of their own routines. Shaun has to get beyond the bar and the protagonist in Zombieland has to finally break one of his rules to be a hero. We are all slaves to ourselves, and we project our own self enslavement onto every historical and fictional example. Remember to see movies as the dream of a dreamer. What is a zombie movie? Who are the zombies in the mind of the dreamer?

SCIENCE: Continuing to evolve this understanding with our own modern spiritual commitment to science, we encounter the scientific conviction that there is no free will, that there is no consciousness or soul, that we are all only zombies, that everything we do is just the body doing it. The brain is just body. Thoughts are just material processes unfolding. The universe is deterministic, everything is causal, mechanical, and there is no free will in existence.

ROBOT: Here then we see the connection of the zombie with the robot. From Frankenstein to the mummy, zombie, robot, ghost and vampire, we’re dealing with representations of soul in relation to body. Pinocchio, robots in movies about the emergence of consciousness, zombies eating brains, soulless vampires with immortal bodies, reanimated mummies – and while all work with overlapping motifs, they all show us different features. We see the question of free will or consciousness appear with the zombie, puppet and robot, but where zombie emphasizes the body, puppets emphasize the control of others and robots emphasize the potential that we are empty of consciousness and free will in the first place.

ZOMBIE WASTELAND: The wasteland is a reality without vitality – sometimes this means without crops or babies or rain, but on another level, it's become about the lack of freedom or free will, spirit, soul and creative energies. This might look like a civilization collapsed or it might look like a society oppressed. In the case of oppression, we see dystopian narratives. In the case of collapsed civilizations, the wasteland is expressed by the inability to create the collaborations required to sustain society. This results in the normal motifs of the lack of food and resource, the lack of new creations and the lack of new infancy. The zombie takes wasteland imagery to another level. Here we see the body as a wasteland – a body without freedom or free will, without soul, without the ability to be a creator, as humans are meant to be, without the ability to procreate and in constant need of resource—especially food.

No creative power

HEAD VS BODY – FEW VS MANY: Zombies are mirrors of us as zombies – not just as individuals but as collectives. When we see massive zombie populations creating an apocalypse, it plays into our fears of humanity consuming itself from overpopulation. Insofar as the zombie is always projected onto the mindless other, it sets up a psychological configuration that identifies one's own family or tribe or the cast of a movie as the center of consciousness meant to be saved from zombie hoards. But who are the zombie hoards? Are we just thinking about a literal zombie apocalypse, or do we project our fear of over-population onto populations we other, shadow and demonize? FUndamentally, the zombies are the many and the few escapees are the few. This, in some ways, is representative of the 1% in relation to the global population. So many zombie movies are about making it to the final encampment of well organized consciousness and governance, typically run by militaries with a white, christian and european lineages. Upper classes have always associated themselves with a higher caste and often with the head or crown, and they have often seen the masses as the body. The Zombie conflict is one of the head against the body, the many against the few.

BIOLOGICAL INFECTIONS: Zombie infections are biological – from 28 days later to Kingsman and the Golden Circle. Biological infections or drugs are focused on the body and how the body infects or threatens consciousness, which we see in Golden Circle, when the zombie infection begins as a mind altering drug.

SURVIVAL: Deepening the relationship of the zombie archetype with embodiment, zombie movies are typically about survival, and when it comes down to it, it's more about the survival of soul than the survival of body, as is seen when, film after film, protagonists prepare suicide of the body to save something more precious. The value system is clearly stated – life of the body is not the priority, which is what the zombie is all about.

ZOMBIE MYTH & GLOBAL MYTHOS: Each major myth in our global mythological landscape builds out our mythological imagination in such a way that both extends what it is but expresses consistency. Zombies, witches, vampires – they all fill out the psyche. Zombies are what we are in the normal world. Vampires are feeding off of them. Witches are repressed. Zombies are people of the wasteland, wasted people, spiritless bodies.

SLAVE TO BODY & BODILY FUNCTIONS: Notice when people die in Zombieland – primary danger is going to the bathroom and trying to find food, whether it’s in a Twinkie truck or a grocery store. These are bodily needs that come from the process of consumption.

episodes.title: Bigfoot & Yeti
episodes.summary: Hidden from the eyes of mankind, fabulous creatures are said to live deep in the forests of Central America and high up in the mountains of the Himalayas – Bigfoot and Yeti: huge, hairy and extremely...

entries.text: Hidden from the eyes of mankind, fabulous creatures are said to live deep in the forests of Central America and high up in the mountains of the Himalayas – Bigfoot and Yeti: huge, hairy and extremely shy. However, there is no clear evidence of their existence so far. Nevertheless, the unknown creatures fascinate explorers and scientists and inspire numerous films and stories. Amateur researchers like Matt and Michael go on expeditions again and again to prove the existence of Bigfoot.

For Jeff Meldrum, professor of anatomy and anthropology at Idaho State University, Bigfoot belongs to the giant ape species Gigantopithecus, which lives deep in the forests. Meldrum's evidence includes footprints, skeletal models and hair samples. For him, his samples lead to only one conclusion: both the footprints and the hair come from Gigantopithecus - from Bigfoot.

Prof. Dr. Kullmer from the Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and wants to test Jeff Meldrum's thesis. With the help of the most modern research methods, he is examining the few fossil finds of Gigantopithecus. They reveal that the giant ape was a pure vegetarian and had to rely on extreme amounts of food due to its size. But during the ice age, the food supply was far too small. In addition, savannahs are gradually replacing the large forests. All of this suggests to the expert that Gigantopithecus is extinct. But then what creature is behind the footprints that are repeatedly attributed to the Bigfoot?

Experiment footprints: It is striking that most Bigfoot sightings come from areas that bears also count as their preferred habitat. Animal keeper Raphael takes a plaster cast of a brown bear and compares it with the footprints of the alleged Bigfoot sightings. The tracks are very similar and lead to the conclusion that the alleged Bigfoot tracks are also bear tracks.But the myth of Bigfoot and Yeti lives on in people's minds.

entries.question: How does Bigfoot/ Yeti look like?
entries.text:
Scientists are actually firm defenders of huge apes and hairy humans that thrive in wilderness. The question is if they’re here today.

Bigfoot, known also as Sasquatch, has the appearance of a near-human great ape. From the forests of North America to the Himalayan Mountains, where the Yeti is found, these figures are hairy and strong, not as upright as we are, less capable of language, and still in the woods, which is the description of our own evolutionary ancestors. This is to say, one of the most interesting things about Big Foot, when compared to other mythical monsters, is that Scientists are actually firm defenders in the existence of what they are. The question is they’re still around.

One of the critical details when it comes to comparing Gigantopithicus with Big Foot is that its dental arcade is arch shaped, like ours. As we stood up and separated from the apes, we developed this arch and opened space for our voice. We see this in Gigantopithicus.

entries.question: Where do myths (about Bigfoot and Yeti) come from?
entries.text: We evolved from animals, but we want to believe we are civilized. This tension plays out in the stories of wild hairy men and our belief—or denial—of their existence.

entries.question: When we go back to the first epic, to one of the earliest accounts of a wild hairy man in the forest, we see Enkidu, the best friend and sidekick to Gilgamesh, become civilized. Do we have an animal nature that needs civilized? If you do, you have psyche to project into Big Foot.
entries.text:
Humans used to look in the mirror and see something like Big Foot, and so when we see big foot, we see our ancient selves, our animal selves. Wherever the stories and legends emerge, whatever their specifics, where they come from in us is our never ending relationship with our animal nature – sometimes repressed, sometimes engaged and always in contrast to what we are now: civilized.

Projected, the repression of our inner animal can become a denial of Big Foot’s existence.

And on the other side, the pursuit of Big Foot can contain the pursuit of our pre-fallen nature, which is why we can see some Big Foot hunters become like wild men. But this is only when it becomes extreme. Most of us oppress our ancient instincts and deny that wild men are real, but we are all drawn to our animal nature—an animal nature that Big Foot reflects.

Denial of Big Foot is fuelled by the repression of our inner animal. Fascination with Big Foot is a fascination with our inner animal. And love of Big Foot is a love of our inner animal, which aligns with our understanding of what it was to be one with Eden and God before the fall. This is where we get images of Big Foot as possessing the mystical powers of Adam—our pre-fallen ancestor.

Figures like the Big Foot or Yeti don’t just recur around the world and across our mythic landscape, we also dream and make movies about them. They’re in our mind. Not so long ago, we were more animal than human, we still have these tendencies, and in the same way we repress our animal instincts to be civilized, civilization denies the existence of bigfoot.

In the world’s oldest epic, Gilgamesh, the best friend and sidekick is a wild hairy man who lived in the forest, and, before he was civilized, terrorized people.

The archetypal essence of Big Foot and comparable figures is at least as old as old as the world’s first epic, Gilgamesh, who’s best friend and sidekick fit the core description: a wild, hairy man who lived in the forest.

Going back to the first epic, we see wild hairy men in the forest; and when we go back to Gilgamesh, the ancient source reveals an arc for this character: to become civilized. And so we see the true meaning of the myth of big foot – it is a civilizing myth. On one level, it’s about defining civilized consciousness by contrasting it with our animal nature, and on another level, it’s used to teach us not to believe in anything abnormal or undiscovered.

In this ancient source, we don’t just find a stagnant creature, we find a character arc. Enkidu, the best friend and Sidekick becomes civilized. This shows us what Big Foot is in our minds—a pre-civilized animal-person.

From the Tibetan stories of the Himalayan Yeti to the North American Big Foot, we find stories about these comparable figures around the world. The Epics of India describe monkey people.  Hunters in the Caucasus learn not to track the hairy mountain dwellers. And the best friend of Gilgamesh, Enkidu, was a wild hairy man.

But this figure doesn’t just recur throughout our mythic landscape, Planet of the Apes is a recurring dream scenario. Big Foot, real or not, is an archetypal figure, and what it represents is our animal selves, which we repress, tame and shave.

The Yeti is a character in ancient legends and folklore of the Himalaya people. In most of the tales, the Yeti is a figure of danger.

The myth of Bigfoot comes from the indigenous cultures across the North American continent include tales of mysterious hair-covered creatures living in forests.

entries.question: The stories about Bigfoot rise because of the first sightings. The indigenous people were sure that a giant creature roamed the forests. This brings us to the question: Does Bigfoot really exist?
entries.text: One of the core qualities of the recurring Big Foot myth is that – from Tibet to North America – it’s the people in the indigenous people and the people in the country who believe it’s true, not the civilized people in normal society. We find this in the Americas—indigenous stories and rural reports against science and civilization.

entries.question: There are three different Yetis / Bigfoot? What is the difference between them?
entries.text:
There is the yeti in our mind and the yeti in our world. The Yeti in our world could be a great ape, a brown bear or an ancient human, but all it really needs to be is a decent mirror for our own projection, and in the case of the Yeti, or big foot, that projection is our own animal nature.

Big Foot and the Big Bad Wolf teach us to fear the animal nature of humans.

entries.question: Why do so many people believe in myths?
entries.text:
People believe what they identify as true. The truths some see in the Big Foot story is that people are fools and think foolish things.

Myths help us understand our reality. On a social level, the myth of big foot teaches us to be normal and doubt the unknown. On a psychological level, it teaches us to repress and distinguish ourselves from our animal nature. On a cosmological level, it teaches us that our role in existence is not to be embedded in creation, but to observe it, consciously, like the scientific heroes with proof about Big Foot.

entries.question: Myths are usually understood as stories about gods or divine figures. They answer big questions such as: how was the world created? Where do humans come from? How did we learn to make fire, or to smith metal?
entries.text:
When we ask if a mythic creature is real, the question is a bit misframed. It is real in our imagination, and the reason it is real in our imagination is because something inside has found a way to co-exist with something outside.

Myths are as relevant to us today as they were to the ancients. Myths answer timeless questions and serve as a compass to each generation. The myths of lost paradise, for example, give people hope that by living a virtuous life, they can earn a better life in the hereafter. The myths of a golden age give people hope that there are great leaders who will improve their lives. The hero's quest is a model for young men and women to follow, as they accept adult responsibilities. Some myths simply reassure, such as myths that explain natural phenomena as the actions of gods, rather than arbitrary events of nature.

entries.question: Why people think that Bigfoot really exist?
entries.text: A lot of beliefs go into one’s belief in big foot – a belief that they are zoologically or biologically possible, that scientists and dismissive authorities are not to be trusted, that wilderness exists and that new discoveries can still be made. At the same time, our relationship with our own inner animal is beneath the surface, which sets up those in denial of their animal nature to be in denial of Big Foot, and visa versa.

entries.question: What is it in ourselves that we want to exist, or not exist, that Big Foot represents? Do we repress or miss our animal nature. Big Foot is free of civilization and connected with earth, which some of us want and some of us fear.
entries.text:
Some people see these creature as symbols of pure freedom, living by instinct and foiling every effort to pin them down. To search for Bigfoot in the forest is to taste that freedom. As long as there are wild places, Bigfoot remains a possibility that cannot be disproved.

Some People hope that there is still something supernatural that gives them power. Something we don't know about yet.

Belief in Big Foot can have to do with the fact it is biologically or zoologically possible. It can be a response to the distrust of science and dismissive authorities  It can influenced by whether or not we believe there is any wilderness or unknown left. And. And it can be reinforced by our conflicted desire to repress and engage our own animal instincts.

entries.question: Does the Yeti influence the existence of Bigfoot?
entries.text: Big Foot did not become an American sensation until a journalist connected large footprints in California to the Himalayan Yeti, who had appeared in the New York Times when, six years prior, footprints had been discovered. On one level, it’s possible that the Himalayan figure helped seed the American imagination. On another, the close appearance of the figure on multiple continents and in multiple mythologies is part of the concept itself—that these creatures are everywhere. And so seeing their everywhereness helped give birth to the mythic image we have today.

entries.text:
Essential to the Big Foot myth is that it is a myth -- that anyone who believes it is crazy. And beneath this myth is another myth -- that we know everything, that we’ve been everywhere, that there is no unknown. Big Foot hunters are drawn to the unexplored in search of the unknown – to forests and mountains -- where, still, today, we find new species. The Okapi, for example, was only just discovered, and, as far as Big Foot Hunters are concerned, it’s not half as intelligent or capable of evasion.

Convictions about Big Foot are often displaced convictions about the unknown.

entries.text:
Mythologically, we don’t just see animals as less civilized, we also see them as more connected. And so, in the myth of Big Foot, we don’t just see an uncivilized monster, we also see a connected being, who, in some cases, has mystical powers. These powers are like those of Adam before the fall, lost to civilization.

To say there is no more BigFoot is to say there is no more human-animal in humanity’s dreamscape. Flipped around, a planet of the apes, from the movies to my own dreams, are about a world run by animal nature. Human uprising within a planet of the apes, at least in my own dreams, are about awakening and living into what makes humans more than animal, which has to do with a type of consciousness that can step outside of a system and look at it, to see it from above — not an animal in nature, a conscious observing free thinking being that may have come from nature but has also achieved the level of self awareness required to transcend our basic animalistic nature. This is not to say animals aren’t wise, one with the universe, enlightened or ensouled — it’s to say that animals are still part of nature in a way that humans are not. We are in from and of nature, we are, but, we are also apart, even if it’s only in the way that we have the ability to think we’re apart. Big Foot is not apart, big foot is in and of nature.

OPPRESSION OF NATURE CONSCIOUSNESS: The mythic demonization of our animal nature separates us from the consciousness our animal nature is capable of, which is its most mystical nature, its most telepathic nature, its most spiritually powerful nature.
