episodes.title: Witches
episodes.summary: Hardly any figure fascinates and frightens us more than the witch does. From the hunchbacked old wicked witch to cheeky children witches to a rebellious idol - they enchant us at all times. However,...

entries.text: Hardly any figure fascinates and frightens us more than the witch does. From the hunchbacked old wicked witch to cheeky children witches to a rebellious idol - they enchant us at all times. However, is it all just fantasy and fiction or does the myth contain a kernel of truth? Should it all be fiction, why have people been afraid of and trying witchcraft as serious felonies, punishable with death sentence? Should the stories about witches be true, do they actually have magical powers – and use them today?

Nowadays, the witch is celebrating a revival as a modern, empowered and independently spiritual woman. One of them is ShiSha Rainbow in Berlin, who shares her knowledge and experiences as part of the hashtag #witchtok community on TikTok and other social media outlets. While it might seem like a contemporary trend, the knowledge and practices run centuries into the past. How much truth do the reports about witchcraft contain and do Shisha, her ancestors and idols have proper magical powers in the end?

There is a wide variety of sources about witches. The first one and properly most famous one are fairy tales and folklore. Kathrin Pöge-Alder is a researcher in that field and shows how the famous tale of “Hansel and Gretel” of the Grimm brothers developed one the famous archetypes of the wicked, child eating witch. As the Grimm brothers recorded those tales in the 19th century, the question remains where these ideas originate.

The traces in folklore and literature lead all the way back to antiquity – the field of research of theologian and researcher of magic texts and rites Professor Marco Frenschkowski. He points to the different kinds of magical women in ancient Roman texts and poetry, such as Circe, Medea or Erichto. Women, whose powers and description range from seductive potion maker to cruel corpse eating necromancer.

While literature is full of women inflicting magic upon man, archaeological sources reveal that magical rituals were exercised widely in Roman society. Professor Frenschkowski travels to Rome to examine the finds of the fountain of Anna Perenna for the first time himself – inscribed clay poppets and metal containers as well as curse tablets. All of them bear witness to the commonality of magical rituals in those times (4th century BCE to 6th century CE) – however, all magic comes with a price and it was the dark, harmful kind of magic that was feared and policed in the Twelve Tables Law during Roman times.

The fear of harmful magic is also a common denominator in the records of the early modern witch trials of the 15th century onwards. In Überlingen, a small town in the south of Germany, historian Professor Johannes Dillinger finds intriguing reports: witches were accused to bewitch the weather, kill people, and cause inexplicable sickness in human and animal. Both men and women were found guilty to have a pact with the devil, partake in secret witch meet ups and dances, use their magic for evil and even have sexual relations with the devil and his demons.

A felony so severe that it was punished with death – in many European countries, including Germany, death by fire. There are not many remains of those executions as the fire was usually extremely thorough; however, archaeologists near Konstanz might have found some. The examinations are still ongoing, but the few remains of burnt bones already impressively show the fear of what would happen if anything of the witch remained in this world. If she did not burn and vanish completely, it could influence her own afterlife and leave a risk of her returning.

The knowledge and ideas about witches were spread and explored by theologians, scientists, judges, and demonologists – educated people of church and state. One of them was the infamous Heinrich Kramer, author of the Maleus Maleficarum. Besides the many accusations he brings up especially against women being more receptive to the devil, he also claims that the source of flight is an ointment made out of children’s bones. Other scholars of his time and the following years pick up on the ointment and develop theories about the possible ingredients – could maybe psychedelic plants like nightshades be responsible for visions of the witches’ dance and flight?

Professor Frenschkowski, though, only finds those theories in circles of scholars, and neither Professor Dillinger can find any traces of the actual so-called witches using those ointments for flying in the court records. The two historians agree: A hallucinogenic ointment only serves as a pseudo-scientific explanation to credit accusations upon completely innocent people.
The theory had a short spark in interest during the 1950-60s, when the witch discourse had its revival as part of the esoteric as well as the feminist movements.

The question remains: how can mysterious phenomena occur where people believe in witches? In Salem, Massachusetts, the fits of the two girls spread and others showed the symptoms, too. Was it just theatrics? Professor Dillinger knows of another case in a German village, where children started the have mysterious symptoms after the husband of a known witch in the village died. Can the mere belief in the witch’s power make people sick?

Researchers of the nocebo effect such as Professor Winfried Rief and Christoph Benke, PhD, know that this is very much a possibility. In an experiment, they illustrate how the body reacts when the brain thinks it cannot breathe even though there is plenty of oxygen supply. It shows that believes can have such a very powerful strength that it reaches into and changes the physical realm.

That is also true for ShiSha Rainbow, the modern witch in Berlin. Together with her mother, who is also a witch, she is performing a healing ritual. Whether it achieves actual healing is secondary for ShiSha; the ritual itself already strengthens her.

In the end, witches continue being a myth. Different sources tell of their existence over the different times and of the different levels of fear and imaginations that people connected and projected upon them. Whether they actually have magical powers remains a mystery. However, the fact that belief itself can have such deep implications for people is in itself pretty magical.

The word witch comes from the same root as whit, which means clever. Prometheus was clever. The clever one, in myth, is a revolutionary, and the State, like Zeus in the story of Prometheus, has a tendency to want to put down the clever ones. So the silencing of witches is the silencing of rebellious cleverness, and in the case of the European witches, this cleverness had to do with the knowledge and wisdom of Europe that Christianity worked to completely snuff out.

The mythic image of the witch is constantly refreshed by our shifting cultural relationships with magic, nature and femininity.

Built into the Classical and Christian stories about the origins of knowledge and humanity is an association of the feminine with materiality. This is why the word Mater means both mother and matter in Latin[DS1] . The Material world is the mother’s world, earth, and like earth, the mother possesses the power of creation. This is why nature’s power of creation is associated with the mother’s power of creation, which is the foundational power beneath all witchcraft.

Masculine envy for the mother’s power of creation is seen in the story of Zeus carrying Dionysus in his thigh, which serves as a makeshift womb.

This power of creation is not the power of a steam engine, gunpowder or money. The power of creation comes from the wombs of nature, not the mechanisms of human effort. The power of life and creation is understood to draw from powers yet untapped by humanity, powers that magic is meant to influence.

The annihilation of witches is inseparable from the rise of emphasis on human manipulation of the material world. Man vs. Witch is actually a Man vs. Nature story – the witch represents the forces of nature and creation that the Enlightenment paradigm wanted to repress.

Their vision of the world was a vision of dead matter interacting in purely mechanical ways. There is no magic in this system, which means there was no room for witches in this paradigm.

Similarly, where there is patriarchy there are witches. Where there is patriarchy there is the oppression of women and the repression of femininity. But again, the patriarchy isn’t just oppressing women for being women. In this paradigm that gives us mater as mother and matter, we also get Pater, which means father and pattern[DS2] . Embedded in the patriarchal oppression of women is the oppression of matter.

The oppression of matter, on one level, looks like the technological mastery of the material world and the social mastery of women. On another level, it looks like the philosophical objectification of both matter and women. Matter becomes seen as dead stuff. Bodies become seen as dead stuff. The material world with which mothers are associated shifts from being seen as alive with the power of creation becomes seen as a lifeless machine. To reduce matter to bodies comes with the reduction of women to bodies. Super interesting!

entries.question: So why, why is masculine consciousness doing this? The answer is very simple. Ego and power. Men have been able to gain power over women, which has enabled them to build a world around the male ego. The male ego includes all of its fears and insecurities.
entries.text:
Fundamentally, men do not have the power to create, which means they live alongside a partner-gender with a supreme divine power that it cannot even begin to match. What happens in this situation? Fear and inferiority complexes start to create narratives that demonize and minimize this power in women. Measures are taken to reduce this power over them.

And this is not the only power women have over men. Women are often experienced by men as more psychologically advanced, meaning they are more capable of manipulating them. Whether they do or not, the capacity is recognized, feared and reacted against. Thus we see narratives that demonize the feminine capacity to enchant.

We all fear enchantment when it comes to love, and from a masculine perspective, there have been negative romantic enchantments that ended in various suffering. This is remembered in the mythic record by those in power. These memories are turned into lessons when romantic interests are demonized for the way they can hurt us. In a man’s world, the one to blame will always be the woman. This rolls into the witch figures.

The power of wives over men is colored by the history of abduction. When women were stolen from war, not only were they likely to carry vitriol for their new husbands, they also brought technical and magical knowledge that was entirely foreign to their captors. Myths are filled with narratives of foreigner-witch-wives that jeopardize their husbands, from Medea to the mother of Alexandre the Great.

MOTHER:  The other major experience of overwhelming feminine power is that of the mother from the perspective of the child. Thus we see wonderful fairy godmothers and terrible wicked witches throughout our folklore – these aren’t just representations of our various ways of relating to femininity and the power of nature, these are also representations of our various ways of experiencing the mother. The mother has absolutely overwhelming power over the child, who is completely dependent on the mother – like a human is on the earth. This sets up multiple layers of threat that can transmute into demonization narratives. The mother not only has the immediate power to nurture or punish, she also has the power of resource. Both are overwhelming powers for the child, which experiences early feelings of anger and resentment towards the mother for punishments and the withholding of nurturing. In the case of the most significant witch hunter of all time, King James, his mother’s love was withheld from him by another mother who decapitated her.

MALE FEARS: In a world controlled by men, all of these masculine fears, insecurities and resentments of nature, creation, mothers, lovers and women comes together in the image of the witch.

The reason witches are associated with the devil is because the Devil has also come to be associated with the powers of nature, which is understood in a Christian consciousness as Fallen. Nature is constantly corrupting the soul, which is symbolized by the seductions of Pandora and Eve, who draw masculine consciousness into the fallen material world. This fallen world is the domain of the devils as much as it is the domain of women. From this perspective, the womb isn’t a great power of creation, it’s the portal through which souls fall. Thus the seduction of the devil and the seduction of the woman are one – both call for the fall, and both entice with the fruit and bodies of a material world. Both represent the magic of the earth, which is imagined to be at odds with the will of the heavens.

Once we recognize the association of the woman with the mortal and material, we understand why witches are so frequently beautiful or aged. They are beautiful to represent the seductive nature of the material world. They are aged to represent the dreaded reality of aging that comes from entering the body and its mortal material world. In the aged witch we see the transference of our own anxieties around aging and death.

For thousands of years, the West has lived within a bubble of perspectives that demonize women and present the material world as fallen. If we go back further in time and search further into the world, we find women-witches that carry all the powers of creation, maternity and seduction without demonization. We see this in the figures of Isis, Inanna and Aphrodite, all of which were associated with Venus, the first star you see at night, the wishing star — the green star associated with the power of love and creation.

I think it’s important to go back and look at these figures. But it leads us to a key question – are the core qualities associated with the feminine, whether they’re seen in positive or negative lights – are these objectively feminine, or are these cultural contrivances? This is going to be an essential part of our conversation in the breakout.

One thing we will come to understand is that where some cultures aligned the earth first and foremost with the womb of life, other cultures prioritized a vision of a cosmic womb. These cultures tend to align the earth with the masculine and the sky with the feminine, which goes back to a memory presented by a key figure in the lineage of witches, Lilith, the first wife of Adam according to Hebrew folklore, who refused to let Adam be on top when they made love. This may be a memory of a historic power struggle between men and women, but it may also be a memory of a conflict between mythic interpretations of the sky as feminine or masculine.  This also sets up an association of the good mother with the heavens and the bad mother with the earth. This is seen with Mary, who is always dressed in Blue and seems to have been influenced by Egyptian iconography, which presented the heavens as a (blue) cosmic womb. Similarly, good fairies from Cinderella to the Wizard of Oz and Pinocchio are Blue. This is the divine good heavenly mother as opposed to the fallen, green faced witch so associated with nature.

entries.question: What is behind the healing effect of dragon body parts? Why do we believe that body parts of a mythical creature could help, heal or make us invincible?
entries.text:
When Segfried became invincible by bathing in dragons blood, but where a leaf had remained on his body, he had a weak spot. This is like the weak spot of Achilles, dipped in the Styx by his heal. But this is also the weak spot of metal, when quenched in a fluid to make it hard. A weak spot remains where it’s held by the tongs. This is clarified by a myth in the Caucasus, where the man of steel is created in the smithy, and who retains a weak spot where held by the tongs. In these stories, dragon bones refer to coal that was used to heat the iron, which is revealed as the dragon blood that protected Siegfried – a poetic representation of Iron armor, including its flaw.

The Placebo effect is very real, but it only works when the imagination of the sick expects to be healed. Dragons heal by healing the imagination. Dragons are killed to kill the imagination.

Dragon power is power of the imagination, and so the association of the dragon with the placebo is a recognition that the imagination can heal.

Dragon bones coal and dragon blood is the fluid in which we quench steel blades.  – this has to do with iron armor, which makes us invincible.

entries.question: Difference good-evil. Why do some cultures make the dragon the creator of life and others make him responsible for everything bad in the world?
entries.text:
Conquerors demonize their enemies, so when rivers were conquered, the dragons that represented them became seen as demons. Because China’s river valley civilizations were never conquered by outsiders, they still valorize their dragons. However, the other great river civilizations that grew around their ability to feed people were defeated in the iron age, by greater weapons. And as the river valleys were subdued, stories emerged of dragons defeated by heroes. The conquering emperors of China took a different approach, instead, they claimed to be the dragons and usurped their icons.

entries.text: Fragen für Will Linn zu SINTFLUT

entries.question: What does the story of the Great Flood stand for? What is the message?
entries.text: Flood myths can be found all over the world, and they typically separate mythic time from real time – it is the great wiping clean of the time before time. Because the earliest cities were dependent on flooding rivers, they didn’t just bring danger, they brought fertility to the fields. So while the annual floods brought annual renewal, the great flood brought the renewal of an entire epoch, like a collective baptism.

entries.question: What kind of god is presented in the story of the Great Flood? (a punishing god more than a god of mercy and forgiveness)
entries.text:
The Old Testament god was known for his wrath. And like other divine patriarchs, he carries qualities of a storm god, who expresses his anger in the form of a storm.

It’s also the case that the old testament god was more visibly participatory in the cultures for which he is responsible.

entries.question: Why is the story of a Great Flood present in other cultures as well? (Aborigines, India, Iceland, Maya…)
entries.text: When you look at the horizon, it comes to a point – the same happens with the mythic imagination; and so the distant memory of multiple major floods are likely to have converged to form these myths—the melting of glaciers, the river floods of ancient cities, perhaps a flood in the Black Sea... And floods are traumatizing. Myths then serve these memories while responding to the trauma and delivering wisdom.

entries.question: Can real events become a myth? And could there be real historical events that could have let to the biblical myth of the Great Flood?
entries.text: Real events can definitely become myths and we should always look for the potential histories beneath the surface. That having been said: flattening myths to a single historic event is often misguided. So the flood in Hebrew mythology is believed to have been influenced by the Sumerian flood myth, which is likely to have been influenced by the civilization’s annual floods and potentially that of the Black Sea.

entries.question: Are the stories of the bible based on true facts? Could also the Great Flood referring to a real event?
entries.text: Its most common for historical memories to become embellished with mythic motifs over time – especially with Oral Narratives, which are not fixed in writing.

entries.question: How can we interpret the fact that so many legends revolve around the element of water?
entries.text:
Life comes and goes with water, which behaves very differently than things. While two things can’t be in the same place at the same time, waves can, which is why quests for enlightenment and union are often quests for elixirs. When we see waves in the world we see the capacity for union.

A symbol’s ability to reflect our projections is grounded in the real qualities of that symbol. Life comes and goes with water, and so water becomes associated with life.

entries.question: What’s the mythological meaning of rivers, lakes, or the sea?
entries.text:
Our origins were nurtured by water of womb and sea. This is mythologized in the form of sunken cities and the ancient claim we evolved from fish. We see ocean life as older, and when we see water as vitality and origin, we seethe Hebrew Tehom to the Egyptian Nu, oceans of chaos and creation.

The ocean is a place of transformation. When a character is swallowed by the sea at sunset and return with sunrise, they return reborn, as though from a womb.

From Ideas like:

In fairy tales, myths and works of art, a river, lake or sea often stands for childhood as a maternal element. Evolution could then be compared to human life: from the simplest life form in the water, resembling an embryo in the amniotic fluid of the womb, to a more conscious being on land, the adult human being. But what if evolution in the water has evolved independently of that on land?

entries.question: What does the wide ocean stand for mythologically?
entries.text:
A drop of water is one with the ocean. A grain of sand is apart from the desert. Waves and water do not behave like things on land. To cross or dive under the waves is not just a journey into the unknown, it is into a world that can teach us the way of resonance, of likeness, of union—these are the ways of dream, metaphor and myth. As we see in the Argonautica, the initiation of Hercules begins when he’s swallowed.

A drop becomes the sea in mystical poetry about union. The sea is made of water that moves like waves, which, are capable of superposition—or, in spiritual and existential terms, union. The one can be many and the many can be one. A single coned speaker plays a single wave, in which we hear every instrument. Waves and water do not operate like things on land. To be at sea, or underwater, is to be in another world. For this reason, to dive or cross the sea has become a metaphor for any otherworld journeys.

entries.question: What social function did the tales of sea monsters have in history? Was it to give form to the uncertain?
entries.text:
We fear the disasters that come from the ocean, and in an effort to make them predictable, we personify the ocean’s will. Typically, a sailor already has some notion of sea monsters, which are ready projections when things go awry. These monsters are then, ambassadors of the unknown. For someone this might mean a demon, or it might mean a god.

We want to believe in an other, which must come from an other place. And so before the focus on aliens, we saw otherness in the sea.

The ocean gives an image into which we project the unknown, and when a sea monster emerges and disappears again, they come as ambassadors to the unknown. For someone this might be a demon, but for another this could be a lover. Whatever is charged up in you will be looking for mirrors onto which it can project.

When looking for symbolic meaning we are trying to recognize a range of supported projections.

entries.question: Should we believe in sea monsters? Dismiss them as fantasy? Reduce them to oarfish, squid and storms? Or is the sea monster something emergent? Not entirely psychological or reductively real—myths, it would seem, are sparked when dreaming consciousness finds living mirrors.
entries.text: The natural material world is always in co-creation with our mythic imagination. When some inner configuration finds its mirror in the outer world, when it finds a totem for its projection, that’s when myths are born.

entries.question: What is the Origin of the “Moby Dick” story?
entries.text:
A historical precedent for Moby Dick can be found in Mocha Dick, a sperm whale that destroyed a ship and, as in Melville’s narrative, was white as “snow,” Its story appeared in a 1939 Knickerbocker article, and the great American author met with a witnessing sailor.

—> In “Monsters of the Sea” by Richard Ellis, he writes on p. 210:

The whale Moby Dick did not spring fully formed from the mind of Herman Melville. In 1835, there was a whale known as “Mocha Dick”, named for the island of Mocha off the Chilean coast, that terrorized and sank whale ships and was introduced in J. N. Reynolds’s May 1839 article in the Knickerbocker Magazine. The whale ship Essex was stove and sunk by a sperm whale in the Pacific in 1820, and Melville is known to have spoken to the mate, Owen Chase, about the incident. In 1851, another whaler, the Ann Alexander, was sunk by a sperm whale, but that was too late for Melville, since Moby-Dick was published in that year.

entries.question: What is the Leviathan?
entries.text:
Leviathan has become synonymous with sea monster. It comes from the Bible and is comparable to the monsters slain by Zeus and Marduk when they built their world. These monsters were often conglomerate creatures—serpents, crocodiles, whales and squid—which represents their unbound nature. To defeat the sea monster is to forge order from chaos.

entries.question: Could the Minoan culture be the real people of Atlantis?
entries.text: The Fall of the Minoans started just after the eruption of Thera and continued until just after the fall of Troy. It’s possible that the Minoans participated in a larger alliance of sea faring cultures that included a significant port city in the Atlantic, and it’s possible a series of natural and human disasters led to the gradual decline of that network, which was ultimately displaced by Phoenicians around that time. From my point of view, the Minoans are not THE Atlantians, but given a few of Plato’s descriptions, it seems likely that they influenced his story.

entries.question: Why do people search for Atlantis? Did the search itself even become a myth?
entries.text: The search for Atlantis is like a quest for the grail—a myth unto itself.  From Disney to Hasboro, DC & Marvel – stories of the search for Atlantis or other underwater civilizations are common.

entries.question: Some people think Atlantis is an Alien colony or even a UFO. Others think it lays iin the Bermuda Triangle emitting crystal energy beams. Why are there so many theories about supernatural connections to Atlantis?
entries.text: There are a lot of supernatural theories, and you’ve got to locate them somewhere. The Atlantian mystery creates a blank screen for endless projection. That having been said, it checks a lot of boxes. The idea of advanced technology opens into the alien myth, as does their existence beneath the water, which would provide the atmospheric pressure required for aliens on bigger planets, which is what we tend to find when looking for habitable bodies. So there’s enough plausibility and mystery mixed together to sustain almost anything.

entries.question: If there was a culture of Atlantis, would their ancestors still live today?
entries.text:
One of the interesting things about the Atlantian myths is that you don’t hear much from the ancient sources on what the survivors did. The story seems to be that they all just disappeared. If they did exist, however, there would have been traveling survivors, whose children would still be with us.

The culture of Atlantis is alive in the Brits, who seemed to feel existentially frustrated by a land-locked economy. Their nature is to exist across a network of islands and ports, not unlike the Atlantians.
